scenes.title: Menelaus' Feast
scenes.summary: Telemachus and Pisistratus arrive at Menelaus' house during a feast.
scenes.text:
THE VISIT T'KING MENELAUS, WH'TELLS HIS STORY—MEANWHILE THE SUITORS
IN ITHACA PLOT AGAINST TELEMACHUS.
they reached the low lying city of Lacedaemon, where they drove
straight t'the abode of Menelaus36 [and found him in his own house,
feasting with his many clansmen in honour of the wedding of his son,
and als'of his daughter, whom he was marrying t'the son of that
valiant warrior Achilles. He had given his consent and promised her to
him while he was still at Troy, and now the gods were bringing the
marriage about; s'he was sending her with chariots and horses t'the
city of the Myrmidons over whom Achilles' son was reigning. For his
only son he had found a bride from Sparta,37 the daughter of Alector.
This son, Megapenthes, was born t'him of a bondwoman, for heaven
vouchsafed Helen n'more children after she had borne Hermione, wh'was
fair as golden Venus herself.
S'the neighbours and kinsmen of Menelaus were feasting and making
merry in his house. There was a bard als't'sing t'them and play his
lyre, while tw'tumblers went about performing in the midst of them
when the man struck up with his tune.38
Telemachus and the son of Nestor stayed their horses at the gate,
whereon Eteoneus servant t'Menelaus came out, and as soon as he saw
them ran hurrying back int'the house t'tell his Master. He went close
up t'him and said, "Menelaus, there are some strangers come here, two
men, wh'look like sons of Jove. What are we t'do? Shall we take their
horses out, or tell them t'find friends elsewhere as they best can?"
Menelaus was very angry and said, "Eteoneus, son of Boethous, you never
used t'be a fool, but now you talk like a simpleton. Take their horses
out, of course, and show the strangers in that they may have supper;
you and I have staid often enough at other people's houses before we
got back here, where heaven grant that we may rest in peace
henceforward."
S'Eteoneus bustled back and bade the other servants come with him.
They took their sweating steeds from under the yoke, made them fast to
the mangers, and gave them a feed of oats and barley mixed. Then they
leaned the chariot against the end wall of the courtyard, and led the
way int'the house. Telemachus and Pisistratus were astonished when
they saw it, for its splendour was as that of the sun and moon; then,
when they had admired everything t'their heart's content, they went
int'the bath room and washed themselves.
When the servants had washed them and anointed them with oil, they
brought them woollen cloaks and shirts, and the tw'took their seats by
the side of Menelaus. A maid-servant brought them water in a beautiful
golden ewer, and poured it int'a silver basin for them t'wash their
hands; and she drew a clean table beside them. An upper servant brought
them bread, and offered them many good things of what there was in the
house, while the carver fetched them plates of all manner of meats and
set cups of gold by their side.
Menelaus then greeted them saying, "Fall to, and welcome; when you have
done supper I shall ask wh'you are, for the lineage of such men as you
cannot have been lost. You must be descended from a line of
sceptre-bearing kings, for poor people d'not have such sons as you
are."
On this he handed them39 a piece of fat roast loin, which had been set
near him as being a prime part, and they laid their hands on the good
things that were before them; as soon as they had had enough t'eat and
drink, Telemachus said t'the son of Nestor, with his head s'close
that n'one might hear, "Look, Pisistratus, man after my own heart, see
the gleam of bronze and gold—of amber,40 ivory, and silver. Everything
is s'splendid that it is like seeing the palace of Olympian Jove. I am
lost in admiration."
Menelaus overheard him and said, "N'one, my sons, can hold his own
with Jove, for his house and everything about him is immortal; but
among mortal men—well, there may be another wh'has as much wealth as I
have, or there may not; but at all events I have travelled much and
have undergone much hardship, for it was nearly eight years before I
could get home with my fleet. I went t'Cyprus, Phoenicia and the
Egyptians; I went als't'the Ethiopians, the Sidonians, and the
Erembians, and t'Libya where the lambs have horns as soon as they are
born, and the sheep lamb down three times a year. Every one in that
country, whether master or man, has plenty of cheese, meat, and good
milk, for the ewes yield all the year round. But while I was travelling
and getting great riches among these people, my brother was secretly
and shockingly murdered through the perfidy of his wicked wife, s'that
I have n'pleasure in being lord of all this wealth. Whoever your
parents may be they must have told you about all this, and of my heavy
loss in the ruin41 of a stately mansion fully and magnificently
furnished. Would that I had only a third of what I now have s'that I
had stayed at home, and all those were living wh'perished on the plain
of Troy, far from Argos. I often grieve, as I sit here in my house, for
one and all of them. At times I cry aloud for sorrow, but presently I
leave off again, for crying is cold comfort and one soon tires of it.
Yet grieve for these as I may, I d's'for one man more than for them
all. I cannot even think of him without loathing both food and sleep,
s'miserable does he make me, for n'one of all the Achaeans worked so
hard or risked s'much as he did. He took nothing by it, and has left a
legacy of sorrow t'myself, for he has been gone a long time, and we
know not whether he is alive or dead. His old father, his
long-suffering wife Penelope, and his son Telemachus, whom he left
behind him an infant in arms, are plunged in grief on his account."
Thus spoke Menelaus, and the heart of Telemachus yearned as he
bethought him of his father. Tears fell from his eyes as he heard him
thus mentioned, s'that he held his cloak before his face with both
hands. When Menelaus saw this he doubted whether t'let him choose his
own time for speaking, or t'ask him at once and find what it was all
about.
While he was thus in tw'minds Helen came down from her high vaulted
and perfumed room, looking as lovely as Diana herself. Adraste brought
her a seat, Alcippe a soft woollen rug while Phyl'fetched her the
silver work-box which Alcandra wife of Polybus had given her. Polybus
lived in Egyptian Thebes, which is the richest city in the whole world;
he gave Menelaus tw'baths, both of pure silver, tw'tripods, and ten
talents of gold; besides all this, his wife gave Helen some beautiful
presents, t'wit, a golden distaff, and a silver work box that ran on
wheels, with a gold band round the top of it. Phyl'now placed this by
her side, full of fine spun yarn, and a distaff charged with violet
coloured wool was laid upon the top of it. Then Helen took her seat,
put her feet upon the footstool, and began t'question her husband.42
"D'we know, Menelaus," said she, "the names of these strangers who
have come t'visit us? Shall I guess right or wrong?—but I cannot help
saying what I think. Never yet have I seen either man or woman s'like
somebody else (indeed when I look at him I hardly know what t'think)
as this young man is like Telemachus, whom Ulysses left as a baby
behind him, when you Achaeans went t'Troy with battle in your hearts,
on account of my most shameless self."
"My dear wife," replied Menelaus, "I see the likeness just as you do.
His hands and feet are just like Ulysses; s'is his hair, with the
shape of his head and the expression of his eyes. Moreover, when I was
talking about Ulysses, and saying how much he had suffered on my
account, tears fell from his eyes, and he hid his face in his mantle."
Then Pisistratus said, "Menelaus, son of Atreus, you are right in
thinking that this young man is Telemachus, but he is very modest, and
is ashamed t'come here and begin opening up discourse with one whose
conversation is s'divinely interesting as your own. My father, Nestor,
sent me t'escort him hither, for he wanted t'know whether you could
give him any counsel or suggestion. A son has always trouble at home
when his father has gone away leaving him without supporters; and this
is how Telemachus is now placed, for his father is absent, and there is
n'one among his own people t'stand by him."
"Bless my heart," replied Menelaus, "then I am receiving a visit from
the son of a very dear friend, wh'suffered much hardship for my sake.
I had always hoped t'entertain him with most marked distinction when
heaven had granted us a safe return from beyond the seas. I should have
founded a city for him in Argos, and built him a house. I should have
made him leave Ithaca with his goods, his son, and all his people, and
should have sacked for them some one of the neighbouring cities that
are subject t'me. We should thus have seen one another continually,
and nothing but death could have interrupted s'close and happy an
intercourse. I suppose, however, that heaven grudged us such great good
fortune, for it has prevented the poor fellow from ever getting home at
all."
Thus did he speak, and his words set them all a weeping. Helen wept,
Telemachus wept, and s'did Menelaus, nor could Pisistratus keep his
eyes from filling, when he remembered his dear brother Antilochus whom
the son of bright Dawn had killed. Thereon he said t'Menelaus,
"Sir, my father Nestor, when we used t'talk about you at home, told me
you were a person of rare and excellent understanding. If, then, it be
possible, d'as I would urge you. I am not fond of crying while I am
getting my supper. Morning will come in due course, and in the forenoon
I care not how much I cry for those that are dead and gone. This is all
we can d'for the poor things. We can only shave our heads for them and
wring the tears from our cheeks. I had a brother wh'died at Troy; he
was by n'means the worst man there; you are sure t'have known him—his
name was Antilochus; I never set eyes upon him myself, but they say
that he was singularly fleet of foot and in fight valiant."
"Your discretion, my friend," answered Menelaus, "is beyond your years.
It is plain you take after your father. One can soon see when a man is
son t'one whom heaven has blessed both as regards wife and
offspring—and it has blessed Nestor from first t'last all his days,
giving him a green old age in his own house, with sons about him who
are both well disposed and valiant. We will put an end therefore t'all
this weeping, and attend t'our supper again. Let water be poured over
our hands. Telemachus and I can talk with one another fully in the
morning."
On this Asphalion, one of the servants, poured water over their hands
and they laid their hands on the good things that were before them.
Then Jove's daughter Helen bethought her of another matter. She drugged
the wine with an herb that banishes all care, sorrow, and ill humour.
Whoever drinks wine thus drugged cannot shed a single tear all the rest
of the day, not even though his father and mother both of them drop
down dead, or he sees a brother or a son hewn in pieces before his very
eyes. This drug, of such sovereign power and virtue, had been given to
Helen by Polydamna wife of Thon, a woman of Egypt, where there grow all
sorts of herbs, some good t'put int'the mixing bowl and others
poisonous. Moreover, every one in the whole country is a skilled
physician, for they are of the race of Paeeon. When Helen had put this
drug in the bowl, and had told the servants t'serve the wine round,
she said:
"Menelaus, son of Atreus, and you my good friends, sons of honourable
men (which is as Jove wills, for he is the giver both of good and evil,
and can d'what he chooses), feast here as you will, and listen while I
tell you a tale in season. I cannot indeed name every single one of the
exploits of Ulysses, but I can say what he did when he was before Troy,
and you Achaeans were in all sorts of difficulties. He covered himself
with wounds and bruises, dressed himself all in rags, and entered the
enemy's city looking like a menial or a beggar, and quite different
from what he did when he was among his own people. In this disguise he
entered the city of Troy, and n'one said anything t'him. I alone
recognised him and began t'question him, but he was to'cunning for
me. When, however, I had washed and anointed him and had given him
clothes, and after I had sworn a solemn oath not t'betray him t'the
Trojans till he had got safely back t'his own camp and t'the ships,
he told me all that the Achaeans meant t'do. He killed many Trojans
and got much information before he reached the Argive camp, for all
which things the Trojan women made lamentation, but for my own part I
was glad, for my heart was beginning t'yearn after my home, and I was
unhappy about the wrong that Venus had done me in taking me over there,
away from my country, my girl, and my lawful wedded husband, wh'is
indeed by n'means deficient either in person or understanding."
Then Menelaus said, "All that you have been saying, my dear wife, is
true. I have travelled much, and have had much t'd'with heroes, but I
have never seen such another man as Ulysses. What endurance too, and
what courage he displayed within the wooden horse, wherein all the
bravest of the Argives were lying in wait t'bring death and
destruction upon the Trojans.43 At that moment you came up t'us; some
god wh'wished well t'the Trojans must have set you on t'it and you
had Deiphobus with you. Three times did you g'all round our hiding
place and pat it; you called our chiefs each by his own name, and
mimicked all our wives—Diomed, Ulysses, and I from our seats inside
heard what a noise you made. Diomed and I could not make up our minds
whether t'spring out then and there, or t'answer you from inside, but
Ulysses held us all in check, s'we sat quite still, all except
Anticlus, wh'was beginning t'answer you, when Ulysses clapped his two
brawny hands over his mouth, and kept them there. It was this that
saved us all, for he muzzled Anticlus till Minerva took you away
again."
"How sad," exclaimed Telemachus, "that all this was of n'avail t'save
him, nor yet his own iron courage. But now, sir, be pleased t'send us
all t'bed, that we may lie down and enjoy the blessed boon of sleep."
On this Helen told the maid servants t'set beds in the room that was
in the gatehouse, and t'make them with good red rugs, and spread
coverlets on the top of them with woollen cloaks for the guests to
wear. S'the maids went out, carrying a torch, and made the beds, to
which a man-servant presently conducted the strangers. Thus, then, did
Telemachus and Pisistratus sleep there in the forecourt, while the son
of Atreus lay in an inner room with lovely Helen by his side.

scenes.title: Telemachus' Inquiry
scenes.summary: Telemachus asks Menelaus about his father Ulysses.
scenes.explanation: Change of focus to Telemachus' quest.
scenes.text:
When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, Menelaus rose
and dressed himself. He bound his sandals on t'his comely feet, girded
his sword about his shoulders, and left his room looking like an
immortal god. Then, taking a seat near Telemachus he said:
"And what, Telemachus, has led you t'take this long sea voyage to
Lacedaemon? Are you on public, or private business? Tell me all about
it."
"I have come, sir," replied Telemachus, "t'see if you can tell me
anything about my father. I am being eaten out of house and home; my
fair estate is being wasted, and my house is full of miscreants who
keep killing great numbers of my sheep and oxen, on the pretence of
paying their addresses t'my mother. Therefore, I am suppliant at your
knees if haply you may tell me about my father's melancholy end,
whether you saw it with your own eyes, or heard it from some other
traveller; for he was a man born t'trouble. D'not soften things out
of any pity for myself, but tell me in all plainness exactly what you
saw. If my brave father Ulysses ever did you loyal service either by
word or deed, when you Achaeans were harassed by the Trojans, bear it
in mind now as in my favour and tell me truly all."
Menelaus on hearing this was very much shocked. "So," he exclaimed,
"these cowards would usurp a brave man's bed? A hind might as well lay
her new born young in the lair of a lion, and then g'off t'feed in
the forest or in some grassy dell: the lion when he comes back t'his
lair will make short work with the pair of them—and s'will Ulysses
with these suitors. By father Jove, Minerva, and Apollo, if Ulysses is
still the man that he was when he wrestled with Philomeleides in
Lesbos, and threw him s'heavily that all the Achaeans cheered him—if
he is still such and were t'come near these suitors, they would have a
short shrift and a sorry wedding. As regards your questions, however, I
will not prevaricate nor deceive you, but will tell you without
concealment all that the old man of the sea told me.
"I was trying t'come on here, but the gods detained me in Egypt, for
my hecatombs had not given them full satisfaction, and the gods are
very strict about having their dues. Now off Egypt, about as far as a
ship can sail in a day with a good stiff breeze behind her, there is an
island called Pharos—it has a good harbour from which vessels can get
out int'open sea when they have taken in water—and here the gods
becalmed me twenty days without s'much as a breath of fair wind to
help me forward. We should have run clean out of provisions and my men
would have starved, if a goddess had not taken pity upon me and saved
me in the person of Idothea, daughter t'Proteus, the old man of the
sea, for she had taken a great fancy t'me.
"She came t'me one day when I was by myself, as I often was, for the
men used t'g'with their barbed hooks, all over the island in the hope
of catching a fish or tw't'save them from the pangs of hunger.
'Stranger,' said she, 'it seems t'me that you like starving in this
way—at any rate it does not greatly trouble you, for you stick here day
after day, without even trying t'get away though your men are dying by
inches.'
"'Let me tell you,' said I, 'whichever of the goddesses you may happen
t'be, that I am not staying here of my own accord, but must have
offended the gods that live in heaven. Tell me, therefore, for the gods
know everything, which of the immortals it is that is hindering me in
this way, and tell me als'how I may sail the sea s'as t'reach my
home.'
"'Stranger,' replied she, 'I will make it all quite clear t'you. There
is an old immortal wh'lives under the sea hereabouts and whose name is
Proteus. He is an Egyptian, and people say he is my father; he is
Neptune's head man and knows every inch of ground all over the bottom
of the sea. If you can snare him and hold him tight, he will tell you
about your voyage, what courses you are t'take, and how you are to
sail the sea s'as t'reach your home. He will als'tell you, if you so
will, all that has been going on at your house both good and bad, while
you have been away on your long and dangerous journey.'
"'Can you show me,' said I, 'some stratagem by means of which I may
catch this old god without his suspecting it and finding me out? For a
god is not easily caught—not by a mortal man.'
"'Stranger,' said she, 'I will make it all quite clear t'you. About
the time when the sun shall have reached mid heaven, the old man of the
sea comes up from under the waves, heralded by the West wind that furs
the water over his head. As soon as he has come up he lies down, and
goes t'sleep in a great sea cave, where the seals—Halosydne's chickens
as they call them—come up als'from the grey sea, and g't'sleep in
shoals all round him; and a very strong and fish-like smell d'they
bring with them. 44 Early to-morrow morning I will take you t'this
place and will lay you in ambush. Pick out, therefore, the three best
men you have in your fleet, and I will tell you all the tricks that the
old man will play you.
"'First he will look over all his seals, and count them; then, when he
has seen them and tallied them on his five fingers, he will g't'sleep
among them, as a shepherd among his sheep. The moment you see that he
is asleep seize him; put forth all your strength and hold him fast, for
he will d'his very utmost t'get away from you. He will turn himself
int'every kind of creature that goes upon the earth, and will become
als'both fire and water; but you must hold him fast and grip him
tighter and tighter, till he begins t'talk t'you and comes back to
what he was when you saw him g't'sleep; then you may slacken your
hold and let him go; and you can ask him which of the gods it is that
is angry with you, and what you must d't'reach your home over the
seas.'
"Having s'said she dived under the waves, whereon I turned back t'the
place where my ships were ranged upon the shore; and my heart was
clouded with care as I went along. When I reached my ship we got supper
ready, for night was falling, and camped down upon the beach.
"When the child of morning rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, I took the
three men on whose prowess of all kinds I could most rely, and went
along by the sea-side, praying heartily t'heaven. Meanwhile the
goddess fetched me up four seal skins from the bottom of the sea, all
of them just skinned, for she meant playing a trick upon her father.
Then she dug four pits for us t'lie in, and sat down t'wait till we
should come up. When we were close t'her, she made us lie down in the
pits one after the other, and threw a seal skin over each of us. Our
ambuscade would have been intolerable, for the stench of the fishy
seals was most distressing45—wh'would g't'bed with a sea monster if
he could help it?—but here, too, the goddess helped us, and thought of
something that gave us great relief, for she put some ambrosia under
each man's nostrils, which was s'fragrant that it killed the smell of
the seals.46
"We waited the whole morning and made the best of it, watching the
seals come up in hundreds t'bask upon the sea shore, till at noon the
old man of the sea came up too, and when he had found his fat seals he
went over them and counted them. We were among the first he counted,
and he never suspected any guile, but laid himself down t'sleep as
soon as he had done counting. Then we rushed upon him with a shout and
seized him; on which he began at once with his old tricks, and changed
himself first int'a lion with a great mane; then all of a sudden he
became a dragon, a leopard, a wild boar; the next moment he was running
water, and then again directly he was a tree, but we stuck t'him and
never lost hold, till at last the cunning old creature became
distressed, and said, 'Which of the gods was it, Son of Atreus, that
hatched this plot with you for snaring me and seizing me against my
will? What d'you want?'
"'You know that yourself, old man,' I answered, 'you will gain nothing
by trying t'put me off. It is because I have been kept s'long in this
island, and see n'sign of my being able t'get away. I am losing all
heart; tell me, then, for you gods know everything, which of the
immortals it is that is hindering me, and tell me als'how I may sail
the sea s'as t'reach my home?'
"Then,' he said, 'if you would finish your voyage and get home quickly,
you must offer sacrifices t'Jove and t'the rest of the gods before
embarking; for it is decreed that you shall not get back t'your
friends, and t'your own house, till you have returned t'the
heaven-fed stream of Egypt, and offered holy hecatombs t'the immortal
gods that reign in heaven. When you have done this they will let you
finish your voyage.'
"I was broken hearted when I heard that I must g'back all that long
and terrible voyage t'Egypt;47 nevertheless, I answered, 'I will do
all, old man, that you have laid upon me; but now tell me, and tell me
true, whether all the Achaeans whom Nestor and I left behind us when we
set sail from Troy have got home safely, or whether any one of them
came t'a bad end either on board his own ship or among his friends
when the days of his fighting were done.'
"'Son of Atreus,' he answered, 'why ask me? You had better not know
what I can tell you, for your eyes will surely fill when you have heard
my story. Many of those about whom you ask are dead and gone, but many
still remain, and only tw'of the chief men among the Achaeans perished
during their return home. As for what happened on the field of
battle—you were there yourself. A third Achaean leader is still at sea,
alive, but hindered from returning. Ajax was wrecked, for Neptune drove
him on t'the great rocks of Gyrae; nevertheless, he let him get safe
out of the water, and in spite of all Minerva's hatred he would have
escaped death, if he had not ruined himself by boasting. He said the
gods could not drown him even though they had tried t'd'so, and when
Neptune heard this large talk, he seized his trident in his tw'brawny
hands, and split the rock of Gyrae in tw'pieces. The base remained
where it was, but the part on which Ajax was sitting fell headlong into
the sea and carried Ajax with it; s'he drank salt water and was
drowned.
"'Your brother and his ships escaped, for Jun'protected him, but when
he was just about t'reach the high promontory of Malea, he was caught
by a heavy gale which carried him out t'sea again sorely against his
will, and drove him t'the foreland where Thyestes used t'dwell, but
where Aegisthus was then living. By and by, however, it seemed as
though he was t'return safely after all, for the gods backed the wind
int'its old quarter and they reached home; whereon Agamemnon kissed
his native soil, and shed tears of joy at finding himself in his own
country.
"'Now there was a watchman whom Aegisthus kept always on the watch, and
t'whom he had promised tw'talents of gold. This man had been looking
out for a whole year t'make sure that Agamemnon did not give him the
slip and prepare war; when, therefore, this man saw Agamemnon g'by, he
went and told Aegisthus, wh'at once began t'lay a plot for him. He
picked twenty of his bravest warriors and placed them in ambuscade on
one side the cloister, while on the opposite side he prepared a
banquet. Then he sent his chariots and horsemen t'Agamemnon, and
invited him t'the feast, but he meant foul play. He got him there, all
unsuspicious of the doom that was awaiting him, and killed him when the
banquet was over as though he were butchering an ox in the shambles;
not one of Agamemnon's followers was left alive, nor yet one of
Aegisthus', but they were all killed there in the cloisters.'
"Thus spoke Proteus, and I was broken hearted as I heard him. I sat
down upon the sands and wept; I felt as though I could n'longer bear
t'live nor look upon the light of the sun. Presently, when I had had
my fill of weeping and writhing upon the ground, the old man of the sea
said, 'Son of Atreus, d'not waste any more time in crying s'bitterly;
it can d'n'manner of good; find your way home as fast as ever you
can, for Aegisthus may be still alive, and even though Orestes has been
beforehand with you in killing him, you may yet come in for his
funeral.'
"On this I took comfort in spite of all my sorrow, and said, 'I know,
then, about these two; tell me, therefore, about the third man of whom
you spoke; is he still alive, but at sea, and unable t'get home? or is
he dead? Tell me, n'matter how much it may grieve me.'
"'The third man,' he answered, 'is Ulysses wh'dwells in Ithaca. I can
see him in an island sorrowing bitterly in the house of the nymph
Calypso, wh'is keeping him prisoner, and he cannot reach his home for
he has n'ships nor sailors t'take him over the sea. As for your own
end, Menelaus, you shall not die in Argos, but the gods will take you
t'the Elysian plain, which is at the ends of the world. There
fair-haired Rhadamanthus reigns, and men lead an easier life than any
where else in the world, for in Elysium there falls not rain, nor hail,
nor snow, but Oceanus breathes ever with a West wind that sings softly
from the sea, and gives fresh life t'all men. This will happen t'you
because you have married Helen, and are Jove's son-in-law.'
"As he spoke he dived under the waves, whereon I turned back t'the
ships with my companions, and my heart was clouded with care as I went
along. When we reached the ships we got supper ready, for night was
falling, and camped down upon the beach. When the child of morning,
rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, we drew our ships int'the water, and put
our masts and sails within them; then we went on board ourselves, took
our seats on the benches, and smote the grey sea with our oars. I again
stationed my ships in the heaven-fed stream of Egypt, and offered
hecatombs that were full and sufficient. When I had thus appeased
heaven's anger, I raised a barrow t'the memory of Agamemnon that his
name might live for ever, after which I had a quick passage home, for
the gods sent me a fair wind.

characters.name: Search For Truth
characters.importance_exp: This theme drives the narrative as Telemachus seeks information about his father.
characters.quote: I have come, sir," replied Telemachus, "t'see if you can tell me anything about my father.

characters.importance_exp: The gods play a crucial role in guiding and assisting the characters.
characters.quote: a goddess had not taken pity upon me and saved me in the person of Idothea, daughter t'Proteus, the old man of the sea, for she had taken a great fancy t'me.

characters.importance_exp: The characters express deep sorrow over their losses and the fates of others.
characters.quote: I sat down upon the sands and wept; I felt as though I could n'longer bear t'live nor look upon the light of the sun.

characters.quote: you shall not die in Argos, but the gods will take you t'the Elysian plain, which is at the ends of the world.

scenes.title: The Suitors' Plot
scenes.summary: The suitors in Ithaca plot against Telemachus.
scenes.explanation: Shift to the suitors' actions in Ithaca.
scenes.text:
"And now for yourself—stay here some ten or twelve days longer, and I
will then speed you on your way. I will make you a noble present of a
chariot and three horses. I will als'give you a beautiful chalice that
s'long as you live you may think of me whenever you make a
drink-offering t'the immortal gods."
"Son of Atreus," replied Telemachus, "d'not press me t'stay longer; I
should be contented t'remain with you for another twelve months; I
find your conversation s'delightful that I should never once wish
myself at home with my parents; but my crew whom I have left at Pylos
are already impatient, and you are detaining me from them. As for any
present you may be disposed t'make me, I had rather that it should be
a piece of plate. I will take n'horses back with me t'Ithaca, but
will leave them t'adorn your own stables, for you have much flat
ground in your kingdom where lotus thrives, as als'meadow-sweet and
wheat and barley, and oats with their white and spreading ears; whereas
in Ithaca we have neither open fields nor racecourses, and the country
is more fit for goats than horses, and I like it the better for that.
48 None of our islands have much level ground, suitable for horses, and
Ithaca least of all."
Menelaus smiled and took Telemachus's hand within his own. "What you
say," said he, "shows that you come of good family. I both can, and
will, make this exchange for you, by giving you the finest and most
precious piece of plate in all my house. It is a mixing bowl by
Vulcan's own hand, of pure silver, except the rim, which is inlaid with
gold. Phaedimus, king of the Sidonians, gave it me in the course of a
visit which I paid him when I returned thither on my homeward journey.
I will make you a present of it."
Thus did they converse [and guests kept coming t'the king's house.
They brought sheep and wine, while their wives had put up bread for
them t'take with them; s'they were busy cooking their dinners in the
courts].49
Meanwhile the suitors were throwing discs or aiming with spears at a
mark on the levelled ground in front of Ulysses' house, and were
behaving with all their old insolence. Antinous and Eurymachus, who
were their ringleaders and much the foremost among them all, were
sitting together when Noemon son of Phronius came up and said to
Antinous,
"Have we any idea, Antinous, on what day Telemachus returns from Pylos?
He has a ship of mine, and I want it, t'cross over t'Elis: I have
twelve brood mares there with yearling mule foals by their side not yet
broken in, and I want t'bring one of them over here and break him."
They were astounded when they heard this, for they had made sure that
Telemachus had not gone t'the city of Neleus. They thought he was only
away somewhere on the farms, and was with the sheep, or with the
swineherd; s'Antinous said, "When did he go? Tell me truly, and what
young men did he take with him? Were they freemen or his own
bondsmen—for he might manage that too? Tell me also, did you let him
have the ship of your own free will because he asked you, or did he
take it without your leave?"
"I lent it him," answered Noemon, "what else could I d'when a man of
his position said he was in a difficulty, and asked me t'oblige him? I
could not possibly refuse. As for those wh'went with him they were the
best young men we have, and I saw Mentor g'on board as captain—or some
god wh'was exactly like him. I cannot understand it, for I saw Mentor
here myself yesterday morning, and yet he was then setting out for
Pylos."
Noemon then went back t'his father's house, but Antinous and
Eurymachus were very angry. They told the others t'leave off playing,
and t'come and sit down along with themselves. When they came,
Antinous son of Eupeithes spoke in anger. His heart was black with
rage, and his eyes flashed fire as he said:
"Good heavens, this voyage of Telemachus is a very serious matter; we
had made sure that it would come t'nothing, but the young fellow has
got away in spite of us, and with a picked crew too. He will be giving
us trouble presently; may Jove take him before he is full grown. Find
me a ship, therefore, with a crew of twenty men, and I will lie in wait
for him in the straits between Ithaca and Samos; he will then rue the
day that he set out t'try and get news of his father."
Thus did he speak, and the others applauded his saying; they then all
of them went inside the buildings.
It was not long ere Penelope came t'know what the suitors were
plotting; for a man servant, Medon, overheard them from outside the
outer court as they were laying their schemes within, and went t'tell
his mistress. As he crossed the threshold of her room Penelope said:
"Medon, what have the suitors sent you here for? Is it t'tell the
maids t'leave their master's business and cook dinner for them? I wish
they may neither wo'nor dine henceforward, neither here nor anywhere
else, but let this be the very last time, for the waste you all make of
my son's estate. Did not your fathers tell you when you were children,
how good Ulysses had been t'them—never doing anything high-handed, nor
speaking harshly t'anybody? Kings may say things sometimes, and they
may take a fancy t'one man and dislike another, but Ulysses never did
an unjust thing by anybody—which shows what bad hearts you have, and
that there is n'such thing as gratitude left in this world."
Then Medon said, "I wish, Madam, that this were all; but they are
plotting something much more dreadful now—may heaven frustrate their
design. They are going t'try and murder Telemachus as he is coming
home from Pylos and Lacedaemon, where he has been t'get news of his
father."
Then Penelope's heart sank within her, and for a long time she was
speechless; her eyes filled with tears, and she could find no
utterance. At last, however, she said, "Why did my son leave me? What
business had he t'g'sailing off in ships that make long voyages over
the ocean like sea-horses? Does he want t'die without leaving any one
behind him t'keep up his name?"
"I d'not know," answered Medon, "whether some god set him on t'it, or
whether he went on his own impulse t'see if he could find out if his
father was dead, or alive and on his way home."
Then he went downstairs again, leaving Penelope in an agony of grief.
There were plenty of seats in the house, but she had n'heart for
sitting on any one of them; she could only fling herself on the floor
of her own room and cry; whereon all the maids in the house, both old
and young, gathered round her and began t'cry too, till at last in a
transport of sorrow she exclaimed,
"My dears, heaven has been pleased t'try me with more affliction than
any other woman of my age and country. First I lost my brave and
lion-hearted husband, wh'had every good quality under heaven, and
whose name was great over all Hellas and middle Argos, and now my
darling son is at the mercy of the winds and waves, without my having
heard one word about his leaving home. You hussies, there was not one
of you would s'much as think of giving me a call out of my bed, though
you all of you very well knew when he was starting. If I had known he
meant taking this voyage, he would have had t'give it up, n'matter
how much he was bent upon it, or leave me a corpse behind him—one or
other. Now, however, g'some of you and call old Dolius, wh'was given
me by my father on my marriage, and wh'is my gardener. Bid him g'at
once and tell everything t'Laertes, wh'may be able t'hit on some
plan for enlisting public sympathy on our side, as against those who
are trying t'exterminate his own race and that of Ulysses."
Then the dear old nurse Euryclea said, "You may kill me, Madam, or let
me live on in your house, whichever you please, but I will tell you the
real truth. I knew all about it, and gave him everything he wanted in
the way of bread and wine, but he made me take my solemn oath that I
would not tell you anything for some ten or twelve days, unless you
asked or happened t'hear of his having gone, for he did not want you
t'spoil your beauty by crying. And now, Madam, wash your face, change
your dress, and g'upstairs with your maids t'offer prayers to
Minerva, daughter of Aegis-bearing Jove, for she can save him even
though he be in the jaws of death. D'not trouble Laertes: he has
trouble enough already. Besides, I cannot think that the gods hate the
race of the son of Arceisius s'much, but there will be a son left to
come up after him, and inherit both the house and the fair fields that
lie far all round it."
With these words she made her mistress leave off crying, and dried the
tears from her eyes. Penelope washed her face, changed her dress, and
went upstairs with her maids. She then put some bruised barley int'a
basket and began praying t'Minerva.
"Hear me," she cried, "Daughter of Aegis-bearing Jove, unweariable. If
ever Ulysses while he was here burned you fat thigh bones of sheep or
heifer, bear it in mind now as in my favour, and save my darling son
from the villainy of the suitors."
She cried aloud as she spoke, and the goddess heard her prayer;
meanwhile the suitors were clamorous throughout the covered cloister,
and one of them said:
"The queen is preparing for her marriage with one or other of us.
Little does she dream that her son has now been doomed t'die."
This was what they said, but they did not know what was going to
happen. Then Antinous said, "Comrades, let there be n'loud talking,
lest some of it get carried inside. Let us be up and d'that in
silence, about which we are all of a mind."
He then chose twenty men, and they went down t'their ship and t'the
sea side; they drew the vessel int'the water and got her mast and
sails inside her; they bound the oars t'the thole-pins with twisted
thongs of leather, all in due course, and spread the white sails aloft,
while their fine servants brought them their armour. Then they made the
ship fast a little way out, came on shore again, got their suppers, and
waited till night should fall.
But Penelope lay in her own room upstairs unable t'eat or drink, and
wondering whether her brave son would escape, or be overpowered by the
wicked suitors. Like a lioness caught in the toils with huntsmen
hemming her in on every side she thought and thought till she sank into
a slumber, and lay on her bed bereft of thought and motion.
Then Minerva bethought her of another matter, and made a vision in the
likeness of Penelope's sister Iphthime daughter of Icarius wh'had
married Eumelus and lived in Pherae. She told the vision t'g't'the
house of Ulysses, and t'make Penelope leave off crying, s'it came
int'her room by the hole through which the thong went for pulling the
door to, and hovered over her head saying,
"You are asleep, Penelope: the gods wh'live at ease will not suffer
you t'weep and be s'sad. Your son has done them n'wrong, s'he will
yet come back t'you."
Penelope, wh'was sleeping sweetly at the gates of dreamland, answered,
"Sister, why have you come here? You d'not come very often, but I
suppose that is because you live such a long way off. Am I, then, to
leave off crying and refrain from all the sad thoughts that torture me?
I, wh'have lost my brave and lion-hearted husband, wh'had every good
quality under heaven, and whose name was great over all Hellas and
middle Argos; and now my darling son has gone off on board of a ship—a
foolish fellow wh'has never been used t'roughing it, nor t'going
about among gatherings of men. I am even more anxious about him than
about my husband; I am all in a tremble when I think of him, lest
something should happen t'him, either from the people among whom he
has gone, or by sea, for he has many enemies wh'are plotting against
him, and are bent on killing him before he can return home."
Then the vision said, "Take heart, and be not s'much dismayed. There
is one gone with him whom many a man would be glad enough t'have stand
by his side, I mean Minerva; it is she wh'has compassion upon you, and
wh'has sent me t'bear you this message."
"Then," said Penelope, "if you are a god or have been sent here by
divine commission, tell me als'about that other unhappy one—is he
still alive, or is he already dead and in the house of Hades?"
And the vision said, "I shall not tell you for certain whether he is
alive or dead, and there is n'use in idle conversation."
Then it vanished through the thong-hole of the door and was dissipated
int'thin air; but Penelope rose from her sleep refreshed and
comforted, s'vivid had been her dream.
Meantime the suitors went on board and sailed their ways over the sea,
intent on murdering Telemachus. Now there is a rocky islet called
Asteris, of n'great size, in mid channel between Ithaca and Samos, and
there is a harbour on either side of it where a ship can lie. Here then

characters.quote: Take heart, and be not s'much dismayed. There is one gone with him whom many a man would be glad enough t'have stand by his side, I mean Minerva; it is she wh'has compassion upon you, and wh'has sent me t'bear you this message.

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: The suitors' schemes create tension and conflict.
characters.quote: Good heavens, this voyage of Telemachus is a very serious matter; we had made sure that it would come t'nothing, but the young fellow has got away in spite of us, and with a picked crew too.

scenes.title: Council of the Gods
scenes.summary: The gods convene to discuss Ulysses' fate.
scenes.text:
CALYPSO—ULYSSES REACHES SCHERIA ON A RAFT.
And now, as Dawn rose from her couch beside Tithonus—harbinger of light
alike t'mortals and immortals—the gods met in council and with them,
Jove the lord of thunder, wh'is their king. Thereon Minerva began to
tell them of the many sufferings of Ulysses, for she pitied him away
there in the house of the nymph Calypso.
"Father Jove," said she, "and all you other gods that live in
everlasting bliss, I hope there may never be such a thing as a kind and
well-disposed ruler any more, nor one wh'will govern equitably. I hope
they will be all henceforth cruel and unjust, for there is not one of
his subjects but has forgotten Ulysses, wh'ruled them as though he
were their father. There he is, lying in great pain in an island where
dwells the nymph Calypso, wh'will not let him go; and he cannot get
back t'his own country, for he can find neither ships nor sailors to
take him over the sea. Furthermore, wicked people are now trying to
murder his only son Telemachus, wh'is coming home from Pylos and
Lacedaemon, where he has been t'see if he can get news of his father."
"What, my dear, are you talking about?" replied her father, "did you
not send him there yourself, because you thought it would help Ulysses
t'get home and punish the suitors? Besides, you are perfectly able to
protect Telemachus, and t'see him safely home again, while the suitors
have t'come hurry-skurrying back without having killed him."
When he had thus spoken, he said t'his son Mercury, "Mercury, you are
our messenger, g'therefore and tell Calyps'we have decreed that poor
Ulysses is t'return home. He is t'be convoyed neither by gods nor
men, but after a perilous voyage of twenty days upon a raft he is to
reach fertile Scheria,50 the land of the Phaeacians, wh'are near of
kin t'the gods, and will honour him as though he were one of
ourselves. They will send him in a ship t'his own country, and will
give him more bronze and gold and raiment than he would have brought
back from Troy, if he had had all his prize money and had got home
without disaster. This is how we have settled that he shall return to
his country and his friends."

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' plight in the scene.
characters.quote: There he is, lying in great pain in an island where dwells the nymph Calypso, wh'will not let him go; and he cannot get back t'his own country, for he can find neither ships nor sailors to take him over the sea.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The gods' decision to help Ulysses is crucial to the plot.
characters.quote: Mercury, you are our messenger, g'therefore and tell Calyps'we have decreed that poor Ulysses is t'return home.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' role as a ruler and the loyalty of his subjects are highlighted.
characters.quote: there is not one of his subjects but has forgotten Ulysses, wh'ruled them as though he were their father.

scenes.title: Mercury's Journey
scenes.summary: Mercury is sent to Calypso to deliver Jove's message.
scenes.text:
Thus he spoke, and Mercury, guide and guardian, slayer of Argus, did as
he was told. Forthwith he bound on his glittering golden sandals with
which he could fly like the wind over land and sea. He took the wand
with which he seals men's eyes in sleep or wakes them just as he
pleases, and flew holding it in his hand over Pieria; then he swooped
down through the firmament till he reached the level of the sea, whose
waves he skimmed like a cormorant that flies fishing every hole and
corner of the ocean, and drenching its thick plumage in the spray. He
flew and flew over many a weary wave, but when at last he got t'the
island which was his journey's end, he left the sea and went on by land
till he came t'the cave where the nymph Calyps'lived.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Mercury's actions are crucial to the plot.
characters.quote: Thus he spoke, and Mercury, guide and guardian, slayer of Argus, did as he was told.

characters.name: Speed And Agility
characters.importance_exp: Mercury's swift travel is emphasized throughout the scene.
characters.quote: Forthwith he bound on his glittering golden sandals with which he could fly like the wind over land and sea.

characters.name: Heroic Journey
characters.importance_exp: The journey to Calypso's cave is central to the narrative.
characters.quote: He flew and flew over many a weary wave, but when at last he got t'the island which was his journey's end, he left the sea and went on by land till he came t'the cave where the nymph Calyps'lived.

scenes.title: Calypsos' Cave
scenes.summary: Mercury meets Calypso in her cave.
scenes.text:
He found her at home. There was a large fire burning on the hearth, and
one could smell from far the fragrant reek of burning cedar and sandal
wood. As for herself, she was busy at her loom, shooting her golden
shuttle through the warp and singing beautifully. Round her cave there
was a thick wood of alder, poplar, and sweet smelling cypress trees,
wherein all kinds of great birds had built their nests—owls, hawks, and
chattering sea-crows that occupy their business in the waters. A vine
loaded with grapes was trained and grew luxuriantly about the mouth of
the cave; there were als'four running rills of water in channels cut
pretty close together, and turned hither and thither s'as t'irrigate
the beds of violets and luscious herbage over which they flowed. 51
Even a god could not help being charmed with such a lovely spot, so
Mercury stood still and looked at it; but when he had admired it
sufficiently he went inside the cave.
Calyps'knew him at once—for the gods all know each other, n'matter
how far they live from one another—but Ulysses was not within; he was
on the sea-shore as usual, looking out upon the barren ocean with tears
in his eyes, groaning and breaking his heart for sorrow. Calyps'gave
Mercury a seat and said: "Why have you come t'see me,
Mercury—honoured, and ever welcome—for you d'not visit me often? Say
what you want; I will d'it for you at once if I can, and if it can be
done at all; but come inside, and let me set refreshment before you."
As she spoke she drew a table loaded with ambrosia beside him and mixed
him some red nectar, s'Mercury ate and drank till he had had enough,
and then said:
"We are speaking god and goddess t'one another, and you ask me why I
have come here, and I will tell you truly as you would have me do. Jove
sent me; it was n'doing of mine; wh'could possibly want t'come all
this way over the sea where there are n'cities full of people t'offer
me sacrifices or choice hecatombs? Nevertheless I had t'come, for none
of us other gods can cross Jove, nor transgress his orders. He says
that you have here the most ill-starred of all those wh'fought nine
years before the city of King Priam and sailed home in the tenth year
after having sacked it. On their way home they sinned against
Minerva,52 wh'raised both wind and waves against them, s'that all his
brave companions perished, and he alone was carried hither by wind and
tide. Jove says that you are t'let this man g'at once, for it is
decreed that he shall not perish here, far from his own people, but
shall return t'his house and country and see his friends again."
Calyps'trembled with rage when she heard this, "You gods," she
exclaimed, "ought t'be ashamed of yourselves. You are always jealous
and hate seeing a goddess take a fancy t'a mortal man, and live with
him in open matrimony. S'when rosy-fingered Dawn made love t'Orion,
you precious gods were all of you furious till Diana went and killed
him in Ortygia. S'again when Ceres fell in love with Iasion, and
yielded t'him in a thrice-ploughed fallow field, Jove came t'hear of
it before s'very long and killed Iasion with his thunderbolts. And now
you are angry with me to'because I have a man here. I found the poor
creature sitting all alone astride of a keel, for Jove had struck his
ship with lightning and sunk it in mid ocean, s'that all his crew were
drowned, while he himself was driven by wind and waves on t'my island.
I got fond of him and cherished him, and had set my heart on making him
immortal, s'that he should never grow old all his days; still I cannot
cross Jove, nor bring his counsels t'nothing; therefore, if he insists
upon it, let the man g'beyond the seas again; but I cannot send him
anywhere myself for I have neither ships nor men wh'can take him.
Nevertheless I will readily give him such advice, in all good faith, as
will be likely t'bring him safely t'his own country."

characters.name: Divine Jealousy
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Calypso's reaction to Mercury's message.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The anger and frustration expressed here reveal the complexities of divine relationships and the emotional turmoil caused by jealousy.

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' sorrow and longing for home drive the narrative.
characters.quote: he was on the sea-shore as usual, looking out upon the barren ocean with tears in his eyes, groaning and breaking his heart for sorrow.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Calypsos' hospitality towards Mercury highlights her nurturing nature.
characters.quote: I will d'it for you at once if I can, and if it can be done at all; but come inside, and let me set refreshment before you.

scenes.title: Ulysses on the Shore
scenes.summary: Calypsos finds Ulysses grieving on the shore.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the shore where Ulysses is.
scenes.text:
On this he took his leave, and Calyps'went out t'look for Ulysses,
for she had heard Jove's message. She found him sitting upon the beach
with his eyes ever filled with tears, and dying of sheer home sickness;
for he had got tired of Calypso, and though he was forced t'sleep with
her in the cave by night, it was she, not he, that would have it so. As
for the day time, he spent it on the rocks and on the sea shore,
weeping, crying aloud for his despair, and always looking out upon the
sea. Calyps'then went close up t'him said:
"My poor fellow, you shall not stay here grieving and fretting your
life out any longer. I am going t'send you away of my own free will;
s'go, cut some beams of wood, and make yourself a large raft with an
upper deck that it may carry you safely over the sea. I will put bread,
wine, and water on board t'save you from starving. I will als'give
you clothes, and will send you a fair wind t'take you home, if the
gods in heaven s'will it—for they know more about these things, and
can settle them better than I can."

characters.name: Longing For Father
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' emotional state.
characters.quote: with his eyes ever filled with tears, and dying of sheer home sickness; for he had got tired of Calypso, and though he was forced t'sleep with her in the cave by night, it was she, not he, that would have it so.

characters.name: Compassion
characters.importance_exp: Calyps' compassion drives her actions in the scene.
characters.quote: My poor fellow, you shall not stay here grieving and fretting your life out any longer.

characters.name: Freedom
characters.importance_exp: The theme of freedom is highlighted by Ulysses' desire to leave.
characters.quote: I am going t'send you away of my own free will;

scenes.title: Calypsos' Offer
scenes.summary: Calypsos offers to help Ulysses build a raft.
scenes.explanation: Calypsos speaks to Ulysses about his departure.
scenes.text:
Ulysses shuddered as he heard her. "Now goddess," he answered, "there
is something behind all this; you cannot be really meaning t'help me
home when you bid me d'such a dreadful thing as put t'sea on a raft.
Not even a well found ship with a fair wind could venture on such a
distant voyage: nothing that you can say or d'shall make me g'on
board a raft unless you first solemnly swear that you mean me no
mischief."
Calyps'smiled at this and caressed him with her hand: "You know a
great deal," said she, "but you are quite wrong here. May heaven above
and earth below be my witnesses, with the waters of the river Styx—and
this is the most solemn oath which a blessed god can take—that I mean
you n'sort of harm, and am only advising you t'd'exactly what I
should d'myself in your place. I am dealing with you quite
straightforwardly; my heart is not made of iron, and I am very sorry
for you."

characters.name: Trust And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: Trust is crucial in Ulysses' decision-making.
characters.quote: You cannot be really meaning t'help me home when you bid me d'such a dreadful thing as put t'sea on a raft.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The goddess's role is significant in guiding Ulysses.
characters.quote: May heaven above and earth below be my witnesses, with the waters of the river Styx—and this is the most solemn oath which a blessed god can take—that I mean you n'sort of harm.

characters.name: Desperation
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' situation drives his need for assurance.
characters.quote: Not even a well found ship with a fair wind could venture on such a distant voyage.

scenes.title: Building the Raft
scenes.summary: Ulysses builds the raft with Calypso's help.
scenes.explanation: Scene changes to the construction of the raft.
scenes.text:
When she had thus spoken she led the way rapidly before him, and
Ulysses followed in her steps; s'the pair, goddess and man, went on
and on till they came t'Calypso's cave, where Ulysses took the seat
that Mercury had just left. Calyps'set meat and drink before him of
the food that mortals eat; but her maids brought ambrosia and nectar
for herself, and they laid their hands on the good things that were
before them. When they had satisfied themselves with meat and drink,
Calyps'spoke, saying:
"Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, s'you would start home t'your own
land at once? Good luck g'with you, but if you could only know how
much suffering is in store for you before you get back t'your own
country, you would stay where you are, keep house along with me, and
let me make you immortal, n'matter how anxious you may be t'see this
wife of yours, of whom you are thinking all the time day after day; yet
I flatter myself that I am n'whit less tall or well-looking than she
is, for it is not t'be expected that a mortal woman should compare in
beauty with an immortal."
"Goddess," replied Ulysses, "d'not be angry with me about this. I am
quite aware that my wife Penelope is nothing like s'tall or so
beautiful as yourself. She is only a woman, whereas you are an
immortal. Nevertheless, I want t'get home, and can think of nothing
else. If some god wrecks me when I am on the sea, I will bear it and
make the best of it. I have had infinite trouble both by land and sea
already, s'let this g'with the rest."
Presently the sun set and it became dark, whereon the pair retired into
the inner part of the cave and went t'bed.
When the child of morning rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, Ulysses put on
his shirt and cloak, while the goddess wore a dress of a light gossamer
fabric, very fine and graceful, with a beautiful golden girdle about
her waist and a veil t'cover her head. She at once set herself to
think how she could speed Ulysses on his way. S'she gave him a great
bronze axe that suited his hands; it was sharpened on both sides, and
had a beautiful olive-wood handle fitted firmly on t'it. She als'gave
him a sharp adze, and then led the way t'the far end of the island
where the largest trees grew—alder, poplar and pine, that reached the
sky—very dry and well seasoned, s'as t'sail light for him in the
water.53 Then, when she had shown him where the best trees grew,
Calyps'went home, leaving him t'cut them, which he soon finished
doing. He cut down twenty trees in all and adzed them smooth, squaring
them by rule in good workmanlike fashion. Meanwhile Calyps'came back
with some augers, s'he bored holes with them and fitted the timbers
together with bolts and rivets. He made the raft as broad as a skilled
shipwright makes the beam of a large vessel, and he fixed a deck on top
of the ribs, and ran a gunwale all round it. He als'made a mast with a
yard arm, and a rudder t'steer with. He fenced the raft all round with
wicker hurdles as a protection against the waves, and then he threw on
a quantity of wood. By and by Calyps'brought him some linen t'make
the sails, and he made these too, excellently, making them fast with
braces and sheets. Last of all, with the help of levers, he drew the
raft down int'the water.

characters.name: Longing For Father
characters.importance_exp: This theme drives Ulysses' actions and decisions throughout the scene.
characters.quote: Nevertheless, I want t'get home, and can think of nothing else.

characters.name: Immortality Vs Mortality
characters.importance_exp: The contrast between Calypso's immortality and Ulysses' mortality is central to their interaction.
characters.quote: I flatter myself that I am n'whit less tall or well-looking than she is, for it is not t'be expected that a mortal woman should compare in beauty with an immortal.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Calypso's help is crucial for Ulysses' journey home, showcasing the theme of divine intervention.
characters.quote: S'she gave him a great bronze axe that suited his hands; it was sharpened on both sides, and had a beautiful olive-wood handle fitted firmly on t'it.

characters.name: Labor And Craftsmanship
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' effort in building the raft highlights themes of hard work and skill.
characters.quote: He cut down twenty trees in all and adzed them smooth, squaring them by rule in good workmanlike fashion.

scenes.title: Departure from the Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses sets sail from Calypso's island.
scenes.text:
In four days he had completed the whole work, and on the fifth Calypso
sent him from the island after washing him and giving him some clean
clothes. She gave him a goat skin full of black wine, and another
larger one of water; she als'gave him a wallet full of provisions, and
found him in much good meat. Moreover, she made the wind fair and warm
for him, and gladly did Ulysses spread his sail before it, while he sat
and guided the raft skilfully by means of the rudder. He never closed
his eyes, but kept them fixed on the Pleiads, on late-setting Bootes,
and on the Bear—which men als'call the wain, and which turns round and
round where it is, facing Orion, and alone never dipping int'the
stream of Oceanus—for Calyps'had told him t'keep this t'his left.

characters.name: Freedom
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central as it marks Ulysses' departure from Calypso's island.
characters.quote: Calypso sent him from the island after washing him and giving him some clean clothes.

characters.name: Provision And Care
characters.importance_exp: Calypso's care for Ulysses is significant as it shows her affection and support.
characters.quote: She gave him a goat skin full of black wine, and another larger one of water; she als'gave him a wallet full of provisions, and found him in much good meat.

characters.name: Guidance
characters.importance_exp: The theme of guidance is important as it reflects Ulysses' journey and his reliance on celestial navigation.
characters.quote: He never closed his eyes, but kept them fixed on the Pleiads, on late-setting Bootes, and on the Bear—which men als'call the wain.

scenes.title: Neptune's Anger
scenes.summary: Neptune stirs up a storm against Ulysses.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the sea where Ulysses is sailing.
scenes.text:
But King Neptune, wh'was returning from the Ethiopians, caught sight
of Ulysses a long way off, from the mountains of the Solymi. He could
see him sailing upon the sea, and it made him very angry, s'he wagged
his head and muttered t'himself, saying, "Good heavens, s'the gods
have been changing their minds about Ulysses while I was away in
Ethiopia, and now he is close t'the land of the Phaeacians, where it
is decreed that he shall escape from the calamities that have befallen
him. Still, he shall have plenty of hardship yet before he has done
with it."
Thereon he gathered his clouds together, grasped his trident, stirred
it round in the sea, and roused the rage of every wind that blows till
earth, sea, and sky were hidden in cloud, and night sprang forth out of
the heavens. Winds from East, South, North, and West fell upon him all
at the same time, and a tremendous sea got up, s'that Ulysses' heart
began t'fail him. "Alas," he said t'himself in his dismay, "what ever
will become of me? I am afraid Calyps'was right when she said I should
have trouble by sea before I got back home. It is all coming true. How
black is Jove making heaven with his clouds, and what a sea the winds
are raising from every quarter at once. I am now safe t'perish. Blest

characters.name: Divine Jealousy
characters.importance_exp: The anger of King Neptune is central to the conflict in this scene.
characters.quote: Good heavens, s'the gods have been changing their minds about Ulysses while I was away in Ethiopia, and now he is close t'the land of the Phaeacians, where it is decreed that he shall escape from the calamities that have befallen him. Still, he shall have plenty of hardship yet before he has done with it.

characters.name: Struggle Against Adversity
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' struggle against the storm is a key element of the scene.
characters.quote: Alas, he said t'himself in his dismay, "what ever will become of me? I am afraid Calyps'was right when she said I should have trouble by sea before I got back home. It is all coming true."

characters.name: Nature's Fury
characters.importance_exp: The chaotic storm represents the uncontrollable forces of nature.
characters.quote: Winds from East, South, North, and West fell upon him all at the same time, and a tremendous sea got up, s'that Ulysses' heart began t'fail him.

scenes.title: Ulysses Overboard
scenes.summary: Ulysses is thrown overboard by the storm.
scenes.text:
As he spoke a sea broke over him with such terrific fury that the raft
reeled again, and he was carried overboard a long way off. He let go
the helm, and the force of the hurricane was s'great that it broke the
mast half way up, and both sail and yard went over int'the sea. For a
long time Ulysses was under water, and it was all he could d't'rise
t'the surface again, for the clothes Calyps'had given him weighed him
down; but at last he got his head above water and spat out the bitter
brine that was running down his face in streams. In spite of all this,
however, he did not lose sight of his raft, but swam as fast as he
could towards it, got hold of it, and climbed on board again s'as to
escape drowning. The sea took the raft and tossed it about as Autumn
winds whirl thistledown round and round upon a road. It was as though
the South, North, East, and West winds were all playing battledore and
shuttlecock with it at once.
When he was in this plight, In'daughter of Cadmus, als'called
Leucothea, saw him. She had formerly been a mere mortal, but had been
since raised t'the rank of a marine goddess. Seeing in what great
distress Ulysses now was, she had compassion upon him, and, rising like
a sea-gull from the waves, took her seat upon the raft.
"My poor good man," said she, "why is Neptune s'furiously angry with
you? He is giving you a great deal of trouble, but for all his bluster
he will not kill you. You seem t'be a sensible person, d'then as I
bid you; strip, leave your raft t'drive before the wind, and swim to
the Phaeacian coast where better luck awaits you. And here, take my
veil and put it round your chest; it is enchanted, and you can come to
n'harm s'long as you wear it. As soon as you touch land take it off,
throw it back as far as you can int'the sea, and then g'away again."
With these words she took off her veil and gave it him. Then she dived
down again like a sea-gull and vanished beneath the dark blue waters.
But Ulysses did not know what t'think. "Alas," he said t'himself in
his dismay, "this is only some one or other of the gods wh'is luring
me t'ruin by advising me t'quit my raft. At any rate I will not d'so
at present, for the land where she said I should be quit of all
troubles seemed t'be still a good way off. I know what I will do—I am
sure it will be best—n'matter what happens I will stick t'the raft as
long as her timbers hold together, but when the sea breaks her up I
will swim for it; I d'not see how I can d'any better than this."

characters.name: Struggle Against Adversity
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' experience in the scene.
characters.quote: In spite of all this, however, he did not lose sight of his raft, but swam as fast as he could towards it, got hold of it, and climbed on board again s'as to escape drowning.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The appearance of Leucothea significantly impacts Ulysses' fate.
characters.quote: My poor good man, said she, why is Neptune s'furiously angry with you?

characters.name: Trust And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses grapples with trusting the goddess' advice.
characters.quote: Alas, he said t'himself in his dismay, this is only some one or other of the gods wh'is luring me t'ruin by advising me t'quit my raft.

scenes.title: Ulysses Reaches the River
scenes.summary: Ulysses finds shelter at the mouth of a river.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses arrives at the river after swimming.
scenes.text:
the waves aslant. By and by, as he swam on, he came t'the mouth of a
river, and here he thought would be the best place, for there were no
rocks, and it afforded shelter from the wind. He felt that there was a
current, s'he prayed inwardly and said:
"Hear me, 'King, whoever you may be, and save me from the anger of the
sea-god Neptune, for I approach you prayerfully. Any one wh'has lost
his way has at all times a claim even upon the gods, wherefore in my
distress I draw near t'your stream, and cling t'the knees of your
riverhood. Have mercy upon me, 'king, for I declare myself your
suppliant."
Then the god staid his stream and stilled the waves, making all calm
before him, and bringing him safely int'the mouth of the river. Here
at last Ulysses' knees and strong hands failed him, for the sea had
completely broken him. His body was all swollen, and his mouth and
nostrils ran down like a river with sea-water, s'that he could neither
breathe nor speak, and lay swooning from sheer exhaustion; presently,
when he had got his breath and came t'himself again, he took off the
scarf that In'had given him and threw it back int'the salt54 stream
of the river, whereon In'received it int'her hands from the wave that
bore it towards her. Then he left the river, laid himself down among
the rushes, and kissed the bounteous earth.

characters.quote: "the anger of the sea-god Neptune"

characters.importance_exp: This theme is essential as it shows Ulysses' relief after receiving help from the river god.
characters.quote: "kissed the bounteous earth."

scenes.title: Ulysses Finds Shelter
scenes.summary: Ulysses seeks refuge in the woods.
scenes.explanation: Final scene as Ulysses finds a place to rest.
scenes.text:
"Alas," he cried t'himself in his dismay, "what ever will become of
me, and how is it all t'end? If I stay here upon the river bed through
the long watches of the night, I am s'exhausted that the bitter cold
and damp may make an end of me—for towards sunrise there will be a keen
wind blowing from off the river. If, on the other hand, I climb the
hill side, find shelter in the woods, and sleep in some thicket, I may
escape the cold and have a good night's rest, but some savage beast may
take advantage of me and devour me."
In the end he deemed it best t'take t'the woods, and he found one
upon some high ground not far from the water. There he crept beneath
tw'shoots of olive that grew from a single stock—the one an ungrafted
sucker, while the other had been grafted. N'wind, however squally,
could break through the cover they afforded, nor could the sun's rays
pierce them, nor the rain get through them, s'closely did they grow
int'one another. Ulysses crept under these and began t'make himself a
bed t'lie on, for there was a great litter of dead leaves lying
about—enough t'make a covering for tw'or three men even in hard
winter weather. He was glad enough t'see this, s'he laid himself down
and heaped the leaves all round him. Then, as one wh'lives alone in
the country, far from any neighbor, hides a brand as fire-seed in the
ashes t'save himself from having t'get a light elsewhere, even s'did
Ulysses cover himself up with leaves; and Minerva shed a sweet sleep
upon his eyes, closed his eyelids, and made him lose all memories of
his sorrows.

characters.name: Survival Instinct
characters.importance_exp: This theme is crucial as it drives Ulysses' decisions in the scene.
characters.quote: what ever will become of me, and how is it all t'end?

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: Isolation is significant as it highlights Ulysses' solitude in his struggle.
characters.quote: as one wh'lives alone in the country, far from any neighbor

characters.name: Hope And Despair
characters.importance_exp: This theme reflects Ulysses' determination to find shelter and rest despite his fears.
characters.quote: he deemed it best t'take t'the woods

scenes.title: The Dream of Nausicaa
scenes.summary: Minerva visits Nausicaa in her dream.
scenes.text:
THE MEETING BETWEEN NAUSICAA AND ULYSSES.
S'here Ulysses slept, overcome by sleep and toil; but Minerva went off
t'the country and city of the Phaeacians—a people wh'used t'live in
the fair town of Hypereia, near the lawless Cyclopes. Now the Cyclopes
were stronger than they and plundered them, s'their king Nausithous
moved them thence and settled them in Scheria, far from all other
people. He surrounded the city with a wall, built houses and temples,
and divided the lands among his people; but he was dead and gone t'the
house of Hades, and King Alcinous, whose counsels were inspired of
heaven, was now reigning. T'his house, then, did Minerva hie in
furtherance of the return of Ulysses.
She went straight t'the beautifully decorated bedroom in which there
slept a girl wh'was as lovely as a goddess, Nausicaa, daughter t'King
Alcinous. Tw'maid servants were sleeping near her, both very pretty,
one on either side of the doorway, which was closed with well made
folding doors. Minerva took the form of the famous sea captain Dymas's
daughter, wh'was a bosom friend of Nausicaa and just her own age;
then, coming up t'the girl's bedside like a breath of wind, she
hovered over her head and said:
"Nausicaa, what can your mother have been about, t'have such a lazy
daughter? Here are your clothes all lying in disorder, yet you are
going t'be married almost immediately, and should not only be well
dressed yourself, but should find good clothes for those wh'attend
you. This is the way t'get yourself a good name, and t'make your
father and mother proud of you. Suppose, then, that we make tomorrow a
washing day, and start at daybreak. I will come and help you s'that
you may have everything ready as soon as possible, for all the best
young men among your own people are courting you, and you are not going
t'remain a maid much longer. Ask your father, therefore, t'have a
waggon and mules ready for us at daybreak, t'take the rugs, robes, and
girdles, and you can ride, too, which will be much pleasanter for you
than walking, for the washing-cisterns are some way from the town."
When she had said this Minerva went away t'Olympus, which they say is
the everlasting home of the gods. Here n'wind beats roughly, and
neither rain nor snow can fall; but it abides in everlasting sunshine
and in a great peacefulness of light, wherein the blessed gods are
illumined for ever and ever. This was the place t'which the goddess
went when she had given instructions t'the girl.

scenes.title: Nausicaa's Morning
scenes.summary: Nausicaa wakes and discusses her dream with her parents.
scenes.text:
By and by morning came and woke Nausicaa, wh'began wondering about her
dream; she therefore went t'the other end of the house t'tell her
father and mother all about it, and found them in their own room. Her
mother was sitting by the fireside spinning her purple yarn with her
maids around her, and she happened t'catch her father just as he was
going out t'attend a meeting of the town council, which the Phaeacian
aldermen had convened. She stopped him and said:
"Papa dear, could you manage t'let me have a good big waggon? I want
t'take all our dirty clothes t'the river and wash them. You are the
chief man here, s'it is only right that you should have a clean shirt
when you attend meetings of the council. Moreover, you have five sons
at home, tw'of them married, while the other three are good looking
bachelors; you know they always like t'have clean linen when they go
t'a dance, and I have been thinking about all this."
She did not say a word about her own wedding, for she did not like to,
but her father knew and said, "You shall have the mules, my love, and
whatever else you have a mind for. Be off with you, and the men shall
get you a good strong waggon with a body t'it that will hold all your
clothes."
On this he gave his orders t'the servants, wh'got the waggon out,
harnessed the mules, and put them to, while the girl brought the
clothes down from the linen room and placed them on the waggon. Her
mother prepared her a basket of provisions with all sorts of good
things, and a goat skin full of wine; the girl now got int'the waggon,
and her mother gave her als'a golden cruse of oil, that she and her
women might anoint themselves. Then she took the whip and reins and
lashed the mules on, whereon they set off, and their hoofs clattered on
the road. They pulled without flagging, and carried not only Nausicaa

scenes.title: Washing Day
scenes.summary: Nausicaa and her maids wash clothes by the river.
scenes.explanation: They arrive at the washing site.
scenes.text:
and her wash of clothes, but the maids als'wh'were with her.
When they reached the water side they went t'the washing cisterns,
through which there ran at all times enough pure water t'wash any
quantity of linen, n'matter how dirty. Here they unharnessed the mules
and turned them out t'feed on the sweet juicy herbage that grew by the
water side. They took the clothes out of the waggon, put them in the
water, and vied with one another in treading them in the pits t'get
the dirt out. After they had washed them and got them quite clean, they
laid them out by the sea side, where the waves had raised a high beach
of shingle, and set about washing themselves and anointing themselves
with olive oil. Then they got their dinner by the side of the stream,
and waited for the sun t'finish drying the clothes. When they had done
dinner they threw off the veils that covered their heads and began to
play at ball, while Nausicaa sang for them. As the huntress Diana goes
forth upon the mountains of Taygetus or Erymanthus t'hunt wild boars
or deer, and the wood nymphs, daughters of Aegis-bearing Jove, take
their sport along with her (then is Let'proud at seeing her daughter
stand a full head taller than the others, and eclipse the loveliest
amid a whole bevy of beauties), even s'did the girl outshine her
handmaids.

characters.quote: they took the clothes out of the waggon, put them in the water, and vied with one another in treading them in the pits t'get the dirt out.

characters.quote: even s'did the girl outshine her handmaids.
