characters.importance_exp: The Cyclopes' way of life contrasts with civilized societies.
characters.quote: Now the Cyclopes neither plant nor plough, but trust in providence, and live on such wheat, barley, and grapes as grow wild without any kind of tillage.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The arrival at the island is attributed to a god's influence.
characters.quote: s'dark was the night that some god must have brought us in, for there was nothing whatever t'be seen.

scenes.title: The Cyclops' Cave
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men explore the Cyclops' cave.
scenes.explanation: Change of location to the Cyclops' cave.
scenes.text:
till daybreak.
"When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn appeared, we admired the
island and wandered all over it, while the nymphs Jove's daughters
roused the wild goats that we might get some meat for our dinner. On
this we fetched our spears and bows and arrows from the ships, and
dividing ourselves int'three bands began t'shoot the goats. Heaven
sent us excellent sport; I had twelve ships with me, and each ship got
nine goats, while my own ship had ten; thus through the livelong day to
the going down of the sun we ate and drank our fill, and we had plenty
of wine left, for each one of us had taken many jars full when we
sacked the city of the Cicons, and this had not yet run out. While we
were feasting we kept turning our eyes towards the land of the
Cyclopes, which was hard by, and saw the smoke of their stubble fires.
We could almost fancy we heard their voices and the bleating of their
sheep and goats, but when the sun went down and it came on dark, we
camped down upon the beach, and next morning I called a council.
"'Stay here, my brave fellows,' said I, 'all the rest of you, while I
g'with my ship and exploit these people myself: I want t'see if they
are uncivilised savages, or a hospitable and humane race.'
"I went on board, bidding my men t'd's'als'and loose the hawsers;
s'they took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars. When
we got t'the land, which was not far, there, on the face of a cliff
near the sea, we saw a great cave overhung with laurels. It was a
station for a great many sheep and goats, and outside there was a large
yard, with a high wall round it made of stones built int'the ground
and of trees both pine and oak. This was the abode of a huge monster
wh'was then away from home shepherding his flocks. He would have
nothing t'd'with other people, but led the life of an outlaw. He was
a horrid creature, not like a human being at all, but resembling rather
some crag that stands out boldly against the sky on the top of a high

characters.name: Exploration
characters.importance_exp: Exploration is central to the characters' actions in this scene.
characters.quote: I want t'see if they are uncivilised savages, or a hospitable and humane race.

characters.name: Celebration And Joy
characters.importance_exp: Feasting highlights the characters' camaraderie and survival.
characters.quote: thus through the livelong day to the going down of the sun we ate and drank our fill, and we had plenty of wine left

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: Isolation is emphasized by the description of the Cyclopes' lifestyle.
characters.quote: He would have nothing t'd'with other people, but led the life of an outlaw.

scenes.title: The Cyclops' Return
scenes.summary: The Cyclops returns home and captures Ulysses' men.
scenes.explanation: Change of location as the Cyclops returns.
scenes.text:
mountain.
"I told my men t'draw the ship ashore, and stay where they were, all
but the twelve best among them, wh'were t'g'along with myself. I
als'took a goatskin of sweet black wine which had been given me by
Maron, son of Euanthes, wh'was priest of Apoll'the patron god of
Ismarus, and lived within the wooded precincts of the temple. When we
were sacking the city we respected him, and spared his life, as also
his wife and child; s'he made me some presents of great value—seven
talents of fine gold, and a bowl of silver, with twelve jars of sweet
wine, unblended, and of the most exquisite flavour. Not a man nor maid
in the house knew about it, but only himself, his wife, and one
housekeeper: when he drank it he mixed twenty parts of water t'one of
wine, and yet the fragrance from the mixing-bowl was s'exquisite that
it was impossible t'refrain from drinking. I filled a large skin with
this wine, and took a wallet full of provisions with me, for my mind
misgave me that I might have t'deal with some savage wh'would be of
great strength, and would respect neither right nor law.
"We soon reached his cave, but he was out shepherding, s'we went
inside and took stock of all that we could see. His cheese-racks were
loaded with cheeses, and he had more lambs and kids than his pens could
hold. They were kept in separate flocks; first there were the hoggets,
then the oldest of the younger lambs and lastly the very young ones80
all kept apart from one another; as for his dairy, all the vessels,
bowls, and milk pails int'which he milked, were swimming with whey.
When they saw all this, my men begged me t'let them first steal some
cheeses, and make off with them t'the ship; they would then return,
drive down the lambs and kids, put them on board and sail away with
them. It would have been indeed better if we had done s'but I would
not listen t'them, for I wanted t'see the owner himself, in the hope
that he might give me a present. When, however, we saw him my poor men
found him ill t'deal with.
"We lit a fire, offered some of the cheeses in sacrifice, ate others of
them, and then sat waiting till the Cyclops should come in with his
sheep. When he came, he brought in with him a huge load of dry firewood
t'light the fire for his supper, and this he flung with such a noise
on t'the floor of his cave that we hid ourselves for fear at the far
end of the cavern. Meanwhile he drove all the ewes inside, as well as
the she-goats that he was going t'milk, leaving the males, both rams
and he-goats, outside in the yards. Then he rolled a huge stone t'the
mouth of the cave—s'huge that tw'and twenty strong four-wheeled
waggons would not be enough t'draw it from its place against the
doorway. When he had s'done he sat down and milked his ewes and goats,
all in due course, and then let each of them have her own young. He
curdled half the milk and set it aside in wicker strainers, but the
other half he poured int'bowls that he might drink it for his supper.
When he had got through with all his work, he lit the fire, and then
caught sight of us, whereon he said:
"'Strangers, wh'are you? Where d'sail from? Are you traders, or do
you sail the sea as rovers, with your hands against every man, and
every man's hand against you?'
"We were frightened out of our senses by his loud voice and monstrous
form, but I managed t'say, 'We are Achaeans on our way home from Troy,
but by the will of Jove, and stress of weather, we have been driven far
out of our course. We are the people of Agamemnon, son of Atreus, who
has won infinite renown throughout the whole world, by sacking s'great
a city and killing s'many people. We therefore humbly pray you t'show
us some hospitality, and otherwise make us such presents as visitors
may reasonably expect. May your excellency fear the wrath of heaven,
for we are your suppliants, and Jove takes all respectable travellers
under his protection, for he is the avenger of all suppliants and
foreigners in distress.'
"T'this he gave me but a pitiless answer, 'Stranger,' said he, 'you
are a fool, or else you know nothing of this country. Talk t'me,
indeed, about fearing the gods or shunning their anger? We Cyclopes do
not care about Jove or any of your blessed gods, for we are ever so
much stronger than they. I shall not spare either yourself or your
companions out of any regard for Jove, unless I am in the humour for
doing so. And now tell me where you made your ship fast when you came
on shore. Was it round the point, or is she lying straight off the
land?'
"He said this t'draw me out, but I was to'cunning t'be caught in
that way, s'I answered with a lie; 'Neptune,' said I, 'sent my ship on
t'the rocks at the far end of your country, and wrecked it. We were
driven on t'them from the open sea, but I and those wh'are with me
escaped the jaws of death.'
"The cruel wretch vouchsafed me not one word of answer, but with a
sudden clutch he gripped up tw'of my men at once and dashed them down
upon the ground as though they had been puppies. Their brains were shed
upon the ground, and the earth was wet with their blood. Then he tore
them limb from limb and supped upon them. He gobbled them up like a
lion in the wilderness, flesh, bones, marrow, and entrails, without
leaving anything uneaten. As for us, we wept and lifted up our hands to
heaven on seeing such a horrid sight, for we did not know what else to
do; but when the Cyclops had filled his huge paunch, and had washed
down his meal of human flesh with a drink of neat milk, he stretched
himself full length upon the ground among his sheep, and went t'sleep.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Central to the interaction between Odysseus and the Cyclops.
characters.quote: We therefore humbly pray you t'show us some hospitality, and otherwise make us such presents as visitors may reasonably expect.

characters.name: War And Conflict
characters.importance_exp: The Cyclops' brutal actions are pivotal to the scene.
characters.quote: he gripped up tw'of my men at once and dashed them down upon the ground as though they had been puppies.

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: Odysseus uses deception to protect himself and his men.
characters.quote: I answered with a lie; 'Neptune,' said I, 'sent my ship on t'the rocks at the far end of your country.'

scenes.title: The Blinding of the Cyclops
scenes.summary: Ulysses blinds the Cyclops and escapes.
scenes.explanation: Change of location as Ulysses enacts his plan.
scenes.text:
I was at first inclined t'seize my sword, draw it, and drive it into
his vitals, but I reflected that if I did we should all certainly be
lost, for we should never be able t'shift the stone which the monster
had put in front of the door. S'we stayed sobbing and sighing where we
were till morning came.
"When the child of morning, rosy-fingered dawn, appeared, he again lit
his fire, milked his goats and ewes, all quite rightly, and then let
each have her own young one; as soon as he had got through with all his
work, he clutched up tw'more of my men, and began eating them for his
morning's meal. Presently, with the utmost ease, he rolled the stone
away from the door and drove out his sheep, but he at once put it back
again—as easily as though he were merely clapping the lid on t'a
quiver full of arrows. As soon as he had done s'he shouted, and cried
'Shoo, shoo,' after his sheep t'drive them on t'the mountain; s'I
was left t'scheme some way of taking my revenge and covering myself
with glory.
"In the end I deemed it would be the best plan t'd'as follows: The
Cyclops had a great club which was lying near one of the sheep pens; it
was of green olive wood, and he had cut it intending t'use it for a
staff as soon as it should be dry. It was s'huge that we could only
compare it t'the mast of a twenty-oared merchant vessel of large
burden, and able t'venture out int'open sea. I went up t'this club
and cut off about six feet of it; I then gave this piece t'the men and
told them t'fine it evenly off at one end, which they proceeded t'do,
and lastly I brought it t'a point myself, charring the end in the fire
t'make it harder. When I had done this I hid it under dung, which was
lying about all over the cave, and told the men t'cast lots which of
them should venture along with myself t'lift it and bore it int'the
monster's eye while he was asleep. The lot fell upon the very four whom
I should have chosen, and I myself made five. In the evening the wretch
came back from shepherding, and drove his flocks int'the cave—this
time driving them all inside, and not leaving any in the yards; I
suppose some fancy must have taken him, or a god must have prompted him
t'd'so. As soon as he had put the stone back t'its place against the
door, he sat down, milked his ewes and his goats all quite rightly, and
then let each have her own young one; when he had got through with all
this work, he gripped up tw'more of my men, and made his supper off
them. S'I went up t'him with an ivy-wood bowl of black wine in my
hands:
"'Look here, Cyclops,' said I, you have been eating a great deal of
man's flesh, s'take this and drink some wine, that you may see what
kind of liquor we had on board my ship. I was bringing it t'you as a
drink-offering, in the hope that you would take compassion upon me and
further me on my way home, whereas all you d'is t'g'on ramping and
raving most intolerably. You ought t'be ashamed of yourself; how can
you expect people t'come see you any more if you treat them in this
way?'
"He then took the cup and drank. He was s'delighted with the taste of
the wine that he begged me for another bowl full. 'Be s'kind,' he
said, 'as t'give me some more, and tell me your name at once. I want
t'make you a present that you will be glad t'have. We have wine even
in this country, for our soil grows grapes and the sun ripens them, but
this drinks like Nectar and Ambrosia all in one.'
"I then gave him some more; three times did I fill the bowl for him,
and three times did he drain it without thought or heed; then, when I
saw that the wine had got int'his head, I said t'him as plausibly as
I could: 'Cyclops, you ask my name and I will tell it you; give me,
therefore, the present you promised me; my name is Noman; this is what
my father and mother and my friends have always called me.'
"But the cruel wretch said, 'Then I will eat all Noman's comrades
before Noman himself, and will keep Noman for the last. This is the
present that I will make him.'
"As he spoke he reeled, and fell sprawling face upwards on the ground.
His great neck hung heavily backwards and a deep sleep took hold upon
him. Presently he turned sick, and threw up both wine and the gobbets
of human flesh on which he had been gorging, for he was very drunk.
Then I thrust the beam of wood far int'the embers t'heat it, and
encouraged my men lest any of them should turn faint-hearted. When the
wood, green though it was, was about t'blaze, I drew it out of the
fire glowing with heat, and my men gathered round me, for heaven had
filled their hearts with courage. We drove the sharp end of the beam
int'the monster's eye, and bearing upon it with all my weight I kept
turning it round and round as though I were boring a hole in a ship's
plank with an auger, which tw'men with a wheel and strap can keep on
turning as long as they choose. Even thus did we bore the red hot beam
int'his eye, till the boiling blood bubbled all over it as we worked
it round and round, s'that the steam from the burning eyeball scalded
his eyelids and eyebrows, and the roots of the eye sputtered in the
fire. As a blacksmith plunges an axe or hatchet int'cold water to
temper it—for it is this that gives strength t'the iron—and it makes a
great hiss as he does so, even thus did the Cyclops' eye hiss round the
beam of olive wood, and his hideous yells made the cave ring again. We
ran away in a fright, but he plucked the beam all besmirched with gore
from his eye, and hurled it from him in a frenzy of rage and pain,
shouting as he did s't'the other Cyclopes wh'lived on the bleak
headlands near him; s'they gathered from all quarters round his cave
when they heard him crying, and asked what was the matter with him.
"'What ails you, Polyphemus,' said they, 'that you make such a noise,
breaking the stillness of the night, and preventing us from being able
t'sleep? Surely n'man is carrying off your sheep? Surely n'man is
trying t'kill you either by fraud or by force?'
"But Polyphemus shouted t'them from inside the cave, 'Noman is killing
me by fraud; n'man is killing me by force.'
"'Then,' said they, 'if n'man is attacking you, you must be ill; when
Jove makes people ill, there is n'help for it, and you had better pray
t'your father Neptune.'
"Then they went away, and I laughed inwardly at the success of my
clever stratagem, but the Cyclops, groaning and in an agony of pain,
felt about with his hands till he found the stone and took it from the
door; then he sat in the doorway and stretched his hands in front of it
t'catch anyone going out with the sheep, for he thought I might be
foolish enough t'attempt this.
"As for myself I kept on puzzling t'think how I could best save my own
life and those of my companions; I schemed and schemed, as one who
knows that his life depends upon it, for the danger was very great. In
the end I deemed that this plan would be the best; the male sheep were
well grown, and carried a heavy black fleece, s'I bound them
noiselessly in threes together, with some of the withies on which the
wicked monster used t'sleep. There was t'be a man under the middle
sheep, and the tw'on either side were t'cover him, s'that there were
three sheep t'each man. As for myself there was a ram finer than any
of the others, s'I caught hold of him by the back, esconced myself in
the thick wool under his belly, and hung on patiently t'his fleece,
face upwards, keeping a firm hold on it all the time.
"Thus, then, did we wait in great fear of mind till morning came, but
when the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, the male sheep
hurried out t'feed, while the ewes remained bleating about the pens
waiting t'be milked, for their udders were full t'bursting; but their
master in spite of all his pain felt the backs of all the sheep as they
stood upright, without being sharp enough t'find out that the men were
underneath their bellies. As the ram was going out, last of all, heavy
with its fleece and with the weight of my crafty self, Polyphemus laid
hold of it and said:
"'My good ram, what is it that makes you the last t'leave my cave this
morning? You are not wont t'let the ewes g'before you, but lead the
mob with a run whether t'flowery mead or bubbling fountain, and are
the first t'come home again at night; but now you lag last of all. Is
it because you know your master has lost his eye, and are sorry because
that wicked Noman and his horrid crew has got him down in his drink and
blinded him? But I will have his life yet. If you could understand and
talk, you would tell me where the wretch is hiding, and I would dash
his brains upon the ground till they flew all over the cave. I should
thus have some satisfaction for the harm this no-good Noman has done
me.'
"As he spoke he drove the ram outside, but when we were a little way
out from the cave and yards, I first got from under the ram's belly,
and then freed my comrades; as for the sheep, which were very fat, by
constantly heading them in the right direction we managed t'drive them
down t'the ship. The crew rejoiced greatly at seeing those of us who
had escaped death, but wept for the others whom the Cyclops had killed.
However, I made signs t'them by nodding and frowning that they were to
hush their crying, and told them t'get all the sheep on board at once
and put out t'sea; s'they went aboard, took their places, and smote
the grey sea with their oars. Then, when I had got as far out as my
voice would reach, I began t'jeer at the Cyclops.
"'Cyclops,' said I, 'you should have taken better measure of your man
before eating up his comrades in your cave. You wretch, eat up your
visitors in your own house? You might have known that your sin would
find you out, and now Jove and the other gods have punished you.'
"He got more and more furious as he heard me, s'he tore the top from
off a high mountain, and flung it just in front of my ship s'that it
was within a little of hitting the end of the rudder.81 The sea quaked
as the rock fell int'it, and the wash of the wave it raised carried us
back towards the mainland, and forced us towards the shore. But I
snatched up a long pole and kept the ship off, making signs t'my men
by nodding my head, that they must row for their lives, whereon they
laid out with a will. When we had got twice as far as we were before, I
was for jeering at the Cyclops again, but the men begged and prayed of
me t'hold my tongue.
"'D'not,' they exclaimed, 'be mad enough t'provoke this savage
creature further; he has thrown one rock at us already which drove us
back again t'the mainland, and we made sure it had been the death of
us; if he had then heard any further sound of voices he would have
pounded our heads and our ship's timbers int'a jelly with the rugged
rocks he would have heaved at us, for he can throw them a long way.'
"But I would not listen t'them, and shouted out t'him in my rage,
'Cyclops, if any one asks you wh'it was that put your eye out and
spoiled your beauty, say it was the valiant warrior Ulysses, son of
Laertes, wh'lives in Ithaca.'

characters.quote: But the cruel wretch said, 'Then I will eat all Noman's comrades before Noman himself...

scenes.title: The Escape and Jeering
scenes.summary: Ulysses taunts the Cyclops as they escape.
scenes.explanation: Change of location as they leave the Cyclops' island.
scenes.text:
"On this he groaned, and cried out, 'Alas, alas, then the old prophecy
about me is coming true. There was a prophet here, at one time, a man
both brave and of great stature, Telemus son of Eurymus, wh'was an
excellent seer, and did all the prophesying for the Cyclopes till he
grew old; he told me that all this would happen t'me some day, and
said I should lose my sight by the hand of Ulysses. I have been all
along expecting some one of imposing presence and superhuman strength,
whereas he turns out t'be a little insignificant weakling, wh'has
managed t'blind my eye by taking advantage of me in my drink; come
here, then, Ulysses, that I may make you presents t'show my
hospitality, and urge Neptune t'help you forward on your journey—for
Neptune and I are father and son. He, if he s'will, shall heal me,
which n'one else neither god nor man can do.'
"Then I said, 'I wish I could be as sure of killing you outright and
sending you down t'the house of Hades, as I am that it will take more
than Neptune t'cure that eye of yours.'
"On this he lifted up his hands t'the firmament of heaven and prayed,
saying, 'Hear me, great Neptune; if I am indeed your own true begotten
son, grant that Ulysses may never reach his home alive; or if he must
get back t'his friends at last, let him d's'late and in sore plight
after losing all his men [let him reach his home in another man's ship
and find trouble in his house.'82
"Thus did he pray, and Neptune heard his prayer. Then he picked up a
rock much larger than the first, swung it aloft and hurled it with
prodigious force. It fell just short of the ship, but was within a
little of hitting the end of the rudder. The sea quaked as the rock
fell int'it, and the wash of the wave it raised drove us onwards on
our way towards the shore of the island.
"When at last we got t'the island where we had left the rest of our
ships, we found our comrades lamenting us, and anxiously awaiting our
return. We ran our vessel upon the sands and got out of her on t'the
sea shore; we als'landed the Cyclops' sheep, and divided them
equitably amongst us s'that none might have reason t'complain. As for
the ram, my companions agreed that I should have it as an extra share;
s'I sacrificed it on the sea shore, and burned its thigh bones to
Jove, wh'is the lord of all. But he heeded not my sacrifice, and only
thought how he might destroy both my ships and my comrades.
"Thus through the livelong day t'the going down of the sun we feasted
our fill on meat and drink, but when the sun went down and it came on
dark, we camped upon the beach. When the child of morning rosy-fingered
Dawn appeared, I bade my men on board and loose the hawsers. Then they
took their places and smote the grey sea with their oars; s'we sailed
on with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have escaped death though we
had lost our comrades.

characters.name: Prophecy Fulfillment
characters.importance_exp: The prophecy is central to the Cyclops' actions and emotions.
characters.quote: 'Alas, alas, then the old prophecy about me is coming true.'

characters.name: Divine Retribution
characters.importance_exp: Neptune's response to the Cyclops' prayer is crucial to the plot.
characters.quote: 'Hear me, great Neptune; if I am indeed your own true begotten son, grant that Ulysses may never reach his home alive.'

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.importance_exp: The loss of comrades weighs heavily on the survivors.
characters.quote: 's'we sailed on with sorrow in our hearts, but glad t'have escaped death though we had lost our comrades.'

scenes.title: Arrival at Aeolian Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men arrive at Aeolus's island.
scenes.text:
AEOLUS, THE LAESTRYGONES, CIRCE.
"Thence we went on t'the Aeolian island where lives Aeolus son of
Hippotas, dear t'the immortal gods. It is an island that floats (as it
were) upon the sea,83 iron bound with a wall that girds it. Now, Aeolus
has six daughters and six lusty sons, s'he made the sons marry the
daughters, and they all live with their dear father and mother,
feasting and enjoying every conceivable kind of luxury. All day long
the atmosphere of the house is loaded with the savour of roasting meats
till it groans again, yard and all; but by night they sleep on their
well made bedsteads, each with his own wife between the blankets. These
were the people among whom we had now come.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The presence of Aeolus indicates divine favor for the characters.
characters.quote: Aeolus son of Hippotas, dear t'the immortal gods.

characters.name: Abundance
characters.importance_exp: The description of the lifestyle highlights themes of luxury and abundance.
characters.quote: feasting and enjoying every conceivable kind of luxury.

characters.name: Family And Kinship
characters.importance_exp: The familial relationships among Aeolus's children emphasize the theme of family.
characters.quote: Aeolus has six daughters and six lusty sons, s'he made the sons marry the daughters.

scenes.title: Aeolus's Hospitality
scenes.summary: Aeolus entertains Ulysses and learns about Troy.
scenes.text:
"Aeolus entertained me for a whole month asking me questions all the
time about Troy, the Argive fleet, and the return of the Achaeans. I
told him exactly how everything had happened, and when I said I must
go, and asked him t'further me on my way, he made n'sort of
difficulty, but set about doing s'at once. Moreover, he flayed me a
prime ox-hide t'hold the ways of the roaring winds, which he shut up
in the hide as in a sack—for Jove had made him captain over the winds,
and he could stir or still each one of them according t'his own
pleasure. He put the sack in the ship and bound the mouth s'tightly
with a silver thread that not even a breath of a side-wind could blow
from any quarter. The West wind which was fair for us did he alone let
blow as it chose; but it all came t'nothing, for we were lost through
our own folly.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The theme is crucial as it highlights Aeolus's role in aiding Odysseus.
characters.quote: he flayed me a prime ox-hide t'hold the ways of the roaring winds, which he shut up in the hide as in a sack—for Jove had made him captain over the winds, and he could stir or still each one of them according t'his own pleasure.

characters.name: Human Folly
characters.importance_exp: This theme is significant as it reflects the consequences of Odysseus's crew's actions.
characters.quote: but it all came t'nothing, for we were lost through our own folly.

scenes.title: Departure from Aeolus
scenes.summary: Aeolus gifts Ulysses a bag of winds.
scenes.text:
"Nine days and nine nights did we sail, and on the tenth day our native
land showed on the horizon. We got s'close in that we could see the
stubble fires burning, and I, being then dead beat, fell int'a light
sleep, for I had never let the rudder out of my own hands, that we
might get home the faster. On this the men fell t'talking among
themselves, and said I was bringing back gold and silver in the sack
that Aeolus had given me. 'Bless my heart,' would one turn t'his
neighbour, saying, 'how this man gets honoured and makes friends to
whatever city or country he may go. See what fine prizes he is taking
home from Troy, while we, wh'have travelled just as far as he has,
come back with hands as empty as we set out with—and now Aeolus has
given him ever s'much more. Quick—let us see what it all is, and how
much gold and silver there is in the sack he gave him.'
"Thus they talked and evil counsels prevailed. They loosed the sack,
whereupon the wind flew howling forth and raised a storm that carried
us weeping out t'sea and away from our own country. Then I awoke, and
knew not whether t'throw myself int'the sea or t'live on and make
the best of it; but I bore it, covered myself up, and lay down in the
ship, while the men lamented bitterly as the fierce winds bore our
fleet back t'the Aeolian island.

characters.name: Human Folly
characters.importance_exp: This theme drives the actions of the crew, leading to their downfall.
characters.quote: 'Quick—let us see what it all is, and how much gold and silver there is in the sack he gave him.'

characters.name: Folly And Consequences
characters.importance_exp: The crew's decision to open the sack leads to dire consequences.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The crew's greed results in a storm that drives them away from home.

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: The protagonist feels isolated and despondent after the storm.
characters.quote: I awoke, and knew not whether t'throw myself int'the sea or t'live on and make the best of it; but I bore it, covered myself up, and lay down in the ship.

scenes.title: Arrival at Telepylus
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his men reach the land of the Laestrygonians.
scenes.text:
"Thence we sailed sadly on till the men were worn out with long and
fruitless rowing, for there was n'longer any wind t'help them. Six
days, night and day did we toil, and on the seventh day we reached the
rocky stronghold of Lamus—Telepylus, the city of the Laestrygonians,
where the shepherd wh'is driving in his sheep and goats [t'be milked]
salutes him wh'is driving out his flock [t'feed] and this last
answers the salute. In that country a man wh'could d'without sleep
might earn double wages, one as a herdsman of cattle, and another as a
shepherd, for they work much the same by night as they d'by day.84
"When we reached the harbour we found it land-locked under steep
cliffs, with a narrow entrance between tw'headlands. My captains took
all their ships inside, and made them fast close t'one another, for
there was never s'much as a breath of wind inside, but it was always
dead calm. I kept my own ship outside, and moored it t'a rock at the
very end of the point; then I climbed a high rock t'reconnoitre, but
could see n'sign neither of man nor cattle, only some smoke rising
from the ground. S'I sent tw'of my company with an attendant t'find
out what sort of people the inhabitants were.

characters.name: Desperation
characters.importance_exp: The crew's exhaustion from rowing reflects their desperation.
characters.quote: Six days, night and day did we toil, and on the seventh day we reached the rocky stronghold of Lamus—Telepylus.

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: The calm harbor and lack of wind symbolize isolation.
characters.quote: there was never s'much as a breath of wind inside, but it was always dead calm.

characters.name: Exploration
characters.importance_exp: The need to explore the unknown reflects curiosity.
characters.quote: I kept my own ship outside, and moored it t'a rock at the very end of the point; then I climbed a high rock t'reconnoitre, but could see n'sign neither of man nor cattle.

scenes.title: Attack of the Laestrygonians
scenes.summary: The Laestrygonians attack Ulysses's fleet.
scenes.text:
"The men when they got on shore followed a level road by which the
people draw their firewood from the mountains int'the town, till
presently they met a young woman wh'had come outside t'fetch water,
and wh'was daughter t'a Laestrygonian named Antiphates. She was going
t'the fountain Artacia from which the people bring in their water, and
when my men had come close up t'her, they asked her wh'the king of
that country might be, and over what kind of people he ruled; s'she
directed them t'her father's house, but when they got there they found
his wife t'be a giantess as huge as a mountain, and they were
horrified at the sight of her.
"She at once called her husband Antiphates from the place of assembly,
and forthwith he set about killing my men. He snatched up one of them,
and began t'make his dinner off him then and there, whereon the other
tw'ran back t'the ships as fast as ever they could. But Antiphates
raised a hue-and-cry after them, and thousands of sturdy Laestrygonians
sprang up from every quarter—ogres, not men. They threw vast rocks at
us from the cliffs as though they had been mere stones, and I heard the
horrid sound of the ships crunching up against one another, and the
death cries of my men, as the Laestrygonians speared them like fishes
and took them home t'eat them. While they were thus killing my men
within the harbour I drew my sword, cut the cable of my own ship, and
told my men t'row with all their might if they to'would not fare like
the rest; s'they laid out for their lives, and we were thankful enough
when we got int'open water out of reach of the rocks they hurled at
us. As for the others there was not one of them left.

characters.name: Survival Instinct
characters.importance_exp: Survival is the primary focus of the characters in this scene.
characters.quote: s'they laid out for their lives, and we were thankful enough when we got int'open water out of reach of the rocks they hurled at us.

characters.name: Fear And Horror
characters.importance_exp: The scene evokes strong feelings of fear and horror due to the giantess and the Laestrygonians.
characters.quote: they were horrified at the sight of her.

characters.name: War And Conflict
characters.importance_exp: The theme of violence is central as characters face brutal attacks and death.
characters.quote: the death cries of my men, as the Laestrygonians speared them like fishes and took them home t'eat them.

scenes.title: Arrival at Circe's Island
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives at Circe's island after escaping.
scenes.explanation: Change of location to Circe's island.
scenes.text:
lost our comrades, and came t'the Aeaean island, where Circe lives—a
great and cunning goddess wh'is own sister t'the magician Aeetes—for
they are both children of the sun by Perse, wh'is daughter t'Oceanus.
We brought our ship int'a safe harbour without a word, for some god
guided us thither, and having landed we lay there for tw'days and two
nights, worn out in body and mind. When the morning of the third day

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.importance_exp: The theme of loss is central to the characters' emotional state after their journey.
characters.quote: lost our comrades, and came t'the Aeaean island, where Circe lives—

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The presence of divine intervention is significant in their journey.
characters.quote: some god guided us thither, and having landed we lay there for tw'days and two nights, worn out in body and mind.

scenes.title: Council of the Men
scenes.summary: Ulysses calls a council to discuss their situation.
scenes.text:
came on dark, we camped upon the sea shore. When the child of morning,
rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, I called a council and said, 'My friends,
we are in very great difficulties; listen therefore t'me. We have no
idea where the sun either sets or rises,85 s'that we d'not even know
East from West. I see n'way out of it; nevertheless, we must try and
find one. We are certainly on an island, for I went as high as I could
this morning, and saw the sea reaching all round it t'the horizon; it
lies low, but towards the middle I saw smoke rising from out of a thick
forest of trees.'
"Their hearts sank as they heard me, for they remembered how they had
been treated by the Laestrygonian Antiphates, and by the savage ogre
Polyphemus. They wept bitterly in their dismay, but there was nothing
t'be got by crying, s'I divided them int'tw'companies and set a
captain over each; I gave one company t'Eurylochus, while I took
command of the other myself. Then we cast lots in a helmet, and the lot
fell upon Eurylochus; s'he set out with his twenty-tw'men, and they
wept, as als'did we wh'were left behind.

characters.name: Hope And Despair
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' emotional state in the scene.
characters.quote: Their hearts sank as they heard me, for they remembered how they had been treated by the Laestrygonian Antiphates, and by the savage ogre Polyphemus. They wept bitterly in their dismay.

characters.name: Leadership And Decision-making
characters.importance_exp: The protagonist's role as a leader is crucial in this scene.
characters.quote: I divided them int'tw'companies and set a captain over each; I gave one company t'Eurylochus, while I took command of the other myself.

characters.name: Suffering And Isolation
characters.importance_exp: The characters' lack of knowledge about their surroundings creates a sense of isolation.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The confusion and helplessness expressed here illustrate the disorientation and despair that can accompany isolation.

scenes.title: Encounter with Circe
scenes.summary: Ulysses's men meet Circe and are transformed.
scenes.text:
"When they reached Circe's house they found it built of cut stones, on
a site that could be seen from far, in the middle of the forest. There
were wild mountain wolves and lions prowling all round it—poor
bewitched creatures whom she had tamed by her enchantments and drugged
int'subjection. They did not attack my men, but wagged their great
tails, fawned upon them, and rubbed their noses lovingly against
them.86 As hounds crowd round their master when they see him coming
from dinner—for they know he will bring them something—even s'did
these wolves and lions with their great claws fawn upon my men, but the
men were terribly frightened at seeing such strange creatures.
Presently they reached the gates of the goddess's house, and as they
stood there they could hear Circe within, singing most beautifully as
she worked at her loom, making a web s'fine, s'soft, and of such
dazzling colours as n'one but a goddess could weave. On this Polites,
whom I valued and trusted more than any other of my men, said, 'There
is some one inside working at a loom and singing most beautifully; the
whole place resounds with it, let us call her and see whether she is
woman or goddess.'
"They called her and she came down, unfastened the door, and bade them
enter. They, thinking n'evil, followed her, all except Eurylochus, who
suspected mischief and staid outside. When she had got them int'her
house, she set them upon benches and seats and mixed them a mess with
cheese, honey, meal, and Pramnian wine, but she drugged it with wicked
poisons t'make them forget their homes, and when they had drunk she
turned them int'pigs by a stroke of her wand, and shut them up in her
pig-styes. They were like pigs—head, hair, and all, and they grunted
just as pigs do; but their senses were the same as before, and they
remembered everything.

characters.name: Transformation
characters.importance_exp: Transformation is central to the plot as characters are literally changed into pigs.
characters.quote: she turned them int'pigs by a stroke of her wand

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: Deception is a key theme as Circe lures the men with her beauty and hospitality.
characters.quote: she drugged it with wicked poisons t'make them forget their homes

characters.name: Nature Vs. Magic
characters.importance_exp: The contrast between the natural world and Circe's magical influence is significant.
characters.quote: wild mountain wolves and lions prowling all round it

scenes.title: Eurylochus's Warning
scenes.summary: Eurylochus warns Ulysses about Circe's danger.
scenes.explanation: Eurylochus recounts the fate of the men.
scenes.text:
"Thus then were they shut up squealing, and Circe threw them some
acorns and beech masts such as pigs eat, but Eurylochus hurried back to
tell me about the sad fate of our comrades. He was s'overcome with
dismay that though he tried t'speak he could find n'words t'd'so;
his eyes filled with tears and he could only sob and sigh, till at last
we forced his story out of him, and he told us what had happened t'the
others.
"'We went,' said he, 'as you told us, through the forest, and in the
middle of it there was a fine house built with cut stones in a place
that could be seen from far. There we found a woman, or else she was a
goddess, working at her loom and singing sweetly; s'the men shouted to
her and called her, whereon she at once came down, opened the door, and
invited us in. The others did not suspect any mischief s'they followed
her int'the house, but I staid where I was, for I thought there might
be some treachery. From that moment I saw them n'more, for not one of
them ever came out, though I sat a long time watching for them.'
"Then I took my sword of bronze and slung it over my shoulders; I also
took my bow, and told Eurylochus t'come back with me and shew me the
way. But he laid hold of me with both his hands and spoke piteously,
saying, 'Sir, d'not force me t'g'with you, but let me stay here, for
I know you will not bring one of them back with you, nor even return
alive yourself; let us rather see if we cannot escape at any rate with
the few that are left us, for we may still save our lives.'

characters.name: Fear And Horror
characters.importance_exp: This theme is crucial as it drives the characters' actions and decisions.
characters.quote: I thought there might be some treachery.

characters.name: Hope And Despair
characters.importance_exp: The emotional weight of loss is significant in this scene.
characters.quote: his eyes filled with tears and he could only sob and sigh

characters.name: Caution Vs. Recklessness
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the tension between caution and the desire to rescue comrades.
characters.quote: d'not force me t'g'with you, but let me stay here

scenes.title: Ulysses Meets Mercury
scenes.summary: Mercury gives Ulysses advice and a protective herb.
scenes.text:
"'Stay where you are, then,' answered I, 'eating and drinking at the
ship, but I must go, for I am most urgently bound t'd'so.'
"With this I left the ship and went up inland. When I got through the
charmed grove, and was near the great house of the enchantress Circe, I
met Mercury with his golden wand, disguised as a young man in the
hey-day of his youth and beauty with the down just coming upon his
face. He came up t'me and took my hand within his own, saying, 'My
poor unhappy man, whither are you going over this mountain top, alone
and without knowing the way? Your men are shut up in Circe's pigstyes,
like s'many wild boars in their lairs. You surely d'not fancy that
you can set them free? I can tell you that you will never get back and
will have t'stay there with the rest of them. But never mind, I will
protect you and get you out of your difficulty. Take this herb, which
is one of great virtue, and keep it about you when you g't'Circe's
house, it will be a talisman t'you against every kind of mischief.
"'And I will tell you of all the wicked witchcraft that Circe will try
t'practice upon you. She will mix a mess for you t'drink, and she
will drug the meal with which she makes it, but she will not be able to
charm you, for the virtue of the herb that I shall give you will
prevent her spells from working. I will tell you all about it. When
Circe strikes you with her wand, draw your sword and spring upon her as
though you were going t'kill her. She will then be frightened, and
will desire you t'g't'bed with her; on this you must not point blank
refuse her, for you want her t'set your companions free, and t'take
good care als'of yourself, but you must make her swear solemnly by all
the blessed gods that she will plot n'further mischief against you, or
else when she has got you naked she will unman you and make you fit for
nothing.'
"As he spoke he pulled the herb out of the ground and shewed me what it
was like. The root was black, while the flower was as white as milk;
the gods call it Moly, and mortal men cannot uproot it, but the gods
can d'whatever they like.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Mercury's guidance is crucial for the protagonist's survival.
characters.quote: 'I will protect you and get you out of your difficulty.'

characters.name: Nature Vs. Magic
characters.importance_exp: The threat of Circe's magic is central to the conflict.
characters.quote: 'She will mix a mess for you t'drink, and she will drug the meal with which she makes it.'

characters.name: Cunning And Strategy
characters.importance_exp: The protagonist must use clever tactics to navigate the situation.
characters.quote: 'draw your sword and spring upon her as though you were going t'kill her.'

scenes.title: Confrontation with Circe
scenes.summary: Ulysses confronts Circe and demands his men back.
scenes.text:
"Then Mercury went back t'high Olympus passing over the wooded island;
but I fared onward t'the house of Circe, and my heart was clouded with
care as I walked along. When I got t'the gates I stood there and
called the goddess, and as soon as she heard me she came down, opened
the door, and asked me t'come in; s'I followed her—much troubled in
my mind. She set me on a richly decorated seat inlaid with silver,
there was a footstool als'under my feet, and she mixed a mess in a
golden goblet for me t'drink; but she drugged it, for she meant me
mischief. When she had given it me, and I had drunk it without its
charming me, she struck me with her wand. 'There now,' she cried, 'be
off t'the pigstye, and make your lair with the rest of them.'
"But I rushed at her with my sword drawn as though I would kill her,
whereon she fell with a loud scream, clasped my knees, and spoke
piteously, saying, 'Wh'and whence are you? from what place and people
have you come? How can it be that my drugs have n'power t'charm you?
Never yet was any man able t'stand s'much as a taste of the herb I
gave you; you must be spell-proof; surely you can be none other than
the bold her'Ulysses, wh'Mercury always said would come here some day
with his ship while on his way home from Troy; s'be it then; sheathe
your sword and let us g't'bed, that we may make friends and learn to
trust each other.'
"And I answered, 'Circe, how can you expect me t'be friendly with you
when you have just been turning all my men int'pigs? And now that you
have got me here myself, you mean me mischief when you ask me t'g'to
bed with you, and will unman me and make me fit for nothing. I shall
certainly not consent t'g't'bed with you unless you will first take
your solemn oath t'plot n'further harm against me.'
"S'she swore at once as I had told her, and when she had completed her

scenes.title: Restoration of the Men
scenes.summary: Circe restores Ulysses's men to their human forms.
scenes.text:
oath then I went t'bed with her.
"Meanwhile her four servants, wh'are her housemaids, set about their
work. They are the children of the groves and fountains, and of the
holy waters that run down int'the sea. One of them spread a fair
purple cloth over a seat, and laid a carpet underneath it. Another
brought tables of silver up t'the seats, and set them with baskets of
gold. A third mixed some sweet wine with water in a silver bowl and put
golden cups upon the tables, while the fourth brought in water and set
it t'boil in a large cauldron over a good fire which she had lighted.
When the water in the cauldron was boiling,87 she poured cold int'it
till it was just as I liked it, and then she set me in a bath and began
washing me from the cauldron about the head and shoulders, t'take the
tire and stiffness out of my limbs. As soon as she had done washing me
and anointing me with oil, she arrayed me in a good cloak and shirt and
led me t'a richly decorated seat inlaid with silver; there was a
footstool als'under my feet. A maid servant then brought me water in a
beautiful golden ewer and poured it int'a silver basin for me t'wash
my hands, and she drew a clean table beside me; an upper servant
brought me bread and offered me many things of what there was in the
house, and then Circe bade me eat, but I would not, and sat without
heeding what was before me, still moody and suspicious.
"When Circe saw me sitting there without eating, and in great grief,
she came t'me and said, 'Ulysses, why d'you sit like that as though
you were dumb, gnawing at your own heart, and refusing both meat and
drink? Is it that you are still suspicious? You ought not t'be, for I
have already sworn solemnly that I will not hurt you.'
"And I said, 'Circe, n'man with any sense of what is right can think
of either eating or drinking in your house until you have set his
friends free and let him see them. If you want me t'eat and drink, you
must free my men and bring them t'me that I may see them with my own
eyes.'
"When I had said this she went straight through the court with her wand
in her hand and opened the pigstye doors. My men came out like s'many
prime hogs and stood looking at her, but she went about among them and
anointed each with a second drug, whereon the bristles that the bad
drug had given them fell off, and they became men again, younger than
they were before, and much taller and better looking. They knew me at
once, seized me each of them by the hand, and wept for joy till the
whole house was filled with the sound of their halloa-ballooing, and
Circe herself was s'sorry for them that she came up t'me and said,

characters.name: Transformation
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as it depicts the change of Ulysses' men from pigs back to humans.
characters.quote: they became men again, younger than they were before, and much taller and better looking.

characters.name: Trust And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' refusal to eat highlights his distrust of Circe despite her assurances.
characters.quote: I would not, and sat without heeding what was before me, still moody and suspicious.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Circe's efforts to provide comfort and care for Ulysses reflect the theme of hospitality, though it is overshadowed by Ulysses' concerns.
characters.quote: she arrayed me in a good cloak and shirt and led me t'a richly decorated seat inlaid with silver;

scenes.title: Ulysses's Promise to Circe
scenes.summary: Circe promises to help Ulysses return home.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses discusses his journey with Circe.
scenes.text:
'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, g'back at once t'the sea where you
have left your ship, and first draw it on t'the land. Then, hide all
your ship's gear and property in some cave, and come back here with
your men.'
"I agreed t'this, s'I went back t'the sea shore, and found the men
at the ship weeping and wailing most piteously. When they saw me the
silly blubbering fellows began frisking round me as calves break out
and gambol round their mothers, when they see them coming home t'be
milked after they have been feeding all day, and the homestead resounds
with their lowing. They seemed as glad t'see me as though they had got
back t'their own rugged Ithaca, where they had been born and bred.
'Sir,' said the affectionate creatures, 'we are as glad t'see you back
as though we had got safe home t'Ithaca; but tell us all about the
fate of our comrades.'
"I spoke comfortingly t'them and said, 'We must draw our ship on to
the land, and hide the ship's gear with all our property in some cave;
then come with me all of you as fast as you can t'Circe's house, where
you will find your comrades eating and drinking in the midst of great
abundance.'
"On this the men would have come with me at once, but Eurylochus tried
t'hold them back and said, 'Alas, poor wretches that we are, what will
become of us? Rush not on your ruin by going t'the house of Circe, who
will turn us all int'pigs or wolves or lions, and we shall have to
keep guard over her house. Remember how the Cyclops treated us when our
comrades went inside his cave, and Ulysses with them. It was all
through his sheer folly that those men lost their lives.'
"When I heard him I was in tw'minds whether or n't'draw the keen
blade that hung by my sturdy thigh and cut his head off in spite of his
being a near relation of my own; but the men interceded for him and
said, 'Sir, if it may s'be, let this fellow stay here and mind the
ship, but take the rest of us with you t'Circe's house.'
"On this we all went inland, and Eurylochus was not left behind after
all, but came on too, for he was frightened by the severe reprimand
that I had given him.
"Meanwhile Circe had been seeing that the men wh'had been left behind
were washed and anointed with olive oil; she had als'given them
woollen cloaks and shirts, and when we came we found them all
comfortably at dinner in her house. As soon as the men saw each other
face t'face and knew one another, they wept for joy and cried aloud
till the whole palace rang again. Thereon Circe came up t'me and said,
'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, tell your men t'leave off crying; I
know how much you have all of you suffered at sea, and how ill you have
fared among cruel savages on the mainland, but that is over now, so
stay here, and eat and drink till you are once more as strong and
hearty as you were when you left Ithaca; for at present you are
weakened both in body and mind; you keep all the time thinking of the
hardships you have suffered during your travels, s'that you have no
more cheerfulness left in you.'
"Thus did she speak and we assented. We stayed with Circe for a whole
twelvemonth feasting upon an untold quantity both of meat and wine. But
when the year had passed in the waning of moons and the long days had
come round, my men called me apart and said, 'Sir, it is time you began
t'think about going home, if s'be you are t'be spared t'see your
house and native country at all.'
"Thus did they speak and I assented. Thereon through the livelong day
t'the going down of the sun we feasted our fill on meat and wine, but
when the sun went down and it came on dark the men laid themselves down
t'sleep in the covered cloisters. I, however, after I had got int'bed
with Circe, besought her by her knees, and the goddess listened t'what
I had got t'say. 'Circe,' said I, 'please t'keep the promise you made
me about furthering me on my homeward voyage. I want t'get back and so
d'my men, they are always pestering me with their complaints as soon
as ever your back is turned.'
"And the goddess answered, 'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, you shall
none of you stay here any longer if you d'not want to, but there is
another journey which you have got t'take before you can sail
homewards. You must g't'the house of Hades and of dread Proserpine to
consult the ghost of the blind Theban prophet Teiresias, whose reason
is still unshaken. T'him alone has Proserpine left his understanding
even in death, but the other ghosts flit about aimlessly.'

characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' motivations and emotions in the scene.
characters.quote: They seemed as glad t'see me as though they had got back t'their own rugged Ithaca, where they had been born and bred.

characters.quote: Alas, poor wretches that we are, what will become of us? Rush not on your ruin by going t'the house of Circe, who will turn us all int'pigs or wolves or lions.

characters.importance_exp: This theme illustrates the relief and joy the men experience after their hardships.
characters.quote: we found them all comfortably at dinner in her house.

characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' role as a leader is highlighted through his decisions and interactions with his men.
characters.quote: I spoke comfortingly t'them and said, 'We must draw our ship on to the land...

characters.name: Transformation
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the potential for change in the characters' fates and circumstances.
characters.quote: You must g't'the house of Hades and of dread Proserpine to consult the ghost of the blind Theban prophet Teiresias.

scenes.title: Preparing to Leave
scenes.summary: Ulysses prepares to leave Circe's island.
scenes.explanation: Ulysses gathers his men to depart.
scenes.text:
"I was dismayed when I heard this. I sat up in bed and wept, and would
gladly have lived n'longer t'see the light of the sun, but presently
when I was tired of weeping and tossing myself about, I said, 'And who
shall guide me upon this voyage—for the house of Hades is a port that
n'ship can reach.'
"'You will want n'guide,' she answered; 'raise your mast, set your
white sails, sit quite still, and the North Wind will blow you there of
itself. When your ship has traversed the waters of Oceanus, you will
reach the fertile shore of Proserpine's country with its groves of tall
poplars and willows that shed their fruit untimely; here beach your
ship upon the shore of Oceanus, and g'straight on t'the dark abode of
Hades. You will find it near the place where the rivers Pyriphlegethon
and Cocytus (which is a branch of the river Styx) flow int'Acheron,
and you will see a rock near it, just where the tw'roaring rivers run
int'one another.
"'When you have reached this spot, as I now tell you, dig a trench a
cubit or s'in length, breadth, and depth, and pour int'it as a
drink-offering t'all the dead, first, honey mixed with milk, then
wine, and in the third place water—sprinkling white barley meal over
the whole. Moreover you must offer many prayers t'the poor feeble
ghosts, and promise them that when you get back t'Ithaca you will
sacrifice a barren heifer t'them, the best you have, and will load the
pyre with good things. More particularly you must promise that
Teiresias shall have a black sheep all t'himself, the finest in all
your flocks.
"'When you shall have thus besought the ghosts with your prayers, offer
them a ram and a black ewe, bending their heads towards Erebus; but
yourself turn away from them as though you would make towards the
river. On this, many dead men's ghosts will come t'you, and you must
tell your men t'skin the tw'sheep that you have just killed, and
offer them as a burnt sacrifice with prayers t'Hades and to
Proserpine. Then draw your sword and sit there, s'as t'prevent any
other poor ghost from coming near the spilt blood before Teiresias
shall have answered your questions. The seer will presently come to
you, and will tell you about your voyage—what stages you are t'make,
and how you are t'sail the sea s'as t'reach your home.'
"It was day-break by the time she had done speaking, s'she dressed me
in my shirt and cloak. As for herself she threw a beautiful light
gossamer fabric over her shoulders, fastening it with a golden girdle
round her waist, and she covered her head with a mantle. Then I went
about among the men everywhere all over the house, and spoke kindly to
each of them man by man: 'You must not lie sleeping here any longer,'
said I t'them, 'we must be going, for Circe has told me all about it.'
And on this they did as I bade them.
"Even so, however, I did not get them away without misadventure. We had
with us a certain youth named Elpenor, not very remarkable for sense or
courage, wh'had got drunk and was lying on the house-top away from the
rest of the men, t'sleep off his liquor in the cool. When he heard the
noise of the men bustling about, he jumped up on a sudden and forgot
all about coming down by the main staircase, s'he tumbled right off
the roof and broke his neck, and his soul went down t'the house of
Hades.
"When I had got the men together I said t'them, 'You think you are
about t'start home again, but Circe has explained t'me that instead
of this, we have got t'g't'the house of Hades and Proserpine to
consult the ghost of the Theban prophet Teiresias.'
"The men were broken-hearted as they heard me, and threw themselves on
the ground groaning and tearing their hair, but they did not mend
matters by crying. When we reached the sea shore, weeping and lamenting
our fate, Circe brought the ram and the ewe, and we made them fast hard
by the ship. She passed through the midst of us without our knowing it,
for wh'can see the comings and goings of a god, if the god does not

characters.quote: 'You will want n'guide,' she answered; 'raise your mast, set your white sails, sit quite still, and the North Wind will blow you there of itself.'

characters.quote: The men were broken-hearted as they heard me, and threw themselves on the ground groaning and tearing their hair, but they did not mend matters by crying.

scenes.title: The Departure
scenes.summary: Ulysses and his crew set sail.
scenes.text:
THE VISIT T'THE DEAD.88
"Then, when we had got down t'the sea shore we drew our ship int'the
water and got her mast and sails int'her; we als'put the sheep on
board and took our places, weeping and in great distress of mind.
Circe, that great and cunning goddess, sent us a fair wind that blew
dead aft and staid steadily with us keeping our sails all the time well
filled; s'we did whatever wanted doing t'the ship's gear and let her
g'as the wind and helmsman headed her. All day long her sails were
full as she held her course over the sea, but when the sun went down
and darkness was over all the earth, we got int'the deep waters of the
river Oceanus, where lie the land and city of the Cimmerians wh'live
enshrouded in mist and darkness which the rays of the sun never pierce
neither at his rising nor as he goes down again out of the heavens, but
the poor wretches live in one long melancholy night. When we got there
we beached the ship, took the sheep out of her, and went along by the
waters of Oceanus till we came t'the place of which Circe had told us.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.importance_exp: The characters are deeply affected by their emotional state.
characters.quote: weeping and in great distress of mind

characters.name: Darkness And Despair
characters.importance_exp: The setting reflects the emotional state of the characters.
characters.quote: live in one long melancholy night

characters.name: Guidance And Fate
characters.importance_exp: Circe's influence is crucial for their journey.
characters.quote: Circe, that great and cunning goddess, sent us a fair wind

scenes.title: The Ritual
scenes.summary: Ulysses performs a ritual for the dead.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the trench for the ritual.
scenes.text:
"Here Perimedes and Eurylochus held the victims, while I drew my sword
and dug the trench a cubit each way. I made a drink-offering t'all the
dead, first with honey and milk, then with wine, and thirdly with
water, and I sprinkled white barley meal over the whole, praying
earnestly t'the poor feckless ghosts, and promising them that when I
got back t'Ithaca I would sacrifice a barren heifer for them, the best
I had, and would load the pyre with good things. I als'particularly
promised that Teiresias should have a black sheep t'himself, the best
in all my flocks. When I had prayed sufficiently t'the dead, I cut the
throats of the tw'sheep and let the blood run int'the trench, whereon
the ghosts came trooping up from Erebus—brides,89 young bachelors, old
men worn out with toil, maids wh'had been crossed in love, and brave
men wh'had been killed in battle, with their armour still smirched
with blood; they came from every quarter and flitted round the trench
with a strange kind of screaming sound that made me turn pale with
fear. When I saw them coming I told the men t'be quick and flay the
carcasses of the tw'dead sheep and make burnt offerings of them, and
at the same time t'repeat prayers t'Hades and t'Proserpine; but I
sat where I was with my sword drawn and would not let the poor feckless
ghosts come near the blood till Teiresias should have answered my
questions.

characters.name: Divine Worship
characters.importance_exp: Central to the scene's actions and intentions.
characters.quote: I made a drink-offering t'all the dead, first with honey and milk, then with wine, and thirdly with water, and I sprinkled white barley meal over the whole, praying earnestly t'the poor feckless ghosts, and promising them that when I got back t'Ithaca I would sacrifice a barren heifer for them, the best I had, and would load the pyre with good things.

characters.name: Communication With The Dead
characters.importance_exp: Essential for the protagonist's quest and understanding.
characters.quote: When I saw them coming I told the men t'be quick and flay the carcasses of the tw'dead sheep and make burnt offerings of them, and at the same time t'repeat prayers t'Hades and t'Proserpine;

characters.name: Fear And Horror
characters.importance_exp: Significant emotional response to the ghosts' arrival.
characters.quote: they came from every quarter and flitted round the trench with a strange kind of screaming sound that made me turn pale with fear.

scenes.title: Elpenor's Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks with Elpenor's ghost.
scenes.text:
"The first ghost that came was that of my comrade Elpenor, for he had
not yet been laid beneath the earth. We had left his body unwaked and
unburied in Circe's house, for we had had to'much else t'do. I was
very sorry for him, and cried when I saw him: 'Elpenor,' said I, 'how
did you come down here int'this gloom and darkness? You have got here
on foot quicker than I have with my ship.'
"'Sir,' he answered with a groan, 'it was all bad luck, and my own
unspeakable drunkenness. I was lying asleep on the top of Circe's
house, and never thought of coming down again by the great staircase
but fell right off the roof and broke my neck, s'my soul came down to
the house of Hades. And now I beseech you by all those whom you have
left behind you, though they are not here, by your wife, by the father
wh'brought you up when you were a child, and by Telemachus wh'is the
one hope of your house, d'what I shall now ask you. I know that when
you leave this limb'you will again hold your ship for the Aeaean
island. D'not g'thence leaving me unwaked and unburied behind you, or
I may bring heaven's anger upon you; but burn me with whatever armour I
have, build a barrow for me on the sea shore, that may tell people in
days t'come what a poor unlucky fellow I was, and plant over my grave
the oar I used t'row with when I was yet alive and with my messmates.'
And I said, 'My poor fellow, I will d'all that you have asked of me.'

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the emotional weight of the scene.
characters.quote: 'I was very sorry for him, and cried when I saw him:'

characters.name: Burial And Honor
characters.importance_exp: The request for burial signifies respect and the importance of honoring the dead.
characters.quote: 'D'not g'thence leaving me unwaked and unburied behind you,'

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: The bond between Odysseus and Elpenor highlights loyalty even after death.
characters.quote: 'My poor fellow, I will d'all that you have asked of me.'

scenes.title: Anticlea's Ghost
scenes.summary: Ulysses meets his mother, Anticlea.
scenes.text:
"Thus, then, did we sit and hold sad talk with one another, I on the
one side of the trench with my sword held over the blood, and the ghost
of my comrade saying all this t'me from the other side. Then came the
ghost of my dead mother Anticlea, daughter t'Autolycus. I had left her
alive when I set out for Troy and was moved t'tears when I saw her,
but even so, for all my sorrow I would not let her come near the blood
till I had asked my questions of Teiresias.

characters.name: Loss And Grief
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the emotional weight of the scene.
characters.quote: I had left her alive when I set out for Troy and was moved t'tears when I saw her

characters.name: Burial And Honor
characters.importance_exp: The act of not allowing the ghost to approach the blood signifies respect.
characters.quote: for all my sorrow I would not let her come near the blood till I had asked my questions of Teiresias.

scenes.title: Teiresias' Prophecy
scenes.summary: Teiresias provides prophecies to Ulysses.
scenes.text:
"Then came als'the ghost of Theban Teiresias, with his golden sceptre
in his hand. He knew me and said, 'Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, why,
poor man, have you left the light of day and come down t'visit the
dead in this sad place? Stand back from the trench and withdraw your
sword that I may drink of the blood and answer your questions truly.'
"S'I drew back, and sheathed my sword, whereon when he had drank of
the blood he began with his prophecy.
"'You want t'know,' said he, 'about your return home, but heaven will
make this hard for you. I d'not think that you will escape the eye of
Neptune, wh'still nurses his bitter grudge against you for having
blinded his son. Still, after much suffering you may get home if you
can restrain yourself and your companions when your ship reaches the
Thrinacian island, where you will find the sheep and cattle belonging
t'the sun, wh'sees and gives ear t'everything. If you leave these
flocks unharmed and think of nothing but of getting home, you may yet
after much hardship reach Ithaca; but if you harm them, then I forewarn
you of the destruction both of your ship and of your men. Even though
you may yourself escape, you will return in bad plight after losing all
your men, [in another man's ship, and you will find trouble in your
house, which will be overrun by high-handed people, wh'are devouring
your substance under the pretext of paying court and making presents to
your wife.
"'When you get home you will take your revenge on these suitors; and
after you have killed them by force or fraud in your own house, you
must take a well made oar and carry it on and on, till you come t'a
country where the people have never heard of the sea and d'not even
mix salt with their food, nor d'they know anything about ships, and
oars that are as the wings of a ship. I will give you this certain
token which cannot escape your notice. A wayfarer will meet you and
will say it must be a winnowing shovel that you have got upon your
shoulder; on this you must fix the oar in the ground and sacrifice a
ram, a bull, and a boar t'Neptune.90 Then g'home and offer hecatombs
t'all the gods in heaven one after the other. As for yourself, death
shall come t'you from the sea, and your life shall ebb away very
gently when you are full of years and peace of mind, and your people
shall bless you. All that I have said will come true].'91

characters.name: Fate And Free Will
characters.importance_exp: The prophecy given by Teiresias is central to Ulysses' journey.
characters.quote: 'You want t'know,' said he, 'about your return home, but heaven will make this hard for you.'

characters.name: Folly And Consequences
characters.importance_exp: The warning about harming the cattle highlights the consequences of Ulysses' choices.
characters.quote: 'If you harm them, then I forewarn you of the destruction both of your ship and of your men.'

characters.name: Vengeance
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' eventual revenge on the suitors is a key element of his narrative arc.
characters.quote: 'When you get home you will take your revenge on these suitors.'

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The role of gods and divine beings in shaping Ulysses' fate is significant.
characters.quote: 'heaven will make this hard for you.'

scenes.title: Mother's News
scenes.summary: Ulysses learns about his family from Anticlea.
scenes.explanation: Anticlea shares news about his family.
scenes.text:
"'This,' I answered, 'must be as it may please heaven, but tell me and
tell me and tell me true, I see my poor mother's ghost close by us; she
is sitting by the blood without saying a word, and though I am her own
son she does not remember me and speak t'me; tell me, Sir, how I can
make her know me.'
"'That,' said he, 'I can soon do. Any ghost that you let taste of the
blood will talk with you like a reasonable being, but if you d'not let
them have any blood they will g'away again.'
"On this the ghost of Teiresias went back t'the house of Hades, for
his prophecyings had now been spoken, but I sat still where I was until
my mother came up and tasted the blood. Then she knew me at once and
spoke fondly t'me, saying, 'My son, how did you come down t'this
abode of darkness while you are still alive? It is a hard thing for the
living t'see these places, for between us and them there are great and
terrible waters, and there is Oceanus, which n'man can cross on foot,
but he must have a good ship t'take him. Are you all this time trying
t'find your way home from Troy, and have you never yet got back to
Ithaca nor seen your wife in your own house?'
"'Mother,' said I, 'I was forced t'come here t'consult the ghost of
the Theban prophet Teiresias. I have never yet been near the Achaean
land nor set foot on my native country, and I have had nothing but one
long series of misfortunes from the very first day that I set out with
Agamemnon for Ilius, the land of noble steeds, t'fight the Trojans.
But tell me, and tell me true, in what way did you die? Did you have a
long illness, or did heaven vouchsafe you a gentle easy passage to
eternity? Tell me als'about my father, and the son whom I left behind
me, is my property still in their hands, or has some one else got hold
of it, wh'thinks that I shall not return t'claim it? Tell me again
what my wife intends doing, and in what mind she is; does she live with
my son and guard my estate securely, or has she made the best match she
could and married again?'
"My mother answered, 'Your wife still remains in your house, but she is
in great distress of mind and spends her whole time in tears both night
and day. N'one as yet has got possession of your fine property, and
Telemachus still holds your lands undisturbed. He has t'entertain
largely, as of course he must, considering his position as a
magistrate,92 and how every one invites him; your father remains at his
old place in the country and never goes near the town. He has no
comfortable bed nor bedding; in the winter he sleeps on the floor in
front of the fire with the men and goes about all in rags, but in
summer, when the warm weather comes on again, he lies out in the
vineyard on a bed of vine leaves thrown any how upon the ground. He
grieves continually about your never having come home, and suffers more
and more as he grows older. As for my own end it was in this wise:
heaven did not take me swiftly and painlessly in my own house, nor was
I attacked by any illness such as those that generally wear people out
and kill them, but my longing t'know what you were doing and the force
of my affection for you—this it was that was the death of me.'93

characters.quote: 'Your wife still remains in your house, but she is in great distress of mind and spends her whole time in tears both night and day.'
