scenes.title: Planning Revenge
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Minerva plan against the suitors.
scenes.explanation: Location remains with Ulysses and Minerva.
scenes.text:
consulted how t'compass the destruction of the wicked suitors.
"Ulysses," said Minerva, "noble son of Laertes, think how you can lay
hands on these disreputable people wh'have been lording it in your
house these three years, courting your wife and making wedding presents
t'her, while she does nothing but lament your absence, giving hope and
sending encouraging messages123 t'every one of them, but meaning the
very opposite of all she says."
And Ulysses answered, "In good truth, goddess, it seems I should have
come t'much the same bad end in my own house as Agamemnon did, if you
had not given me such timely information. Advise me how I shall best
avenge myself. Stand by my side and put your courage int'my heart as
on the day when we loosed Troy's fair diadem from her brow. Help me now
as you did then, and I will fight three hundred men, if you, goddess,
will be with me."
"Trust me for that," said she, "I will not lose sight of you when once
we set about it, and I imagine that some of those wh'are devouring
your substance will then bespatter the pavement with their blood and
brains. I will begin by disguising you s'that n'human being shall
know you; I will cover your body with wrinkles; you shall lose all your
yellow hair; I will clothe you in a garment that shall fill all wh'see
it with loathing; I will blear your fine eyes for you, and make you an
unseemly object in the sight of the suitors, of your wife, and of the
son whom you left behind you. Then g'at once t'the swineherd wh'is
in charge of your pigs; he has been always well affected towards you,
and is devoted t'Penelope and your son; you will find him feeding his
pigs near the rock that is called Raven124 by the fountain Arethusa,
where they are fattening on beechmast and spring water after their
manner. Stay with him and find out how things are going, while I
proceed t'Sparta and see your son, wh'is with Menelaus at Lacedaemon,
where he has gone t'try and find out whether you are still alive."125
"But why," said Ulysses, "did you not tell him, for you knew all about
it? Did you want him to't'g'sailing about amid all kinds of hardship
while others are eating up his estate?"
Minerva answered, "Never mind about him, I sent him that he might be
well spoken of for having gone. He is in n'sort of difficulty, but is
staying quite comfortably with Menelaus, and is surrounded with
abundance of every kind. The suitors have put out t'sea and are lying
in wait for him, for they mean t'kill him before he can get home. I do
not much think they will succeed, but rather that some of those wh'are
now eating up your estate will first find a grave themselves."
As she spoke Minerva touched him with her wand and covered him with
wrinkles, took away all his yellow hair, and withered the flesh over
his whole body; she bleared his eyes, which were naturally very fine
ones; she changed his clothes and threw an old rag of a wrap about him,
and a tunic, tattered, filthy, and begrimed with smoke; she als'gave
him an undressed deer skin as an outer garment, and furnished him with
a staff and a wallet all in holes, with a twisted thong for him to
sling it over his shoulder.
When the pair had thus laid their plans they parted, and the goddess

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Central to Ulysses' plan for revenge.
characters.quote: "Trust me for that," said she, "I will not lose sight of you when once we set about it..."

characters.name: Disguise And Deception
characters.importance_exp: Essential for Ulysses to reclaim his home.
characters.quote: "I will begin by disguising you s'that n'human being shall know you; I will cover your body with wrinkles..."

characters.name: Vengeance
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' primary motivation in this scene.
characters.quote: "Advise me how I shall best avenge myself. Stand by my side and put your courage int'my heart..."

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Highlighting the bond between Ulysses and his allies.
characters.quote: "he has been always well affected towards you, and is devoted t'Penelope and your son..."

scenes.title: Ulysses Meets Eumaeus
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives at Eumaeus' hut and is welcomed.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES IN THE HUT WITH EUMAEUS.
Ulysses now left the haven, and took the rough track up through the
wooded country and over the crest of the mountain till he reached the
place where Minerva had said that he would find the swineherd, wh'was
the most thrifty servant he had. He found him sitting in front of his
hut, which was by the yards that he had built on a site which could be
seen from far. He had made them spacious126 and fair t'see, with a
free run for the pigs all round them; he had built them during his
master's absence, of stones which he had gathered out of the ground,
without saying anything t'Penelope or Laertes, and he had fenced them
on top with thorn bushes. Outside the yard he had run a strong fence of
oaken posts, split, and set pretty close together, while inside he had
built twelve styes near one another for the sows t'lie in. There were
fifty pigs wallowing in each stye, all of them breeding sows; but the
boars slept outside and were much fewer in number, for the suitors kept
on eating them, and the swineherd had t'send them the best he had
continually. There were three hundred and sixty boar pigs, and the
herdsman's four hounds, which were as fierce as wolves, slept always
with them. The swineherd was at that moment cutting out a pair of
sandals127 from a good stout ox hide. Three of his men were out herding
the pigs in one place or another, and he had sent the fourth t'town
with a boar that he had been forced t'send the suitors that they might
sacrifice it and have their fill of meat.
When the hounds saw Ulysses they set up a furious barking and flew at
him, but Ulysses was cunning enough t'sit down and loose his hold of
the stick that he had in his hand: still, he would have been torn by
them in his own homestead had not the swineherd dropped his ox hide,
rushed full speed through the gate of the yard and driven the dogs off
by shouting and throwing stones at them. Then he said t'Ulysses, "Old
man, the dogs were likely t'have made short work of you, and then you
would have got me int'trouble. The gods have given me quite enough
worries without that, for I have lost the best of masters, and am in
continual grief on his account. I have t'attend swine for other people
t'eat, while he, if he yet lives t'see the light of day, is starving
in some distant land. But come inside, and when you have had your fill
of bread and wine, tell me where you come from, and all about your
misfortunes."
On this the swineherd led the way int'the hut and bade him sit down.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the swineherd's character and actions.
characters.quote: I have lost the best of masters, and am in continual grief on his account.

characters.name: Struggle And Survival
characters.importance_exp: The swineherd's hardships reflect the broader struggles faced by Ulysses and his household.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: The resilience shown in this theme highlights the character's determination to endure hardship while caring for others.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: The swineherd's invitation to Ulysses highlights the importance of hospitality in their culture.
characters.quote: But come inside, and when you have had your fill of bread and wine, tell me where you come from, and all about your misfortunes.

scenes.title: Dinner Preparations
scenes.summary: Eumaeus prepares a meal for Ulysses.
scenes.explanation: Transition to inside the hut for dinner.
scenes.text:
He strewed a good thick bed of rushes upon the floor, and on the top of
this he threw the shaggy chamois skin—a great thick one—on which he
used t'sleep by night. Ulysses was pleased at being made thus welcome,
and said "May Jove, sir, and the rest of the gods grant you your
heart's desire in return for the kind way in which you have received
me."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Stranger, though a still
poorer man should come here, it would not be right for me t'insult
him, for all strangers and beggars are from Jove. You must take what
you can get and be thankful, for servants live in fear when they have
young lords for their masters; and this is my misfortune now, for
heaven has hindered the return of him wh'would have been always good
t'me and given me something of my own—a house, a piece of land, a good
looking wife, and all else that a liberal master allows a servant who
has worked hard for him, and whose labour the gods have prospered as
they have mine in the situation which I hold. If my master had grown
old here he would have done great things by me, but he is gone, and I
wish that Helen's whole race were utterly destroyed, for she has been
the death of many a good man. It was this matter that took my master to
Ilius, the land of noble steeds, t'fight the Trojans in the cause of
king Agamemnon."
As he spoke he bound his girdle round him and went t'the styes where
the young sucking pigs were penned. He picked out tw'which he brought
back with him and sacrificed. He singed them, cut them up, and spitted
them; when the meat was cooked he brought it all in and set it before
Ulysses, hot and still on the spit, whereon Ulysses sprinkled it over
with white barley meal. The swineherd then mixed wine in a bowl of
ivy-wood, and taking a seat opposite Ulysses told him t'begin.
"Fall to, stranger," said he, "on a dish of servant's pork. The fat
pigs have t'g't'the suitors, wh'eat them up without shame or
scruple; but the blessed gods love not such shameful doings, and
respect those wh'd'what is lawful and right. Even the fierce
freebooters wh'g'raiding on other people's land, and Jove gives them
their spoil—even they, when they have filled their ships and got home
again live conscience-stricken, and look fearfully for judgement; but
some god seems t'have told these people that Ulysses is dead and gone;
they will not, therefore, g'back t'their own homes and make their
offers of marriage in the usual way, but waste his estate by force,
without fear or stint. Not a day or night comes out of heaven, but they
sacrifice not one victim nor tw'only, and they take the run of his
wine, for he was exceedingly rich. N'other great man either in Ithaca
or on the mainland is as rich as he was; he had as much as twenty men
put together. I will tell you what he had. There are twelve herds of
cattle upon the main land, and as many flocks of sheep, there are also
twelve droves of pigs, while his own men and hired strangers feed him
twelve widely spreading herds of goats. Here in Ithaca he runs even
large flocks of goats on the far end of the island, and they are in the
charge of excellent goat herds. Each one of these sends the suitors the
best goat in the flock every day. As for myself, I am in charge of the
pigs that you see here, and I have t'keep picking out the best I have
and sending it t'them."
This was his story, but Ulysses went on eating and drinking ravenously
without a word, brooding his revenge. When he had eaten enough and was
satisfied, the swineherd took the bowl from which he usually drank,
filled it with wine, and gave it t'Ulysses, wh'was pleased, and said
as he took it in his hands, "My friend, wh'was this master of yours
that bought you and paid for you, s'rich and s'powerful as you tell
me? You say he perished in the cause of King Agamemnon; tell me wh'he
was, in case I may have met with such a person. Jove and the other gods
know, but I may be able t'give you news of him, for I have travelled
much."
Eumaeus answered, "Old man, n'traveller wh'comes here with news will
get Ulysses' wife and son t'believe his story. Nevertheless, tramps in
want of a lodging keep coming with their mouths full of lies, and not a
word of truth; every one wh'finds his way t'Ithaca goes t'my
mistress and tells her falsehoods, whereon she takes them in, makes
much of them, and asks them all manner of questions, crying all the
time as women will when they have lost their husbands. And you too, old
man, for a shirt and a cloak would doubtless make up a very pretty
story. But the wolves and birds of prey have long since torn Ulysses to
pieces, or the fishes of the sea have eaten him, and his bones are
lying buried deep in sand upon some foreign shore; he is dead and gone,
and a bad business it is for all his friends—for me especially; go
where I may I shall never find s'good a master, not even if I were to
g'home t'my mother and father where I was bred and born. I d'not so
much care, however, about my parents now, though I should dearly like
t'see them again in my own country; it is the loss of Ulysses that
grieves me most; I cannot speak of him without reverence though he is
here n'longer, for he was very fond of me, and took such care of me
that wherever he may be I shall always honour his memory."
"My friend," replied Ulysses, "you are very positive, and very hard of
belief about your master's coming home again, nevertheless I will not
merely say, but will swear, that he is coming. D'not give me anything
for my news till he has actually come, you may then give me a shirt and
cloak of good wear if you will. I am in great want, but I will not take
anything at all till then, for I hate a man, even as I hate hell fire,
wh'lets his poverty tempt him int'lying. I swear by king Jove, by the
rites of hospitality, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I have now
come, that all will surely happen as I have said it will. Ulysses will
return in this self same year; with the end of this moon and the
beginning of the next he will be here t'd'vengeance on all those who
are ill treating his wife and son."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Old man, you will neither
get paid for bringing good news, nor will Ulysses ever come home; drink
your wine in peace, and let us talk about something else. D'not keep
on reminding me of all this; it always pains me when any one speaks
about my honoured master. As for your oath we will let it alone, but I
only wish he may come, as d'Penelope, his old father Laertes, and his
son Telemachus. I am terribly unhappy to'about this same boy of his;
he was running up fast int'manhood, and bade fare t'be n'worse man,
face and figure, than his father, but some one, either god or man, has
been unsettling his mind, s'he has gone off t'Pylos t'try and get
news of his father, and the suitors are lying in wait for him as he is
coming home, in the hope of leaving the house of Arceisius without a
name in Ithaca. But let us say n'more about him, and leave him t'be
taken, or else t'escape if the son of Saturn holds his hand over him
t'protect him. And now, old man, tell me your own story; tell me also,
for I want t'know, wh'you are and where you come from. Tell me of
your town and parents, what manner of ship you came in, how crew
brought you t'Ithaca, and from what country they professed t'come—for
you cannot have come by land."
And Ulysses answered, "I will tell you all about it. If there were meat
and wine enough, and we could stay here in the hut with nothing t'do
but t'eat and drink while the others g't'their work, I could easily
talk on for a whole twelve months without ever finishing the story of
the sorrows with which it has pleased heaven t'visit me.
"I am by birth a Cretan; my father was a well t'd'man, wh'had many
sons born in marriage, whereas I was the son of a slave whom he had
purchased for a concubine; nevertheless, my father Castor son of Hylax
(whose lineage I claim, and wh'was held in the highest honour among
the Cretans for his wealth, prosperity, and the valour of his sons) put
me on the same level with my brothers wh'had been born in wedlock.
When, however, death took him t'the house of Hades, his sons divided
his estate and cast lots for their shares, but t'me they gave a
holding and little else; nevertheless, my valour enabled me t'marry
int'a rich family, for I was not given t'bragging, or shirking on the
field of battle. It is all over now; still, if you look at the straw
you can see what the ear was, for I have had trouble enough and to
spare. Mars and Minerva made me doughty in war; when I had picked my
men t'surprise the enemy with an ambuscade I never gave death s'much
as a thought, but was the first t'leap forward and spear all whom I
could overtake. Such was I in battle, but I did not care about farm
work, nor the frugal home life of those wh'would bring up children. My
delight was in ships, fighting, javelins, and arrows—things that most
men shudder t'think of; but one man likes one thing and another
another, and this was what I was most naturally inclined to. Before the
Achaeans went t'Troy, nine times was I in command of men and ships on
foreign service, and I amassed much wealth. I had my pick of the spoil
in the first instance, and much more was allotted t'me later on.
"My house grew apace and I became a great man among the Cretans, but
when Jove counselled that terrible expedition, in which s'many
perished, the people required me and Idomeneus t'lead their ships to
Troy, and there was n'way out of it, for they insisted on our doing
so. There we fought for nine whole years, but in the tenth we sacked
the city of Priam and sailed home again as heaven dispersed us. Then it
was that Jove devised evil against me. I spent but one month happily
with my children, wife, and property, and then I conceived the idea of
making a descent on Egypt, s'I fitted out a fine fleet and manned it.
I had nine ships, and the people flocked t'fill them. For six days I
and my men made feast, and I found them many victims both for sacrifice
t'the gods and for themselves, but on the seventh day we went on board
and set sail from Crete with a fair North wind behind us though we were
going down a river. Nothing went ill with any of our ships, and we had
n'sickness on board, but sat where we were and let the ships g'as the
wind and steersmen took them. On the fifth day we reached the river
Aegyptus; there I stationed my ships in the river, bidding my men stay
by them and keep guard over them while I sent out scouts t'reconnoitre
from every point of vantage.
"But the men disobeyed my orders, took t'their own devices, and
ravaged the land of the Egyptians, killing the men, and taking their
wives and children captive. The alarm was soon carried t'the city, and
when they heard the war cry, the people came out at daybreak till the
plain was filled with horsemen and foot soldiers and with the gleam of
armour. Then Jove spread panic among my men, and they would n'longer
face the enemy, for they found themselves surrounded. The Egyptians
killed many of us, and took the rest alive t'd'forced labour for
them. Jove, however, put it in my mind t'd'thus—and I wish I had died
then and there in Egypt instead, for there was much sorrow in store for
me—I took off my helmet and shield and dropped my spear from my hand;
then I went straight up t'the king's chariot, clasped his knees and
kissed them, whereon he spared my life, bade me get int'his chariot,
and took me weeping t'his own home. Many made at me with their ashen
spears and tried t'kill me in their fury, but the king protected me,
for he feared the wrath of Jove the protector of strangers, who
punishes those wh'd'evil.
"I stayed there for seven years and got together much money among the
Egyptians, for they all gave me something; but when it was now going on
for eight years there came a certain Phoenician, a cunning rascal, who
had already committed all sorts of villainy, and this man talked me
over int'going with him t'Phoenicia, where his house and his
possessions lay. I stayed there for a whole twelve months, but at the
end of that time when months and days had gone by till the same season
had come round again, he set me on board a ship bound for Libya, on a
pretence that I was t'take a carg'along with him t'that place, but
really that he might sell me as a slave and take the money I fetched. I
suspected his intention, but went on board with him, for I could not
help it.
"The ship ran before a fresh North wind till we had reached the sea
that lies between Crete and Libya; there, however, Jove counselled
their destruction, for as soon as we were well out from Crete and could
see nothing but sea and sky, he raised a black cloud over our ship and
the sea grew dark beneath it. Then Jove let fly with his thunderbolts
and the ship went round and round and was filled with fire and
brimstone as the lightning struck it. The men fell all int'the sea;
they were carried about in the water round the ship looking like so
many sea-gulls, but the god presently deprived them of all chance of
getting home again. I was all dismayed. Jove, however, sent the ship's
mast within my reach, which saved my life, for I clung t'it, and
drifted before the fury of the gale. Nine days did I drift but in the
darkness of the tenth night a great wave bore me on t'the Thesprotian
coast. There Pheidon king of the Thesprotians entertained me hospitably
without charging me anything at all—for his son found me when I was
nearly dead with cold and fatigue, whereon he raised me by the hand,
took me t'his father's house and gave me clothes t'wear.
"There it was that I heard news of Ulysses, for the king told me he had
entertained him, and shown him much hospitality while he was on his
homeward journey. He showed me als'the treasure of gold, and wrought
iron that Ulysses had got together. There was enough t'keep his family
for ten generations, s'much had he left in the house of king Pheidon.
But the king said Ulysses had gone t'Dodona that he might learn Jove's
mind from the god's high oak tree, and know whether after s'long an
absence he should return t'Ithaca openly, or in secret. Moreover the
king swore in my presence, making drink-offerings in his own house as
he did so, that the ship was by the water side, and the crew found,
that should take him t'his own country. He sent me off however before
Ulysses returned, for there happened t'be a Thesprotian ship sailing
for the wheat-growing island of Dulichium, and he told those in charge
of her t'be sure and take me safely t'King Acastus.
"These men hatched a plot against me that would have reduced me t'the
very extreme of misery, for when the ship had got some way out from
land they resolved on selling me as a slave. They stripped me of the
shirt and cloak that I was wearing, and gave me instead the tattered
old clouts in which you now see me; then, towards nightfall, they
reached the tilled lands of Ithaca, and there they bound me with a
strong rope fast in the ship, while they went on shore t'get supper by
the sea side. But the gods soon undid my bonds for me, and having drawn
my rags over my head I slid down the rudder int'the sea, where I
struck out and swam till I was well clear of them, and came ashore near
a thick wood in which I lay concealed. They were very angry at my
having escaped and went searching about for me, till at last they
thought it was n'further use and went back t'their ship. The gods,
having hidden me thus easily, then took me t'a good man's door—for it
seems that I am not t'die yet awhile."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Poor unhappy stranger, I
have found the story of your misfortunes extremely interesting, but
that part about Ulysses is not right; and you will never get me to
believe it. Why should a man like you g'about telling lies in this
way? I know all about the return of my master. The gods one and all of
them detest him, or they would have taken him before Troy, or let him
die with friends around him when the days of his fighting were done;
for then the Achaeans would have built a mound over his ashes and his
son would have been heir t'his renown, but now the storm winds have
spirited him away we know not whither.
"As for me I live out of the way here with the pigs, and never g'to
the town unless when Penelope sends for me on the arrival of some news
about Ulysses. Then they all sit round and ask questions, both those
wh'grieve over the king's absence, and those wh'rejoice at it because
they can eat up his property without paying for it. For my own part I
have never cared about asking anyone else since the time when I was
taken in by an Aetolian, wh'had killed a man and come a long way till
at last he reached my station, and I was very kind t'him. He said he
had seen Ulysses with Idomeneus among the Cretans, refitting his ships
which had been damaged in a gale. He said Ulysses would return in the
following summer or autumn with his men, and that he would bring back
much wealth. And now you, you unfortunate old man, since fate has
brought you t'my door, d'not try t'flatter me in this way with vain
hopes. It is not for any such reason that I shall treat you kindly, but
only out of respect for Jove the god of hospitality, as fearing him and
pitying you."
Ulysses answered, "I see that you are of an unbelieving mind; I have
given you my oath, and yet you will not credit me; let us then make a
bargain, and call all the gods in heaven t'witness it. If your master
comes home, give me a cloak and shirt of good wear, and send me to
Dulichium where I want t'go; but if he does not come as I say he will,
set your men on t'me, and tell them t'throw me from yonder precipice,
as a warning t'tramps not t'g'about the country telling lies."
"And a pretty figure I should cut then," replied Eumaeus, "both now and
hereafter, if I were t'kill you after receiving you int'my hut and
showing you hospitality. I should have t'say my prayers in good
earnest if I did; but it is just supper time and I hope my men will
come in directly, that we may cook something savoury for supper."
Thus did they converse, and presently the swineherds came up with the
pigs, which were then shut up for the night in their styes, and a
tremendous squealing they made as they were being driven int'them. But
Eumaeus called t'his men and said, "Bring in the best pig you have,
that I may sacrifice him for this stranger, and we will take toll of
him ourselves. We have had trouble enough this long time feeding pigs,
while others reap the fruit of our labour."
On this he began chopping firewood, while the others brought in a fine
fat five year old boar pig, and set it at the altar. Eumaeus did not
forget the gods, for he was a man of good principles, s'the first
thing he did was t'cut bristles from the pig's face and throw them
int'the fire, praying t'all the gods as he did s'that Ulysses might
return home again. Then he clubbed the pig with a billet of oak which
he had kept back when he was chopping the firewood, and stunned it,
while the others slaughtered and singed it. Then they cut it up, and
Eumaeus began by putting raw pieces from each joint on t'some of the
fat; these he sprinkled with barley meal, and laid upon the embers;
they cut the rest of the meat up small, put the pieces upon the spits
and roasted them till they were done; when they had taken them off the
spits they threw them on t'the dresser in a heap. The swineherd, who
was a most equitable man, then stood up t'give every one his share. He
made seven portions; one of these he set apart for Mercury the son of
Maia and the nymphs, praying t'them as he did so; the others he dealt
out t'the men man by man. He gave Ulysses some slices cut lengthways
down the loin as a mark of especial honour, and Ulysses was much
pleased. "I hope, Eumaeus," said he, "that Jove will be as well
disposed towards you as I am, for the respect you are showing t'an
outcast like myself."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "Eat, my good fellow, and
enjoy your supper, such as it is. God grants this, and withholds that,
just as he thinks right, for he can d'whatever he chooses."
As he spoke he cut off the first piece and offered it as a burnt
sacrifice t'the immortal gods; then he made them a drink-offering, put
the cup in the hands of Ulysses, and sat down t'his own portion.
Mesaulius brought them their bread; the swineherd had brought this man
on his own account from among the Taphians during his master's absence,
and had paid for him with his own money without saying anything either
t'his mistress or Laertes. They then laid their hands upon the good
things that were before them, and when they had had enough t'eat and
drink, Mesaulius took away what was left of the bread, and they all
went t'bed after having made a hearty supper.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Central to the interaction between Ulysses and Eumaeus.
characters.quote: Stranger, though a still poorer man should come here, it would not be right for me t'insult him, for all strangers and beggars are from Jove.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus's loyalty to Ulysses is a key theme.
characters.quote: I cannot speak of him without reverence though he is here n'longer, for he was very fond of me, and took such care of me that wherever he may be I shall always honour his memory.

characters.name: Suffering
characters.importance_exp: Both characters express their hardships and losses.
characters.quote: I have found the story of your misfortunes extremely interesting, but that part about Ulysses is not right; and you will never get me to believe it.

characters.name: Hope
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses's promise of return brings a glimmer of hope.
characters.quote: I swear by king Jove, by the rites of hospitality, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I have now come, that all will surely happen as I have said it will.

scenes.title: Nightfall and Rest
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Eumaeus settle down for the night.
scenes.text:
Now the night came on stormy and very dark, for there was n'moon. It
poured without ceasing, and the wind blew strong from the West, which
is a wet quarter, s'Ulysses thought he would see whether Eumaeus, in
the excellent care he took of him, would take off his own cloak and
give it him, or make one of his men give him one. "Listen t'me," said
he, "Eumaeus and the rest of you; when I have said a prayer I will tell
you something. It is the wine that makes me talk in this way; wine will
make even a wise man fall t'singing; it will make him chuckle and
dance and say many a word that he had better leave unspoken; still, as
I have begun, I will g'on. Would that I were still young and strong as
when we got up an ambuscade before Troy. Menelaus and Ulysses were the
leaders, but I was in command also, for the other tw'would have it so.
When we had come up t'the wall of the city we crouched down beneath
our armour and lay there under cover of the reeds and thick brushwood
that grew about the swamp. It came on t'freeze with a North wind
blowing; the snow fell small and fine like hoar frost, and our shields
were coated thick with rime. The others had all got cloaks and shirts,
and slept comfortably enough with their shields about their shoulders,
but I had carelessly left my cloak behind me, not thinking that I
should be to'cold, and had gone off in nothing but my shirt and
shield. When the night was two-thirds through and the stars had shifted
their places, I nudged Ulysses wh'was close t'me with my elbow, and
he at once gave me his ear.
"'Ulysses,' said I, 'this cold will be the death of me, for I have no
cloak; some god fooled me int'setting off with nothing on but my
shirt, and I d'not know what t'do.'
"Ulysses, wh'was as crafty as he was valiant, hit upon the following
plan:
"'Keep still,' said he in a low voice, 'or the others will hear you.'
Then he raised his head on his elbow.
"'My friends,' said he, 'I have had a dream from heaven in my sleep. We
are a long way from the ships; I wish some one would g'down and tell
Agamemnon t'send us up more men at once.'
"On this Thoas son of Andraemon threw off his cloak and set out running
t'the ships, whereon I took the cloak and lay in it comfortably enough
till morning. Would that I were still young and strong as I was in
those days, for then some one of you swineherds would give me a cloak
both out of good will and for the respect due t'a brave soldier; but
now people look down upon me because my clothes are shabby."
And Eumaeus answered, "Old man, you have told us an excellent story,
and have said nothing s'far but what is quite satisfactory; for the
present, therefore, you shall want neither clothing nor anything else
that a stranger in distress may reasonably expect, but to-morrow
morning you have t'shake your own old rags about your body again, for
we have not many spare cloaks nor shirts up here, but every man has
only one. When Ulysses' son comes home again he will give you both
cloak and shirt, and send you wherever you may want t'go."
With this he got up and made a bed for Ulysses by throwing some
goatskins and sheepskins on the ground in front of the fire. Here
Ulysses lay down, and Eumaeus covered him over with a great heavy cloak
that he kept for a change in case of extraordinarily bad weather.
Thus did Ulysses sleep, and the young men slept beside him. But the
swineherd did not like sleeping away from his pigs, s'he got ready to
g'outside, and Ulysses was glad t'see that he looked after his
property during his master's absence. First he slung his sword over his
brawny shoulders and put on a thick cloak t'keep out the wind. He also
took the skin of a large and well fed goat, and a javelin in case of
attack from men or dogs. Thus equipped he went t'his rest where the
pigs were camping under an overhanging rock that gave them shelter from
the North wind.

characters.name: Struggle For Comfort
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Ulysses' experience in the scene.
characters.quote: Would that I were still young and strong as I was in those days, for then some one of you swineherds would give me a cloak both out of good will and for the respect due t'a brave soldier; but now people look down upon me because my clothes are shabby.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Eumaeus' actions highlight the theme of loyalty and care for Ulysses.
characters.quote: Old man, you have told us an excellent story, and have said nothing s'far but what is quite satisfactory; for the present, therefore, you shall want neither clothing nor anything else that a stranger in distress may reasonably expect.

characters.name: Nostalgia
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses reflects on his past strength and youth, which is a significant theme.
characters.quote: Would that I were still young and strong as when we got up an ambuscade before Troy.

scenes.title: Minerva's Visit to Telemachus
scenes.summary: Minerva visits Telemachus in Lacedaemon.
scenes.text:
MINERVA SUMMONS TELEMACHUS FROM LACEDAEMON—HE MEETS WITH THEOCLYMENUS
AT PYLOS AND BRINGS HIM T'ITHACA—ON LANDING HE GOES T'THE HUT OF
EUMAEUS.
But Minerva went t'the fair city of Lacedaemon t'tell Ulysses' son
that he was t'return at once. She found him and Pisistratus sleeping
in the forecourt of Menelaus's house; Pisistratus was fast asleep, but
Telemachus could get n'rest all night for thinking of his unhappy
father, s'Minerva went close up t'him and said:
"Telemachus, you should not remain s'far away from home any longer,
nor leave your property with such dangerous people in your house; they
will eat up everything you have among them, and you will have been on a
fool's errand. Ask Menelaus t'send you home at once if you wish to
find your excellent mother still there when you get back. Her father
and brothers are already urging her t'marry Eurymachus, wh'has given
her more than any of the others, and has been greatly increasing his
wedding presents. I hope nothing valuable may have been taken from the
house in spite of you, but you know what women are—they always want to
d'the best they can for the man wh'marries them, and never give
another thought t'the children of their first husband, nor t'their
father either when he is dead and done with. G'home, therefore, and
put everything in charge of the most respectable woman servant that you
have, until it shall please heaven t'send you a wife of your own. Let
me tell you als'of another matter which you had better attend to. The
chief men among the suitors are lying in wait for you in the Strait128
between Ithaca and Samos, and they mean t'kill you before you can
reach home. I d'not much think they will succeed; it is more likely
that some of those wh'are now eating up your property will find a
grave themselves. Sail night and day, and keep your ship well away from
the islands; the god wh'watches over you and protects you will send
you a fair wind. As soon as you get t'Ithaca send your ship and men on
t'the town, but yourself g'straight t'the swineherd wh'has charge
of your pigs; he is well disposed towards you, stay with him,
therefore, for the night, and then send him t'Penelope t'tell her
that you have got back safe from Pylos."

characters.name: The Mother's Love
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the scene as Minerva advises Telemachus about his family.
characters.quote: "you should not remain s'far away from home any longer, nor leave your property with such dangerous people in your house; they will eat up everything you have among them"

characters.name: Danger And Threat
characters.importance_exp: The threat to Telemachus's life is a critical element of the scene.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Fear and caution are evident in this theme as it warns of impending danger that could thwart the character's journey home.

characters.name: Longing For Father
characters.importance_exp: The theme of returning home is vital as it drives Telemachus's actions.
characters.quote: "Sail night and day, and keep your ship well away from the islands; the god wh'watches over you and protects you will send you a fair wind."

scenes.title: Departure from Lacedaemon
scenes.summary: Telemachus prepares to leave Lacedaemon with Pisistratus.
scenes.text:
Then she went back t'Olympus; but Telemachus stirred Pisistratus with
his heel t'rouse him, and said, "Wake up Pisistratus, and yoke the
horses t'the chariot, for we must set off home."129
But Pisistratus said, "N'matter what hurry we are in we cannot drive
in the dark. It will be morning soon; wait till Menelaus has brought
his presents and put them in the chariot for us; and let him say good
bye t'us in the usual way. S'long as he lives a guest should never
forget a host wh'has shown him kindness."
As he spoke day began t'break, and Menelaus, wh'had already risen,
leaving Helen in bed, came towards them. When Telemachus saw him he put
on his shirt as fast as he could, threw a great cloak over his
shoulders, and went out t'meet him. "Menelaus," said he, "let me go
back now t'my own country, for I want t'get home."
And Menelaus answered, "Telemachus, if you insist on going I will not
detain you. I d'not like t'see a host either to'fond of his guest or
to'rude t'him. Moderation is best in all things, and not letting a
man g'when he wants t'd's'is as bad as telling him t'g'if he
would like t'stay. One should treat a guest well as long as he is in
the house and speed him when he wants t'leave it. Wait, then, till I
can get your beautiful presents int'your chariot, and till you have
yourself seen them. I will tell the women t'prepare a sufficient
dinner for you of what there may be in the house; it will be at once
more proper and cheaper for you t'get your dinner before setting out
on such a long journey. If, moreover, you have a fancy for making a
tour in Hellas or in the Peloponnese, I will yoke my horses, and will
conduct you myself through all our principal cities. N'one will send
us away empty handed; every one will give us something—a bronze tripod,
a couple of mules, or a gold cup."
"Menelaus," replied Telemachus, "I want t'g'home at once, for when I
came away I left my property without protection, and fear that while
looking for my father I shall come t'ruin myself, or find that
something valuable has been stolen during my absence."

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the interactions between the characters.
characters.quote: "S'long as he lives a guest should never forget a host wh'has shown him kindness."

characters.name: Urgency
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus's desire to return home drives the scene's action.
characters.quote: "I want t'g'home at once, for when I came away I left my property without protection..."

characters.name: Caution Vs. Recklessness
characters.importance_exp: Menelaus emphasizes the importance of balance in hospitality.
characters.quote: "Moderation is best in all things, and not letting a man g'when he wants t'd's'is as bad as telling him t'g'if he would like t'stay."

scenes.title: Menelaus' Farewell
scenes.summary: Menelaus bids farewell to Telemachus and Pisistratus.
scenes.text:
When Menelaus heard this he immediately told his wife and servants to
prepare a sufficient dinner from what there might be in the house. At
this moment Eteoneus joined him, for he lived close by and had just got
up; s'Menelaus told him t'light the fire and cook some meat, which he
at once did. Then Menelaus went down int'his fragrant store room,130
not alone, but Helen went too, with Megapenthes. When he reached the
place where the treasures of his house were kept, he selected a double
cup, and told his son Megapenthes t'bring als'a silver mixing bowl.
Meanwhile Helen went t'the chest where she kept the lovely dresses
which she had made with her own hands, and took out one that was
largest and most beautifully enriched with embroidery; it glittered
like a star, and lay at the very bottom of the chest. 131 Then they all
came back through the house again till they got t'Telemachus, and
Menelaus said, "Telemachus, may Jove, the mighty husband of Juno, bring
you safely home according t'your desire. I will now present you with
the finest and most precious piece of plate in all my house. It is a
mixing bowl of pure silver, except the rim, which is inlaid with gold,
and it is the work of Vulcan. Phaedimus king of the Sidonians made me a
present of it in the course of a visit that I paid him while I was on
my return home. I should like t'give it t'you."
With these words he placed the double cup in the hands of Telemachus,
while Megapenthes brought the beautiful mixing bowl and set it before
him. Hard by stood lovely Helen with the robe ready in her hand.
"I too, my son," said she, "have something for you as a keepsake from
the hand of Helen; it is for your bride t'wear upon her wedding day.
Till then, get your dear mother t'keep it for you; thus may you go
back rejoicing t'your own country and t'your home."
S'saying she gave the robe over t'him and he received it gladly. Then
Pisistratus put the presents int'the chariot, and admired them all as
he did so. Presently Menelaus took Telemachus and Pisistratus int'the
house, and they both of them sat down t'table. A maid servant brought
them water in a beautiful golden ewer, and poured it int'a silver
basin for them t'wash their hands, and she drew a clean table beside
them; an upper servant brought them bread and offered them many good
things of what there was in the house. Eteoneus carved the meat and
gave them each their portions, while Megapenthes poured out the wine.
Then they laid their hands upon the good things that were before them,
but as soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink Telemachus and
Pisistratus yoked the horses, and took their places in the chariot.
They drove out through the inner gateway and under the echoing
gatehouse of the outer court, and Menelaus came after them with a
golden goblet of wine in his right hand that they might make a
drink-offering before they set out. He stood in front of the horses and
pledged them, saying, "Farewell t'both of you; see that you tell
Nestor how I have treated you, for he was as kind t'me as any father
could be while we Achaeans were fighting before Troy."

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Central to the scene as Menelaus prepares a feast for his guests.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: Warmth and generosity are embodied in this theme, showcasing the kindness extended to guests in times of need.

characters.name: Ritual And Memory
characters.importance_exp: Significant as Menelaus presents valuable gifts to Telemachus.
characters.quote: I will now present you with the finest and most precious piece of plate in all my house.

characters.name: Family Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Present but not the main focus, as Helen gives a keepsake for Telemachus's future bride.
characters.quote: it is for your bride t'wear upon her wedding day.

scenes.title: The Omen
scenes.summary: Telemachus receives an omen from an eagle.
scenes.explanation: Location changes as they prepare to leave.
scenes.text:
"We will be sure, sir," answered Telemachus, "t'tell him everything as
soon as we see him. I wish I were as certain of finding Ulysses
returned when I get back t'Ithaca, that I might tell him of the very
great kindness you have shown me and of the many beautiful presents I
am taking with me."
As he was thus speaking a bird flew on his right hand—an eagle with a
great white goose in its talons which it had carried off from the farm
yard—and all the men and women were running after it and shouting. It
came quite close up t'them and flew away on their right hands in front
of the horses. When they saw it they were glad, and their hearts took
comfort within them, whereon Pisistratus said, "Tell me, Menelaus, has
heaven sent this omen for us or for you?"
Menelaus was thinking what would be the most proper answer for him to
make, but Helen was to'quick for him and said, "I will read this
matter as heaven has put it in my heart, and as I doubt not that it
will come t'pass. The eagle came from the mountain where it was bred
and has its nest, and in like manner Ulysses, after having travelled
far and suffered much, will return t'take his revenge—if indeed he is
not back already and hatching mischief for the suitors."

characters.name: Hope And Return
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' motivations and actions in the scene.
characters.quote: I wish I were as certain of finding Ulysses returned when I get back t'Ithaca, that I might tell him of the very great kindness you have shown me.

characters.name: Prophecy Fulfillment
characters.importance_exp: The omen serves as a significant sign that influences the characters' beliefs about the future.
characters.quote: I will read this matter as heaven has put it in my heart, and as I doubt not that it will come t'pass.

characters.name: Gratitude And Relief
characters.importance_exp: This theme reflects the relationships and bonds formed between characters, though it is less central than others.
characters.quote: the very great kindness you have shown me

scenes.title: Journey to Pylos
scenes.summary: Telemachus and Pisistratus travel to Pylos.
scenes.text:
As he spoke he lashed his horses and they started off at full speed
through the town towards the open country. They swayed the yoke upon
their necks and travelled the whole day long till the sun set and
darkness was over all the land. Then they reached Pherae, where Diocles
lived wh'was son of Ortilochus, the son of Alpheus. There they passed
the night and were treated hospitably. When the child of morning,
rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, they again yoked their horses and their
places in the chariot. They drove out through the inner gateway and
under the echoing gatehouse of the outer court. Then Pisistratus lashed
his horses on and they flew forward nothing loath; ere long they came
t'Pylos, and then Telemachus said:

characters.name: Heroic Journey
characters.importance_exp: The journey is central to the scene as it drives the narrative forward.
characters.quote: As he spoke he lashed his horses and they started off at full speed through the town towards the open country.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Hospitality is significant as it highlights the kindness of the characters they encounter.
characters.quote: there they passed the night and were treated hospitably.

characters.name: Time
characters.importance_exp: The passage of time is important as it marks the transition from day to night and the journey's progression.
characters.quote: till the sun set and darkness was over all the land.

scenes.title: Arrival at Pylos
scenes.summary: Telemachus arrives at Pylos and speaks with Pisistratus.
scenes.text:
"Pisistratus, I hope you will promise t'd'what I am going t'ask you.
You know our fathers were old friends before us; moreover, we are both
of an age, and this journey has brought us together still more closely;
d'not, therefore, take me past my ship, but leave me there, for if I
g't'your father's house he will try t'keep me in the warmth of his
good will towards me, and I must g'home at once."
Pisistratus thought how he should d'as he was asked, and in the end he
deemed it best t'turn his horses towards the ship, and put Menelaus's
beautiful presents of gold and raiment in the stern of the vessel. Then
he said, "G'on board at once and tell your men t'd's'als'before I
can reach home t'tell my father. I know how obstinate he is, and am
sure he will not let you go; he will come down here t'fetch you, and
he will not g'back without you. But he will be very angry."
With this he drove his goodly steeds back t'the city of the Pylians

characters.name: Friendship
characters.importance_exp: The bond between the characters is central to the scene.
characters.quote: You know our fathers were old friends before us; moreover, we are both of an age, and this journey has brought us together still more closely.

characters.name: Urgency
characters.importance_exp: The need to return home quickly drives the actions of the characters.
characters.quote: I must g'home at once.

characters.name: Dangerous Choices
characters.importance_exp: The stubborn nature of Menelaus is highlighted as a concern.
characters.quote: I know how obstinate he is, and am sure he will not let you go; he will come down here t'fetch you, and he will not g'back without you.

scenes.title: Theoclymenus Joins Telemachus
scenes.summary: Theoclymenus, a seer, asks to join Telemachus.
scenes.text:
and soon reached his home, but Telemachus called the men together and
gave his orders. "Now, my men," said he, "get everything in order on
board the ship, and let us set out home."
Thus did he speak, and they went on board even as he had said. But as
Telemachus was thus busied, praying als'and sacrificing t'Minerva in
the ship's stern, there came t'him a man from a distant country, a
seer, wh'was flying from Argos because he had killed a man. He was
descended from Melampus, wh'used t'live in Pylos, the land of sheep;
he was rich and owned a great house, but he was driven int'exile by
the great and powerful king Neleus. Neleus seized his goods and held
them for a whole year, during which he was a close prisoner in the
house of king Phylacus, and in much distress of mind both on account of
the daughter of Neleus and because he was haunted by a great sorrow
that dread Erinys had laid upon him. In the end, however, he escaped
with his life, drove the cattle from Phylace t'Pylos, avenged the
wrong that had been done him, and gave the daughter of Neleus t'his
brother. Then he left the country and went t'Argos, where it was
ordained that he should reign over much people. There he married,
established himself, and had tw'famous sons Antiphates and Mantius.
Antiphates became father of Oicleus, and Oicleus of Amphiaraus, wh'was
dearly loved both by Jove and by Apollo, but he did not live t'old
age, for he was killed in Thebes by reason of a woman's gifts. His sons
were Alcmaeon and Amphilochus. Mantius, the other son of Melampus, was
father t'Polypheides and Cleitus. Aurora, throned in gold, carried off
Cleitus for his beauty's sake, that he might dwell among the immortals,
but Apoll'made Polypheides the greatest seer in the whole world now
that Amphiaraus was dead. He quarrelled with his father and went to
live in Hyperesia, where he remained and prophesied for all men.
His son, Theoclymenus, it was wh'now came up t'Telemachus as he was
making drink-offerings and praying in his ship. "Friend," said he, "now
that I find you sacrificing in this place, I beseech you by your
sacrifices themselves, and by the god t'whom you make them, I pray you
als'by your own head and by those of your followers tell me the truth
and nothing but the truth. Wh'and whence are you? Tell me als'of your
town and parents."
Telemachus said, "I will answer you quite truly. I am from Ithaca, and
my father is Ulysses, as surely as that he ever lived. But he has come
t'some miserable end. Therefore I have taken this ship and got my crew
together t'see if I can hear any news of him, for he has been away a
long time."
"I too," answered Theoclymenus, "am an exile, for I have killed a man
of my own race. He has many brothers and kinsmen in Argos, and they
have great power among the Argives. I am flying t'escape death at
their hands, and am thus doomed t'be a wanderer on the face of the
earth. I am your suppliant; take me, therefore, on board your ship that
they may not kill me, for I know they are in pursuit."
"I will not refuse you," replied Telemachus, "if you wish t'join us.
Come, therefore, and in Ithaca we will treat you hospitably according
t'what we have."

characters.name: Stranger's Plight
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the characters' motivations and backgrounds.
characters.quote: I am your suppliant; take me, therefore, on board your ship that they may not kill me, for I know they are in pursuit.

characters.name: Identity And Origin
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus' quest for news of his father drives the narrative.
characters.quote: I am from Ithaca, and my father is Ulysses, as surely as that he ever lived.

characters.name: Hospitality And Suppliancy
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the cultural values of the characters and their interactions.
characters.quote: I will not refuse you, replied Telemachus, if you wish t'join us.

scenes.title: Setting Sail
scenes.summary: Telemachus and his crew set sail from Pylos.
scenes.text:
On this he received Theoclymenus' spear and laid it down on the deck of
the ship. He went on board and sat in the stern, bidding Theoclymenus
sit beside him; then the men let g'the hawsers. Telemachus told them
t'catch hold of the ropes, and they made all haste t'd'so. They set
the mast in its socket in the cross plank, raised it and made it fast
with the forestays, and they hoisted their white sails with sheets of
twisted ox hide. Minerva sent them a fair wind that blew fresh and
strong t'take the ship on her course as fast as possible. Thus then
they passed by Crouni and Chalcis.

characters.name: Heroic Journey
characters.importance_exp: The start of their voyage is crucial to the scene.
characters.quote: They set the mast in its socket in the cross plank, raised it and made it fast with the forestays, and they hoisted their white sails with sheets of twisted ox hide.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Minerva's intervention is significant for their success.
characters.quote: Minerva sent them a fair wind that blew fresh and strong t'take the ship on her course as fast as possible.

scenes.title: Ulysses and Eumaeus
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Eumaeus discuss plans in the hut.
scenes.text:
Meanwhile Ulysses and the swineherd were eating their supper in the
hut, and the men supped with them. As soon as they had had t'eat and
drink, Ulysses began trying t'prove the swineherd and see whether he
would continue t'treat him kindly, and ask him t'stay on at the
station or pack him off t'the city; s'he said:
"Eumaeus, and all of you, to-morrow I want t'g'away and begin begging
about the town, s'as t'be n'more trouble t'you or t'your men. Give
me your advice therefore, and let me have a good guide t'g'with me
and show me the way. I will g'the round of the city begging as I needs
must, t'see if any one will give me a drink and a piece of bread. I
should like als't'g't'the house of Ulysses and bring news of her
husband t'Queen Penelope. I could then g'about among the suitors and
see if out of all their abundance they will give me a dinner. I should
soon make them an excellent servant in all sorts of ways. Listen and
believe when I tell you that by the blessing of Mercury wh'gives grace
and good name t'the works of all men, there is n'one living wh'would
make a more handy servant than I should—t'put fresh wood on the fire,
chop fuel, carve, cook, pour out wine, and d'all those services that
poor men have t'd'for their betters."
The swineherd was very much disturbed when he heard this. "Heaven help
me," he exclaimed, "what ever can have put such a notion as that into
your head? If you g'near the suitors you will be undone t'a
certainty, for their pride and insolence reach the very heavens. They
would never think of taking a man like you for a servant. Their
servants are all young men, well dressed, wearing good cloaks and
shirts, with well looking faces and their hair always tidy, the tables
are kept quite clean and are loaded with bread, meat, and wine. Stay
where you are, then; you are not in anybody's way; I d'not mind your
being here, n'more d'any of the others, and when Telemachus comes
home he will give you a shirt and cloak and will send you wherever you
want t'go."
Ulysses answered, "I hope you may be as dear t'the gods as you are to
me, for having saved me from going about and getting int'trouble;
there is nothing worse than being always on the tramp; still, when men
have once got low down in the world they will g'through a great deal
on behalf of their miserable bellies. Since, however, you press me to
stay here and await the return of Telemachus, tell me about Ulysses'
mother, and his father whom he left on the threshold of old age when he
set out for Troy. Are they still living or are they already dead and in
the house of Hades?"
"I will tell you all about them," replied Eumaeus, "Laertes is still
living and prays heaven t'let him depart peacefully in his own house,
for he is terribly distressed about the absence of his son, and also
about the death of his wife, which grieved him greatly and aged him
more than anything else did. She came t'an unhappy end133 through
sorrow for her son: may n'friend or neighbour wh'has dealt kindly by
me come t'such an end as she did. As long as she was still living,
though she was always grieving, I used t'like seeing her and asking
her how she did, for she brought me up along with her daughter Ctimene,
the youngest of her children; we were boy and girl together, and she
made little difference between us. When, however, we both grew up, they
sent Ctimene t'Same and received a splendid dowry for her. As for me,
my mistress gave me a good shirt and cloak with a pair of sandals for
my feet, and sent me off int'the country, but she was just as fond of
me as ever. This is all over now. Still it has pleased heaven to
prosper my work in the situation which I now hold. I have enough t'eat
and drink, and can find something for any respectable stranger who
comes here; but there is n'getting a kind word or deed out of my
mistress, for the house has fallen int'the hands of wicked people.
Servants want sometimes t'see their mistress and have a talk with her;
they like t'have something t'eat and drink at the house, and
something to't'take back with them int'the country. This is what
will keep servants in a good humour."
Ulysses answered, "Then you must have been a very little fellow,
Eumaeus, when you were taken s'far away from your home and parents.
Tell me, and tell me true, was the city in which your father and mother
lived sacked and pillaged, or did some enemies carry you off when you
were alone tending sheep or cattle, ship you off here, and sell you for
whatever your master gave them?"
"Stranger," replied Eumaeus, "as regards your question: sit still, make
yourself comfortable, drink your wine, and listen t'me. The nights are
now at their longest; there is plenty of time both for sleeping and
sitting up talking together; you ought not t'g't'bed till bed time,
to'much sleep is as bad as to'little; if any one of the others wishes
t'g't'bed let him leave us and d'so; he can then take my master's
pigs out when he has done breakfast in the morning. We to'will sit
here eating and drinking in the hut, and telling one another stories
about our misfortunes; for when a man has suffered much, and been

scenes.title: Telemachus Returns to Ithaca
scenes.summary: Telemachus returns to Ithaca and plans to visit the herdsmen.
scenes.text:
sleep, for it was soon daybreak. In the mean time Telemachus and his
crew were nearing land, s'they loosed the sails, took down the mast,
and rowed the ship int'the harbour.136 They cast out their mooring
stones and made fast the hawsers; they then got out upon the sea shore,
mixed their wine, and got dinner ready. As soon as they had had enough
t'eat and drink Telemachus said, "Take the ship on t'the town, but
leave me here, for I want t'look after the herdsmen on one of my
farms. In the evening, when I have seen all I want, I will come down to
the city, and to-morrow morning in return for your trouble I will give
you all a good dinner with meat and wine." 137
Then Theoclymenus said, "And what, my dear young friend, is t'become
of me? T'whose house, among all your chief men, am I t'repair? or
shall I g'straight t'your own house and t'your mother?"
"At any other time," replied Telemachus, "I should have bidden you go
t'my own house, for you would find n'want of hospitality; at the
present moment, however, you would not be comfortable there, for I
shall be away, and my mother will not see you; she does not often show
herself even t'the suitors, but sits at her loom weaving in an upper
chamber, out of their way; but I can tell you a man whose house you can
g'to—I mean Eurymachus the son of Polybus, wh'is held in the highest
estimation by every one in Ithaca. He is much the best man and the most
persistent wooer, of all those wh'are paying court t'my mother and
trying t'take Ulysses' place. Jove, however, in heaven alone knows
whether or n'they will come t'a bad end before the marriage takes
place."
As he was speaking a bird flew by upon his right hand—a hawk, Apollo's
messenger. It held a dove in its talons, and the feathers, as it tore
them off,138 fell t'the ground midway between Telemachus and the ship.
On this Theoclymenus called him apart and caught him by the hand.
"Telemachus," said he, "that bird did not fly on your right hand
without having been sent there by some god. As soon as I saw it I knew
it was an omen; it means that you will remain powerful and that there
will be n'house in Ithaca more royal than your own."
"I wish it may prove so," answered Telemachus. "If it does, I will show
you s'much good will and give you s'many presents that all wh'meet
you will congratulate you."
Then he said t'his friend Piraeus, "Piraeus, son of Clytius, you have
throughout shown yourself the most willing t'serve me of all those who
have accompanied me t'Pylos; I wish you would take this stranger to
your own house and entertain him hospitably till I can come for him."
And Piraeus answered, "Telemachus, you may stay away as long as you
please, but I will look after him for you, and he shall find n'lack of
hospitality."
As he spoke he went on board, and bade the others d's'als'and loose
the hawsers, s'they took their places in the ship. But Telemachus
bound on his sandals, and took a long and doughty spear with a head of
sharpened bronze from the deck of the ship. Then they loosed the
hawsers, thrust the ship off from land, and made on towards the city as
they had been told t'do, while Telemachus strode on as fast as he
could, till he reached the homestead where his countless herds of swine
were feeding, and where dwelt the excellent swineherd, wh'was so
devoted a servant t'his master.

scenes.title: Ulysses and Telemachus Meet
scenes.summary: Ulysses reveals himself to Telemachus in the hut.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES REVEALS HIMSELF T'TELEMACHUS.
Meanwhile Ulysses and the swineherd had lit a fire in the hut and were
were getting breakfast ready at daybreak, for they had sent the men out
with the pigs. When Telemachus came up, the dogs did not bark but
fawned upon him, s'Ulysses, hearing the sound of feet and noticing
that the dogs did not bark, said t'Eumaeus:
"Eumaeus, I hear footsteps; I suppose one of your men or some one of
your acquaintance is coming here, for the dogs are fawning upon him and
not barking."
The words were hardly out of his mouth before his son stood at the
door. Eumaeus sprang t'his feet, and the bowls in which he was mixing
wine fell from his hands, as he made towards his master. He kissed his
head and both his beautiful eyes, and wept for joy. A father could not
be more delighted at the return of an only son, the child of his old
age, after ten years' absence in a foreign country and after having
gone through much hardship. He embraced him, kissed him all over as
though he had come back from the dead, and spoke fondly t'him saying:
"S'you are come, Telemachus, light of my eyes that you are. When I
heard you had gone t'Pylos I made sure I was never going t'see you
any more. Come in, my dear child, and sit down, that I may have a good
look at you now you are home again; it is not very often you come into
the country t'see us herdsmen; you stick pretty close t'the town
generally. I suppose you think it better t'keep an eye on what the
suitors are doing."
"S'be it, old friend," answered Telemachus, "but I am come now because
I want t'see you, and t'learn whether my mother is still at her old
home or whether some one else has married her, s'that the bed of
Ulysses is without bedding and covered with cobwebs."
"She is still at the house," replied Eumaeus, "grieving and breaking
her heart, and doing nothing but weep, both night and day continually."
As he spoke he took Telemachus' spear, whereon he crossed the stone
threshold and came inside. Ulysses rose from his seat t'give him place
as he entered, but Telemachus checked him; "Sit down, stranger," said
he, "I can easily find another seat, and there is one here wh'will lay
it for me."
Ulysses went back t'his own place, and Eumaeus strewed some green
brushwood on the floor and threw a sheepskin on top of it for
Telemachus t'sit upon. Then the swineherd brought them platters of
cold meat, the remains from what they had eaten the day before, and he
filled the bread baskets with bread as fast as he could. He mixed wine
als'in bowls of ivy-wood, and took his seat facing Ulysses. Then they
laid their hands on the good things that were before them, and as soon
as they had had enough t'eat and drink Telemachus said t'Eumaeus,
"Old friend, where does this stranger come from? How did his crew bring
him t'Ithaca, and wh'were they?—for assuredly he did not come here by
land."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "My son, I will tell you the
real truth. He says he is a Cretan, and that he has been a great
traveller. At this moment he is running away from a Thesprotian ship,
and has taken refuge at my station, s'I will put him int'your hands.
D'whatever you like with him, only remember that he is your
suppliant."
"I am very much distressed," said Telemachus, "by what you have just
told me. How can I take this stranger int'my house? I am as yet young,
and am not strong enough t'hold my own if any man attacks me. My
mother cannot make up her mind whether t'stay where she is and look
after the house out of respect for public opinion and the memory of her
husband, or whether the time is now come for her t'take the best man
of those wh'are wooing her, and the one wh'will make her the most
advantageous offer; still, as the stranger has come t'your station I
will find him a cloak and shirt of good wear, with a sword and sandals,
and will send him wherever he wants t'go. Or if you like you can keep
him here at the station, and I will send him clothes and food that he
may be n'burden on you and on your men; but I will not have him go
near the suitors, for they are very insolent, and are sure t'ill treat
him in a way that would greatly grieve me; n'matter how valiant a man
may be he can d'nothing against numbers, for they will be to'strong
for him."
Then Ulysses said, "Sir, it is right that I should say something
myself. I am much shocked about what you have said about the insolent
way in which the suitors are behaving in despite of such a man as you
are. Tell me, d'you submit t'such treatment tamely, or has some god
set your people against you? May you not complain of your brothers—for
it is t'these that a man may look for support, however great his
quarrel may be? I wish I were as young as you are and in my present
mind; if I were son t'Ulysses, or, indeed, Ulysses himself, I would
rather some one came and cut my head off, but I would g't'the house
and be the bane of every one of these men.139 If they were to'many for
me—I being single-handed—I would rather die fighting in my own house
than see such disgraceful sights day after day, strangers grossly
maltreated, and men dragging the women servants about the house in an
unseemly way, wine drawn recklessly, and bread wasted all t'n'purpose
for an end that shall never be accomplished."
And Telemachus answered, "I will tell you truly everything. There is no
enmity between me and my people, nor can I complain of brothers, to
whom a man may look for support however great his quarrel may be. Jove
has made us a race of only sons. Laertes was the only son of Arceisius,
and Ulysses only son of Laertes. I am myself the only son of Ulysses
wh'left me behind him when he went away, s'that I have never been of
any use t'him. Hence it comes that my house is in the hands of
numberless marauders; for the chiefs from all the neighbouring islands,
Dulichium, Same, Zacynthus, as als'all the principal men of Ithaca
itself, are eating up my house under the pretext of paying court t'my
mother, wh'will neither say point blank that she will not marry, nor
yet bring matters t'an end, s'they are making havoc of my estate, and
before long will d's'with myself int'the bargain. The issue,
however, rests with heaven. But d'you, old friend Eumaeus, g'at once
and tell Penelope that I am safe and have returned from Pylos. Tell it
t'herself alone, and then come back here without letting any one else
know, for there are many wh'are plotting mischief against me."
"I understand and heed you," replied Eumaeus; "you need instruct me no
further, only as I am going that way say whether I had not better let
poor Laertes know that you are returned. He used t'superintend the
work on his farm in spite of his bitter sorrow about Ulysses, and he
would eat and drink at will along with his servants; but they tell me
that from the day on which you set out for Pylos he has neither eaten
nor drunk as he ought t'do, nor does he look after his farm, but sits
weeping and wasting the flesh from off his bones."
"More's the pity," answered Telemachus, "I am sorry for him, but we
must leave him t'himself just now. If people could have everything
their own way, the first thing I should choose would be the return of
my father; but go, and give your message; then make haste back again,
and d'not turn out of your way t'tell Laertes. Tell my mother t'send
one of her women secretly with the news at once, and let him hear it
from her."
Thus did he urge the swineherd; Eumaeus, therefore, took his sandals,
bound them t'his feet, and started for the town. Minerva watched him
well off the station, and then came up t'it in the form of a
woman—fair, stately, and wise. She stood against the side of the entry,
and revealed herself t'Ulysses, but Telemachus could not see her, and
knew not that she was there, for the gods d'not let themselves be seen
by everybody. Ulysses saw her, and s'did the dogs, for they did not
bark, but went scared and whining off t'the other side of the yards.
She nodded her head and motioned t'Ulysses with her eyebrows; whereon
he left the hut and stood before her outside the main wall of the
yards. Then she said t'him:
"Ulysses, noble son of Laertes, it is now time for you t'tell your
son: d'not keep him in the dark any longer, but lay your plans for the
destruction of the suitors, and then make for the town. I will not be
long in joining you, for I to'am eager for the fray."
As she spoke she touched him with her golden wand. First she threw a
fair clean shirt and cloak about his shoulders; then she made him
younger and of more imposing presence; she gave him back his colour,
filled out his cheeks, and let his beard become dark again. Then she
went away and Ulysses came back inside the hut. His son was astounded
