scenes.title: Eumaeus Delivers News
scenes.summary: Eumaeus goes to inform Penelope about Telemachus's return.
scenes.explanation: Change of location to Penelope's house.
scenes.text:
when he saw him, and turned his eyes away for fear he might be looking
upon a god.
"Stranger," said he, "how suddenly you have changed from what you were
a moment or tw'ago. You are dressed differently and your colour is not
the same. Are you some one or other of the gods that live in heaven? If
so, be propitious t'me till I can make you due sacrifice and offerings
of wrought gold. Have mercy upon me."
And Ulysses said, "I am n'god, why should you take me for one? I am
your father, on whose account you grieve and suffer s'much at the
hands of lawless men."
As he spoke he kissed his son, and a tear fell from his cheek on t'the
ground, for he had restrained all tears till now. But Telemachus could
not yet believe that it was his father, and said:
"You are not my father, but some god is flattering me with vain hopes
that I may grieve the more hereafter; n'mortal man could of himself
contrive t'd'as you have been doing, and make yourself old and young
at a moment's notice, unless a god were with him. A second ag'you were
old and all in rags, and now you are like some god come down from
heaven."
Ulysses answered, "Telemachus, you ought not t'be s'immeasurably
astonished at my being really here. There is n'other Ulysses wh'will
come hereafter. Such as I am, it is I, wh'after long wandering and
much hardship have got home in the twentieth year t'my own country.
What you wonder at is the work of the redoubtable goddess Minerva, who
does with me whatever she will, for she can d'what she pleases. At one
moment she makes me like a beggar, and the next I am a young man with
good clothes on my back; it is an easy matter for the gods wh'live in
heaven t'make any man look either rich or poor."
As he spoke he sat down, and Telemachus threw his arms about his father
and wept. They were both s'much moved that they cried aloud like
eagles or vultures with crooked talons that have been robbed of their
half fledged young by peasants. Thus piteously did they weep, and the
sun would have gone down upon their mourning if Telemachus had not
suddenly said, "In what ship, my dear father, did your crew bring you
t'Ithaca? Of what nation did they declare themselves t'be—for you
cannot have come by land?"
"I will tell you the truth, my son," replied Ulysses. "It was the
Phaeacians wh'brought me here. They are great sailors, and are in the
habit of giving escorts t'any one wh'reaches their coasts. They took
me over the sea while I was fast asleep, and landed me in Ithaca, after
giving me many presents in bronze, gold, and raiment. These things by
heaven's mercy are lying concealed in a cave, and I am now come here on
the suggestion of Minerva that we may consult about killing our
enemies. First, therefore, give me a list of the suitors, with their
number, that I may learn who, and how many, they are. I can then turn
the matter over in my mind, and see whether we tw'can fight the whole
body of them ourselves, or whether we must find others t'help us."
T'this Telemachus answered, "Father, I have always heard of your
renown both in the field and in council, but the task you talk of is a
very great one: I am awed at the mere thought of it; tw'men cannot
stand against many and brave ones. There are not ten suitors only, nor
twice ten, but ten many times over; you shall learn their number at
once. There are fifty-tw'chosen youths from Dulichium, and they have
six servants; from Same there are twenty-four; twenty young Achaeans
from Zacynthus, and twelve from Ithaca itself, all of them well born.
They have with them a servant Medon, a bard, and tw'men wh'can carve
at table. If we face such numbers as this, you may have bitter cause to
rue your coming, and your revenge. See whether you cannot think of some
one wh'would be willing t'come and help us."
"Listen t'me," replied Ulysses, "and think whether Minerva and her
father Jove may seem sufficient, or whether I am t'try and find some
one else as well."
"Those whom you have named," answered Telemachus, "are a couple of good
allies, for though they dwell high up among the clouds they have power
over both gods and men."
"These two," continued Ulysses, "will not keep long out of the fray,
when the suitors and we join fight in my house. Now, therefore, return
home early to-morrow morning, and g'about among the suitors as before.
Later on the swineherd will bring me t'the city disguised as a
miserable old beggar. If you see them ill treating me, steel your heart
against my sufferings; even though they drag me feet foremost out of
the house, or throw things at me, look on and d'nothing beyond gently
trying t'make them behave more reasonably; but they will not listen to
you, for the day of their reckoning is at hand. Furthermore I say, and
lay my saying t'your heart; when Minerva shall put it in my mind, I
will nod my head t'you, and on seeing me d'this you must collect all
the armour that is in the house and hide it in the strong store room.
Make some excuse when the suitors ask you why you are removing it; say
that you have taken it t'be out of the way of the smoke, inasmuch as
it is n'longer what it was when Ulysses went away, but has become
soiled and begrimed with soot. Add t'this more particularly that you
are afraid Jove may set them on t'quarrel over their wine, and that
they may d'each other some harm which may disgrace both banquet and
wooing, for the sight of arms sometimes tempts people t'use them. But
leave a sword and a spear apiece for yourself and me, and a couple of
oxhide shields s'that we can snatch them up at any moment; Jove and
Minerva will then soon quiet these people. There is als'another
matter; if you are indeed my son and my blood runs in your veins, let
n'one know that Ulysses is within the house—neither Laertes, nor yet
the swineherd, nor any of the servants, nor even Penelope herself. Let
you and me exploit the women alone, and let us als'make trial of some
other of the men servants, t'see wh'is on our side and whose hand is
against us."
"Father," replied Telemachus, "you will come t'know me by and by, and
when you d'you will find that I can keep your counsel. I d'not think,
however, the plan you propose will turn out well for either of us.
Think it over. It will take us a long time t'g'the round of the farms
and exploit the men, and all the time the suitors will be wasting your
estate with impunity and without compunction. Prove the women by all
means, t'see wh'are disloyal and wh'guiltless, but I am not in
favour of going round and trying the men. We can attend t'that later
on, if you really have some sign from Jove that he will support you."
Thus did they converse, and meanwhile the ship which had brought
Telemachus and his crew from Pylos had reached the town of Ithaca. When
they had come inside the harbour they drew the ship on t'the land;
their servants came and took their armour from them, and they left all
the presents at the house of Clytius. Then they sent a servant t'tell
Penelope that Telemachus had gone int'the country, but had sent the
ship t'the town t'prevent her from being alarmed and made unhappy.
This servant and Eumaeus happened t'meet when they were both on the
same errand of going t'tell Penelope. When they reached the House, the
servant stood up and said t'the queen in the presence of the waiting
women, "Your son, Madam, is now returned from Pylos"; but Eumaeus went
close up t'Penelope, and said privately all that her son had bidden
him tell her. When he had given his message he left the house with its

scenes.title: Suitors Plot Against Telemachus
scenes.summary: The suitors discuss their plans against Telemachus after his return.
scenes.explanation: Change of location to the suitors' assembly.
scenes.text:
outbuildings and went back t'his pigs again.
The suitors were surprised and angry at what had happened, s'they went
outside the great wall that ran round the outer court, and held a
council near the main entrance. Eurymachus, son of Polybus, was the
first t'speak.
"My friends," said he, "this voyage of Telemachus's is a very serious
matter; we had made sure that it would come t'nothing. Now, however,
let us draw a ship int'the water, and get a crew together t'send
after the others and tell them t'come back as fast as they can."
He had hardly done speaking when Amphinomus turned in his place and saw
the ship inside the harbour, with the crew lowering her sails, and
putting by their oars; s'he laughed, and said t'the others, "We need
not send them any message, for they are here. Some god must have told
them, or else they saw the ship g'by, and could not overtake her."
On this they rose and went t'the water side. The crew then drew the
ship on shore; their servants took their armour from them, and they
went up in a body t'the place of assembly, but they would not let any
one old or young sit along with them, and Antinous, son of Eupeithes,
spoke first.
"Good heavens," said he, "see how the gods have saved this man from
destruction. We kept a succession of scouts upon the headlands all day
long, and when the sun was down we never went on shore t'sleep, but
waited in the ship all night till morning in the hope of capturing and
killing him; but some god has conveyed him home in spite of us. Let us
consider how we can make an end of him. He must not escape us; our
affair is never likely t'come off while he is alive, for he is very
shrewd, and public feeling is by n'means all on our side. We must make
haste before he can call the Achaeans in assembly; he will lose n'time
in doing so, for he will be furious with us, and will tell all the
world how we plotted t'kill him, but failed t'take him. The people
will not like this when they come t'know of it; we must see that they
d'us n'hurt, nor drive us from our own country int'exile. Let us try
and lay hold of him either on his farm away from the town, or on the
road hither. Then we can divide up his property amongst us, and let his
mother and the man wh'marries her have the house. If this does not
please you, and you wish Telemachus t'live on and hold his father's
property, then we must not gather here and eat up his goods in this
way, but must make our offers t'Penelope each from his own house, and
she can marry the man wh'will give the most for her, and whose lot it
is t'win her."
They all held their peace until Amphinomus rose t'speak. He was the
son of Nisus, wh'was son t'king Aretias, and he was foremost among
all the suitors from the wheat-growing and well grassed island of
Dulichium; his conversation, moreover, was more agreeable t'Penelope
than that of any of the other suitors, for he was a man of good natural
disposition. "My friends," said he, speaking t'them plainly and in all
honestly, "I am not in favour of killing Telemachus. It is a heinous
thing t'kill one wh'is of noble blood. Let us first take counsel of
the gods, and if the oracles of Jove advise it, I will both help to
kill him myself, and will urge everyone else t'd'so; but if they
dissuade us, I would have you hold your hands."
Thus did he speak, and his words pleased them well, s'they rose
forthwith and went t'the house of Ulysses, where they took their
accustomed seats.
Then Penelope resolved that she would show herself t'the suitors. She
knew of the plot against Telemachus, for the servant Medon had
overheard their counsels and had told her; she went down therefore to
the court attended by her maidens, and when she reached the suitors she
stood by one of the bearing-posts supporting the roof of the cloister
holding a veil before her face, and rebuked Antinous saying:
"Antinous, insolent and wicked schemer, they say you are the best
speaker and counsellor of any man your own age in Ithaca, but you are
nothing of the kind. Madman, why should you try t'compass the death of
Telemachus, and take n'heed of suppliants, whose witness is Jove
himself? It is not right for you t'plot thus against one another. Do
you not remember how your father fled t'this house in fear of the
people, wh'were enraged against him for having gone with some Taphian
pirates and plundered the Thesprotians wh'were at peace with us? They
wanted t'tear him in pieces and eat up everything he had, but Ulysses
stayed their hands although they were infuriated, and now you devour
his property without paying for it, and break my heart by wooing his
wife and trying t'kill his son. Leave off doing so, and stop the
others also."
T'this Eurymachus son of Polybus answered, "Take heart, Queen Penelope
daughter of Icarius, and d'not trouble yourself about these matters.
The man is not yet born, nor never will be, wh'shall lay hands upon
your son Telemachus, while I yet live t'look upon the face of the
earth. I say—and it shall surely be—that my spear shall be reddened
with his blood; for many a time has Ulysses taken me on his knees, held
wine up t'my lips t'drink, and put pieces of meat int'my hands.
Therefore Telemachus is much the dearest friend I have, and has nothing
t'fear from the hands of us suitors. Of course, if death comes t'him
from the gods, he cannot escape it." He said this t'quiet her, but in
reality he was plotting against Telemachus.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The theme of divine intervention is crucial as it influences the actions of the suitors and Telemachus.
characters.quote: some god must have told them, or else they saw the ship g'by, and could not overtake her.

characters.name: Trust And Betrayal
characters.importance_exp: Betrayal and deceit are central to the plot as the suitors conspire against Telemachus.
characters.quote: Let us consider how we can make an end of him.

characters.importance_exp: The theme of nobility and honor is highlighted through the discussions about Telemachus's lineage and the moral implications of killing him.
characters.quote: I am not in favour of killing Telemachus. It is a heinous thing t'kill one wh'is of noble blood.

characters.importance_exp: The struggle for power and control over Ithaca is a driving force in the actions of the suitors.
characters.quote: we must see that they d'us n'hurt, nor drive us from our own country int'exile.

characters.name: Maternal Concern
characters.importance_exp: Penelope's protective instincts for her son are a significant emotional anchor in the scene.
characters.quote: Madman, why should you try t'compass the death of Telemachus, and take n'heed of suppliants, whose witness is Jove himself?

scenes.title: Penelope Confronts Suitors
scenes.summary: Penelope rebukes the suitors for plotting against her son.
scenes.explanation: Change of location back to Penelope's presence.
scenes.text:
Then Penelope went upstairs again and mourned her husband till Minerva
shed sleep over her eyes. In the evening Eumaeus got back t'Ulysses
and his son, wh'had just sacrificed a young pig of a year old and were
helping one another t'get supper ready; Minerva therefore came up to
Ulysses, turned him int'an old man with a stroke of her wand, and clad
him in his old clothes again, for fear that the swineherd might
recognise him and not keep the secret, but g'and tell Penelope.
Telemachus was the first t'speak. "S'you have got back, Eumaeus,"

characters.name: Grief And Mourning
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Penelope's actions in the scene.
characters.quote: Then Penelope went upstairs again and mourned her husband till Minerva shed sleep over her eyes.

characters.name: Transformation
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' transformation is crucial for the plot's progression.
characters.quote: Minerva therefore came up to Ulysses, turned him int'an old man with a stroke of her wand, and clad him in his old clothes again.

scenes.title: Eumaeus Returns
scenes.summary: Eumaeus returns to Ulysses and Telemachus with news from the town.
scenes.explanation: Change of location back to the hut.
scenes.text:
said he. "What is the news of the town? Have the suitors returned, or
are they still waiting over yonder, t'take me on my way home?"
"I did not think of asking about that," replied Eumaeus, "when I was in
the town. I thought I would give my message and come back as soon as I
could. I met a man sent by those wh'had gone with you t'Pylos, and he
was the first t'tell the news t'your mother, but I can say what I saw
with my own eyes; I had just got on t'the crest of the hill of Mercury
above the town when I saw a ship coming int'harbour with a number of
men in her. They had many shields and spears, and I thought it was the
suitors, but I cannot be sure."
On hearing this Telemachus smiled t'his father, but s'that Eumaeus
could not see him.
Then, when they had finished their work and the meal was ready, they
ate it, and every man had his full share s'that all were satisfied. As
soon as they had had enough t'eat and drink, they laid down t'rest
and enjoyed the boon of sleep.

characters.name: Return Home
characters.importance_exp: The theme of returning home is central to the characters' motivations.
characters.quote: What is the news of the town? Have the suitors returned, or are they still waiting over yonder, t'take me on my way home?

characters.name: Community And Sharing
characters.importance_exp: The act of sharing a meal signifies community and camaraderie among the characters.
characters.quote: every man had his full share s'that all were satisfied.

characters.name: Uncertainty
characters.importance_exp: The uncertainty about the suitors' return adds tension to the scene.
characters.quote: I thought it was the suitors, but I cannot be sure.

scenes.title: Telemachus and Penelope Meet
scenes.summary: Telemachus returns home to meet his mother, Penelope.
scenes.text:
TELEMACHUS AND HIS MOTHER MEET—ULYSSES AND EUMAEUS COME DOWN T'THE
TOWN, AND ULYSSES IS INSULTED BY MELANTHIUS—HE IS RECOGNISED BY THE DOG
ARGOS—HE IS INSULTED AND PRESENTLY STRUCK BY ANTINOUS WITH A
STOOL—PENELOPE DESIRES THAT HE SHALL BE SENT T'HER.
When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, Telemachus
bound on his sandals and took a strong spear that suited his hands, for
he wanted t'g'int'the city. "Old friend," said he t'the swineherd,
"I will now g't'the town and show myself t'my mother, for she will
never leave off grieving till she has seen me. As for this unfortunate
stranger, take him t'the town and let him beg there of any one who
will give him a drink and a piece of bread. I have trouble enough of my
own, and cannot be burdened with other people. If this makes him angry
s'much the worse for him, but I like t'say what I mean."
Then Ulysses said, "Sir, I d'not want t'stay here; a beggar can
always d'better in town than country, for any one wh'likes can give
him something. I am to'old t'care about remaining here at the beck
and call of a master. Therefore let this man d'as you have just told
him, and take me t'the town as soon as I have had a warm by the fire,
and the day has got a little heat in it. My clothes are wretchedly
thin, and this frosty morning I shall be perished with cold, for you
say the city is some way off."
On this Telemachus strode off through the yards, brooding his revenge
upon the suitors. When he reached home he stood his spear against a
bearing-post of the cloister, crossed the stone floor of the cloister
itself, and went inside.
Nurse Euryclea saw him long before any one else did. She was putting
the fleeces on t'the seats, and she burst out crying as she ran up to
him; all the other maids came up too, and covered his head and
shoulders with their kisses. Penelope came out of her room looking like
Diana or Venus, and wept as she flung her arms about her son. She
kissed his forehead and both his beautiful eyes, "Light of my eyes,"
she cried as she spoke fondly t'him, "s'you are come home again; I
made sure I was never going t'see you any more. T'think of your
having gone off t'Pylos without saying anything about it or obtaining
my consent. But come, tell me what you saw."
"D'not scold me, mother," answered Telemachus, "nor vex me, seeing
what a narrow escape I have had, but wash your face, change your dress,
g'upstairs with your maids, and promise full and sufficient hecatombs
t'all the gods if Jove will only grant us our revenge upon the
suitors. I must now g't'the place of assembly t'invite a stranger
wh'has come back with me from Pylos. I sent him on with my crew, and
told Piraeus t'take him home and look after him till I could come for
him myself."
She heeded her son's words, washed her face, changed her dress, and
vowed full and sufficient hecatombs t'all the gods if they would only
vouchsafe her revenge upon the suitors.

characters.name: Maternal Concern
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the emotional reunion between Telemachus and Penelope.
characters.quote: "Light of my eyes," she cried as she spoke fondly t'him, "s'you are come home again; I made sure I was never going t'see you any more."

characters.name: Vengeance
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus expresses a strong desire for revenge against the suitors, which drives his actions.
characters.quote: "...promise full and sufficient hecatombs t'all the gods if Jove will only grant us our revenge upon the suitors."

characters.name: Struggle Against Adversity
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' condition as a beggar highlights the struggles faced by characters in this scene.
characters.quote: "I am to'old t'care about remaining here at the beck and call of a master."

scenes.title: Telemachus and Eumaeus
scenes.summary: Telemachus discusses plans with Eumaeus before heading to the town.
scenes.text:
Telemachus went through, and out of, the cloisters spear in hand—not
alone, for his tw'fleet dogs went with him. Minerva endowed him with a
presence of such divine comeliness that all marvelled at him as he went
by, and the suitors gathered round him with fair words in their mouths
and malice in their hearts; but he avoided them, and went t'sit with
Mentor, Antiphus, and Halitherses, old friends of his father's house,
and they made him tell them all that had happened t'him. Then Piraeus
came up with Theoclymenus, whom he had escorted through the town t'the
place of assembly, whereon Telemachus at once joined them. Piraeus was
first t'speak: "Telemachus," said he, "I wish you would send some of
your women t'my house t'take away the presents Menelaus gave you."
"We d'not know, Piraeus," answered Telemachus, "what may happen. If
the suitors kill me in my own house and divide my property among them,
I would rather you had the presents than that any of those people
should get hold of them. If on the other hand I managed t'kill them, I
shall be much obliged if you will kindly bring me my presents."
With these words he took Theoclymenus t'his own house. When they got
there they laid their cloaks on the benches and seats, went int'the
baths, and washed themselves. When the maids had washed and anointed
them, and had given them cloaks and shirts, they took their seats at

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus's divine comeliness is central to his character and the scene.
characters.quote: Minerva endowed him with a presence of such divine comeliness that all marvelled at him as he went by.

characters.name: Conflict And Rivalry
characters.importance_exp: The threat from the suitors creates tension in the scene.
characters.quote: If the suitors kill me in my own house and divide my property among them, I would rather you had the presents than that any of those people should get hold of them.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus's interactions with his friends highlight loyalty and support.
characters.quote: he avoided them, and went t'sit with Mentor, Antiphus, and Halitherses, old friends of his father's house.

scenes.title: Telemachus and the Suitors
scenes.summary: Telemachus interacts with the suitors and discusses his journey.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the place of assembly.
scenes.text:
table. A maid servant then brought them water in a beautiful golden
ewer, and poured it int'a silver basin for them t'wash their hands;
and she drew a clean table beside them. An upper servant brought them
bread and offered them many good things of what there was in the house.
Opposite them sat Penelope, reclining on a couch by one of the
bearing-posts of the cloister, and spinning. Then they laid their hands
on the good things that were before them, and as soon as they had had
enough t'eat and drink Penelope said:
"Telemachus, I shall g'upstairs and lie down on that sad couch, which
I have not ceased t'water with my tears, from the day Ulysses set out
for Troy with the sons of Atreus. You failed, however, t'make it clear
t'me before the suitors came back t'the house, whether or n'you had
been able t'hear anything about the return of your father."
"I will tell you then truth," replied her son. "We went t'Pylos and
saw Nestor, wh'took me t'his house and treated me as hospitably as
though I were a son of his own wh'had just returned after a long
absence; s'als'did his sons; but he said he had not heard a word from
any human being about Ulysses, whether he was alive or dead. He sent
me, therefore, with a chariot and horses t'Menelaus. There I saw
Helen, for whose sake s'many, both Argives and Trojans, were in
heaven's wisdom doomed t'suffer. Menelaus asked me what it was that
had brought me t'Lacedaemon, and I told him the whole truth, whereon
he said, 'So, then, these cowards would usurp a brave man's bed? A hind
might as well lay her new-born young in the lair of a lion, and then go
off t'feed in the forest or in some grassy dell. The lion, when he
comes back t'his lair, will make short work with the pair of them, and
s'will Ulysses with these suitors. By father Jove, Minerva, and
Apollo, if Ulysses is still the man that he was when he wrestled with
Philomeleides in Lesbos, and threw him s'heavily that all the Greeks
cheered him—if he is still such, and were t'come near these suitors,
they would have a short shrift and a sorry wedding. As regards your
question, however, I will not prevaricate nor deceive you, but what the
old man of the sea told me, s'much will I tell you in full. He said he
could see Ulysses on an island sorrowing bitterly in the house of the
nymph Calypso, wh'was keeping him prisoner, and he could not reach his
home, for he had n'ships nor sailors t'take him over the sea.' This
was what Menelaus told me, and when I had heard his story I came away;
the gods then gave me a fair wind and soon brought me safe home again."
With these words he moved the heart of Penelope. Then Theoclymenus said
t'her:
"Madam, wife of Ulysses, Telemachus does not understand these things;
listen therefore t'me, for I can divine them surely, and will hide

characters.name: Longing For Ulysses
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to Penelope's emotional state.
characters.quote: I have not ceased t'water with my tears, from the day Ulysses set out for Troy with the sons of Atreus.

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Hospitality is shown but is not the main focus of the scene.
characters.quote: Nestor, wh'took me t'his house and treated me as hospitably as though I were a son of his own wh'had just returned after a long absence; s'als'did his sons;

characters.name: Hope For Return
characters.importance_exp: The hope for Ulysses' return drives the narrative forward.
characters.quote: if Ulysses is still the man that he was when he wrestled with Philomeleides in Lesbos, and threw him s'heavily that all the Greeks cheered him—if he is still such, and were t'come near these suitors, they would have a short shrift and a sorry wedding.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The mention of gods hints at their influence in the characters' lives.
characters.quote: the gods then gave me a fair wind and soon brought me safe home again.

scenes.title: Ulysses and Eumaeus 2
scenes.summary: Ulysses and Eumaeus prepare to go to the town together.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the road to town.
scenes.text:
nothing from you. May Jove the king of heaven be my witness, and the
rites of hospitality, with that hearth of Ulysses t'which I now come,
that Ulysses himself is even now in Ithaca, and, either going about the
country or staying in one place, is enquiring int'all these evil deeds
and preparing a day of reckoning for the suitors. I saw an omen when I
was on the ship which meant this, and I told Telemachus about it."
"May it be even so," answered Penelope; "if your words come true, you
shall have such gifts and such good will from me that all wh'see you
shall congratulate you."
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile the suitors were throwing discs, or
aiming with spears at a mark on the levelled ground in front of the
house, and behaving with all their old insolence. But when it was now
time for dinner, and the flock of sheep and goats had come int'the
town from all the country round, 140 with their shepherds as usual,
then Medon, wh'was their favourite servant, and wh'waited upon them
at table, said, "Now then, my young masters, you have had enough sport,
s'come inside that we may get dinner ready. Dinner is not a bad thing,
at dinner time."
They left their sports as he told them, and when they were within the
house, they laid their cloaks on the benches and seats inside, and then
sacrificed some sheep, goats, pigs, and a heifer, all of them fat and
well grown.141 Thus they made ready for their meal. In the meantime
Ulysses and the swineherd were about starting for the town, and the
swineherd said, "Stranger, I suppose you still want t'g't'town
to-day, as my master said you were t'do; for my own part I should have
liked you t'stay here as a station hand, but I must d'as my master
tells me, or he will scold me later on, and a scolding from one's
master is a very serious thing. Let us then be off, for it is now broad
day; it will be night again directly and then you will find it
colder."142
"I know, and understand you," replied Ulysses; "you need say n'more.
Let us be going, but if you have a stick ready cut, let me have it to
walk with, for you say the road is a very rough one."
As he spoke he threw his shabby old tattered wallet over his shoulders,
by the cord from which it hung, and Eumaeus gave him a stick t'his
liking. The tw'then started, leaving the station in charge of the dogs
and herdsmen wh'remained behind; the swineherd led the way and his
master followed after, looking like some broken down old tramp as he

characters.name: Hospitality
characters.importance_exp: Central to the interactions in the scene.
characters.quote: May Jove the king of heaven be my witness, and the rites of hospitality, with that hearth of Ulysses t'which I now come, that Ulysses himself is even now in Ithaca...

characters.name: Insolence
characters.importance_exp: Reflects the behavior of the suitors.
characters.quote: ...the suitors were throwing discs, or aiming with spears at a mark on the levelled ground in front of the house, and behaving with all their old insolence.

characters.name: Friendship And Loyalty
characters.importance_exp: Demonstrated by the swineherd's actions and words.
characters.quote: I should have liked you t'stay here as a station hand, but I must d'as my master tells me...

scenes.title: Ulysses Meets Melanthius
scenes.summary: Ulysses encounters Melanthius, who insults him.
scenes.text:
leaned upon his staff, and his clothes were all in rags. When they had
got over the rough steep ground and were nearing the city, they reached
the fountain from which the citizens drew their water. This had been
made by Ithacus, Neritus, and Polyctor. There was a grove of
water-loving poplars planted in a circle all round it, and the clear
cold water came down t'it from a rock high up,143 while above the
fountain there was an altar t'the nymphs, at which all wayfarers used
t'sacrifice. Here Melanthius son of Dolius overtook them as he was
driving down some goats, the best in his flock, for the suitors'
dinner, and there were tw'shepherds with him. When he saw Eumaeus and
Ulysses he reviled them with outrageous and unseemly language, which
made Ulysses very angry.
"There you go," cried he, "and a precious pair you are. See how heaven
brings birds of the same feather t'one another. Where, pray, master
swineherd, are you taking this poor miserable object? It would make any
one sick t'see such a creature at table. A fellow like this never won
a prize for anything in his life, but will g'about rubbing his
shoulders against every man's door post, and begging, not for swords
and cauldrons144 like a man, but only for a few scraps not worth
begging for. If you would give him t'me for a hand on my station, he
might d't'clean out the folds, or bring a bit of sweet feed t'the
kids, and he could fatten his thighs as much as he pleased on whey; but
he has taken t'bad ways and will not g'about any kind of work; he
will d'nothing but beg victuals all the town over, t'feed his
insatiable belly. I say, therefore—and it shall surely be—if he goes
near Ulysses' house he will get his head broken by the stools they will
fling at him, till they turn him out."
On this, as he passed, he gave Ulysses a kick on the hip out of pure
wantonness, but Ulysses stood firm, and did not budge from the path.
For a moment he doubted whether or n't'fly at Melanthius and kill him
with his staff, or fling him t'the ground and beat his brains out; he
resolved, however, t'endure it and keep himself in check, but the
swineherd looked straight at Melanthius and rebuked him, lifting up his
hands and praying t'heaven as he did so.
"Fountain nymphs," he cried, "children of Jove, if ever Ulysses burned
you thigh bones covered with fat whether of lambs or kids, grant my
prayer that heaven may send him home. He would soon put an end t'the
swaggering threats with which such men as you g'about insulting
people—gadding all over the town while your flocks are going t'ruin
through bad shepherding."
Then Melanthius the goatherd answered, "You ill conditioned cur, what
are you talking about? Some day or other I will put you on board ship
and take you t'a foreign country, where I can sell you and pocket the
money you will fetch. I wish I were as sure that Apoll'would strike
Telemachus dead this very day, or that the suitors would kill him, as I
am that Ulysses will never come home again."
With this he left them t'come on at their leisure, while he went
quickly forward and soon reached the house of his master. When he got

characters.name: Social Class Conflict
characters.importance_exp: The interaction highlights the divide between social classes.
characters.quote: There you go, cried he, and a precious pair you are.

characters.name: Endurance And Resilience
characters.importance_exp: Ulysses' restraint in the face of provocation shows his strength.
characters.quote: Ulysses stood firm, and did not budge from the path.

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The swineherd's prayer to the nymphs indicates reliance on divine help.
characters.quote: No quote available
characters.fake_quote: This theme embodies hope, as it expresses a longing for divine assistance in reuniting with a loved one.

scenes.title: Ulysses at the Suitors' House
scenes.summary: Ulysses arrives at the suitors' house and begins to beg.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the suitors' house.
scenes.text:
there he went in and took his seat among the suitors opposite
Eurymachus, wh'liked him better than any of the others. The servants
brought him a portion of meat, and an upper woman servant set bread
before him that he might eat. Presently Ulysses and the swineherd came
up t'the house and stood by it, amid a sound of music, for Phemius was
just beginning t'sing t'the suitors. Then Ulysses took hold of the
swineherd's hand, and said:
"Eumaeus, this house of Ulysses is a very fine place. N'matter how far
you go, you will find few like it. One building keeps following on
after another. The outer court has a wall with battlements all round
it; the doors are double folding, and of good workmanship; it would be
a hard matter t'take it by force of arms. I perceive, too, that there
are many people banqueting within it, for there is a smell of roast
meat, and I hear a sound of music, which the gods have made t'g'along
with feasting."
Then Eumaeus said, "You have perceived aright, as indeed you generally
do; but let us think what will be our best course. Will you g'inside
first and join the suitors, leaving me here behind you, or will you
wait here and let me g'in first? But d'not wait long, or some one may
see you loitering about outside, and throw something at you. Consider
this matter I pray you."
And Ulysses answered, "I understand and heed. G'in first and leave me
here where I am. I am quite used t'being beaten and having things
thrown at me. I have been s'much buffeted about in war and by sea that
I am case-hardened, and this to'may g'with the rest. But a man cannot
hide away the cravings of a hungry belly; this is an enemy which gives
much trouble t'all men; it is because of this that ships are fitted
out t'sail the seas, and t'make war upon other people."
As they were thus talking, a dog that had been lying asleep raised his
head and pricked up his ears. This was Argos, whom Ulysses had bred
before setting out for Troy, but he had never had any work out of him.
In the old days he used t'be taken out by the young men when they went
hunting wild goats, or deer, or hares, but now that his master was gone
he was lying neglected on the heaps of mule and cow dung that lay in
front of the stable doors till the men should come and draw it away to
manure the great close; and he was full of fleas. As soon as he saw
Ulysses standing there, he dropped his ears and wagged his tail, but he
could not get close up t'his master. When Ulysses saw the dog on the
other side of the yard, he dashed a tear from his eyes without Eumaeus
seeing it, and said:
"Eumaeus, what a noble hound that is over yonder on the manure heap:
his build is splendid; is he as fine a fellow as he looks, or is he
only one of those dogs that come begging about a table, and are kept
merely for show?"
"This hound," answered Eumaeus, "belonged t'him wh'has died in a far
country. If he were what he was when Ulysses left for Troy, he would
soon show you what he could do. There was not a wild beast in the
forest that could get away from him when he was once on its tracks. But
now he has fallen on evil times, for his master is dead and gone, and
the women take n'care of him. Servants never d'their work when their
master's hand is n'longer over them, for Jove takes half the goodness
out of a man when he makes a slave of him."
As he spoke he went inside the buildings t'the cloister where the
suitors were, but Argos died as soon as he had recognised his master.
Telemachus saw Eumaeus long before any one else did, and beckoned him
t'come and sit beside him; s'he looked about and saw a seat lying
near where the carver sat serving out their portions t'the suitors; he
picked it up, brought it t'Telemachus's table, and sat down opposite
him. Then the servant brought him his portion, and gave him bread from
the bread-basket.
Immediately afterwards Ulysses came inside, looking like a poor
miserable old beggar, leaning on his staff and with his clothes all in
rags. He sat down upon the threshold of ash-wood just inside the doors
leading from the outer t'the inner court, and against a bearing-post
of cypress-wood which the carpenter had skilfully planed, and had made
t'join truly with rule and line. Telemachus took a whole loaf from the
bread-basket, with as much meat as he could hold in his tw'hands, and
said t'Eumaeus, "Take this t'the stranger, and tell him t'g'the
round of the suitors, and beg from them; a beggar must not be
shamefaced."
S'Eumaeus went up t'him and said, "Stranger, Telemachus sends you
this, and says you are t'g'the round of the suitors begging, for
beggars must not be shamefaced."
Ulysses answered, "May King Jove grant all happiness t'Telemachus, and
fulfil the desire of his heart."
Then with both hands he took what Telemachus had sent him, and laid it
on the dirty old wallet at his feet. He went on eating it while the
bard was singing, and had just finished his dinner as he left off. The
suitors applauded the bard, whereon Minerva went up t'Ulysses and
prompted him t'beg pieces of bread from each one of the suitors, that
he might see what kind of people they were, and tell the good from the
bad; but come what might she was not going t'save a single one of
them. Ulysses, therefore, went on his round, going from left t'right,
and stretched out his hands t'beg as though he were a real beggar.

scenes.title: Penelope's Concern
scenes.summary: Penelope expresses her concerns about the suitors and the beggar.
scenes.text:
Some of them pitied him, and were curious about him, asking one another
wh'he was and where he came from; whereon the goatherd Melanthius
said, "Suitors of my noble mistress, I can tell you something about
him, for I have seen him before. The swineherd brought him here, but I
know nothing about the man himself, nor where he comes from."
On this Antinous began t'abuse the swineherd. "You precious idiot," he
cried, "what have you brought this man t'town for? Have we not tramps
and beggars enough already t'pester us as we sit at meat? D'you think
it a small thing that such people gather here t'waste your master's
property—and must you needs bring this man as well?"
And Eumaeus answered, "Antinous, your birth is good but your words
evil. It was n'doing of mine that he came here. Wh'is likely to
invite a stranger from a foreign country, unless it be one of those who
can d'public service as a seer, a healer of hurts, a carpenter, or a
bard wh'can charm us with his singing? Such men are welcome all the
world over, but n'one is likely t'ask a beggar wh'will only worry
him. You are always harder on Ulysses' servants than any of the other
suitors are, and above all on me, but I d'not care s'long as
Telemachus and Penelope are alive and here."
But Telemachus said, "Hush, d'not answer him; Antinous has the
bitterest tongue of all the suitors, and he makes the others worse."
Then turning t'Antinous he said, "Antinous, you take as much care of
my interests as though I were your son. Why should you want t'see this
stranger turned out of the house? Heaven forbid; take something and
give it him yourself; I d'not grudge it; I bid you take it. Never mind
my mother, nor any of the other servants in the house; but I know you
will not d'what I say, for you are more fond of eating things yourself
than of giving them t'other people."
"What d'you mean, Telemachus," replied Antinous, "by this swaggering
talk? If all the suitors were t'give him as much as I will, he would
not come here again for another three months."
As he spoke he drew the stool on which he rested his dainty feet from
under the table, and made as though he would throw it at Ulysses, but
the other suitors all gave him something, and filled his wallet with
bread and meat; he was about, therefore, t'g'back t'the threshold
and eat what the suitors had given him, but he first went up to
Antinous and said:
"Sir, give me something; you are not, surely, the poorest man here; you
seem t'be a chief, foremost among them all; therefore you should be
the better giver, and I will tell far and wide of your bounty. I too
was a rich man once, and had a fine house of my own; in those days I
gave t'many a tramp such as I now am, n'matter wh'he might be nor
what he wanted. I had any number of servants, and all the other things
which people have wh'live well and are accounted wealthy, but it
pleased Jove t'take all away from me. He sent me with a band of roving
robbers t'Egypt; it was a long voyage and I was undone by it. I
stationed my ships in the river Aegyptus, and bade my men stay by them
and keep guard over them, while I sent out scouts t'reconnoitre from
every point of vantage.
"But the men disobeyed my orders, took t'their own devices, and
ravaged the land of the Egyptians, killing the men, and taking their
wives and children captives. The alarm was soon carried t'the city,
and when they heard the war-cry, the people came out at daybreak till
the plain was filled with soldiers horse and foot, and with the gleam
of armour. Then Jove spread panic among my men, and they would no
longer face the enemy, for they found themselves surrounded. The
Egyptians killed many of us, and took the rest alive t'd'forced
labour for them; as for myself, they gave me t'a friend wh'met them,
t'take t'Cyprus, Dmetor by name, son of Iasus, wh'was a great man in
Cyprus. Thence I am come hither in a state of great misery."
Then Antinous said, "What god can have sent such a pestilence t'plague
us during our dinner? Get out, int'the open part of the court,145 or I
will give you Egypt and Cyprus over again for your insolence and
importunity; you have begged of all the others, and they have given you
lavishly, for they have abundance round them, and it is easy t'be free
with other people's property when there is plenty of it."
On this Ulysses began t'move off, and said, "Your looks, my fine sir,
are better than your breeding; if you were in your own house you would
not spare a poor man s'much as a pinch of salt, for though you are in
another man's, and surrounded with abundance, you cannot find it in you
t'give him even a piece of bread."
This made Antinous very angry, and he scowled at him saying, "You shall
pay for this before you get clear of the court." With these words he
threw a footstool at him, and hit him on the right shoulder blade near
the top of his back. Ulysses stood firm as a rock and the blow did not
even stagger him, but he shook his head in silence as he brooded on his
revenge. Then he went back t'the threshold and sat down there, laying
his well filled wallet at his feet.
"Listen t'me," he cried, "you suitors of Queen Penelope, that I may
speak even as I am minded. A man knows neither ache nor pain if he gets
hit while fighting for his money, or for his sheep or his cattle; and
even s'Antinous has hit me while in the service of my miserable belly,
which is always getting people int'trouble. Still, if the poor have
gods and avenging deities at all, I pray them that Antinous may come to
a bad end before his marriage."
"Sit where you are, and eat your victuals in silence, or be off
elsewhere," shouted Antinous. "If you say more I will have you dragged
hand and foot through the courts, and the servants shall flay you
alive."
The other suitors were much displeased at this, and one of the young
men said, "Antinous, you did ill in striking that poor wretch of a
tramp: it will be worse for you if he should turn out t'be some
god—and we know the gods g'about disguised in all sorts of ways as
people from foreign countries, and travel about the world t'see wh'do
amiss and wh'righteously."146
Thus said the suitors, but Antinous paid them n'heed. Meanwhile
Telemachus was furious about the blow that had been given t'his
father, and though n'tear fell from him, he shook his head in silence
and brooded on his revenge.
Now when Penelope heard that the beggar had been struck in the
banqueting-cloister, she said before her maids, "Would that Apollo
would s'strike you, Antinous," and her waiting woman Eurynome
answered, "If our prayers were answered not one of the suitors would
ever again see the sun rise." Then Penelope said, "Nurse,147 I hate
every single one of them, for they mean nothing but mischief, but I
hate Antinous like the darkness of death itself. A poor unfortunate
tramp has come begging about the house for sheer want. Every one else
has given him something t'put in his wallet, but Antinous has hit him
on the right shoulder-blade with a footstool."
Thus did she talk with her maids as she sat in her own room, and in the
meantime Ulysses was getting his dinner. Then she called for the
swineherd and said, "Eumaeus, g'and tell the stranger t'come here, I
want t'see him and ask him some questions. He seems t'have travelled
much, and he may have seen or heard something of my unhappy husband."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "If these Achaeans, Madam,
would only keep quiet, you would be charmed with the history of his
adventures. I had him three days and three nights with me in my hut,
which was the first place he reached after running away from his ship,
and he has not yet completed the story of his misfortunes. If he had
been the most heaven-taught minstrel in the whole world, on whose lips
all hearers hang entranced, I could not have been more charmed as I sat
in my hut and listened t'him. He says there is an old friendship
between his house and that of Ulysses, and that he comes from Crete
where the descendants of Minos live, after having been driven hither
and thither by every kind of misfortune; he als'declares that he has
heard of Ulysses as being alive and near at hand among the
Thesprotians, and that he is bringing great wealth home with him."
"Call him here, then," said Penelope, "that I to'may hear his story.
As for the suitors, let them take their pleasure indoors or out as they
will, for they have nothing t'fret about. Their corn and wine remain
unwasted in their houses with none but servants t'consume them, while
they keep hanging about our house day after day sacrificing our oxen,
sheep, and fat goats for their banquets, and never giving s'much as a
thought t'the quantity of wine they drink. N'estate can stand such
recklessness, for we have now n'Ulysses t'protect us. If he were to
come again, he and his son would soon have their revenge."
As she spoke Telemachus sneezed s'loudly that the whole house
resounded with it. Penelope laughed when she heard this, and said to
Eumaeus, "G'and call the stranger; did you not hear how my son sneezed
just as I was speaking? This can only mean that all the suitors are
going t'be killed, and that not one of them shall escape. Furthermore
I say, and lay my saying t'your heart: if I am satisfied that the
stranger is speaking the truth I shall give him a shirt and cloak of
good wear."

scenes.title: Eumaeus Returns to the Suitors
scenes.summary: Eumaeus returns to the suitors after speaking with Penelope.
scenes.explanation: Location changes back to the suitors' house.
scenes.text:
When Eumaeus heard this he went straight t'Ulysses and said, "Father
stranger, my mistress Penelope, mother of Telemachus, has sent for you;
she is in great grief, but she wishes t'hear anything you can tell her
about her husband, and if she is satisfied that you are speaking the
truth, she will give you a shirt and cloak, which are the very things
that you are most in want of. As for bread, you can get enough of that
t'fill your belly, by begging about the town, and letting those give
that will."
"I will tell Penelope," answered Ulysses, "nothing but what is strictly
true. I know all about her husband, and have been partner with him in
affliction, but I am afraid of passing through this crowd of cruel
suitors, for their pride and insolence reach heaven. Just now,
moreover, as I was going about the house without doing any harm, a man
gave me a blow that hurt me very much, but neither Telemachus nor any
one else defended me. Tell Penelope, therefore, t'be patient and wait
till sundown. Let her give me a seat close up t'the fire, for my
clothes are worn very thin—you know they are, for you have seen them
ever since I first asked you t'help me—she can then ask me about the
return of her husband."
The swineherd went back when he heard this, and Penelope said as she
saw him cross the threshold, "Why d'you not bring him here, Eumaeus?
Is he afraid that some one will ill-treat him, or is he shy of coming
inside the house at all? Beggars should not be shamefaced."
T'this you answered, 'swineherd Eumaeus, "The stranger is quite
reasonable. He is avoiding the suitors, and is only doing what any one
else would do. He asks you t'wait till sundown, and it will be much
better, madam, that you should have him all t'yourself, when you can
hear him and talk t'him as you will."
"The man is n'fool," answered Penelope, "it would very likely be as he
says, for there are n'such abominable people in the whole world as
these men are."
When she had done speaking Eumaeus went back t'the suitors, for he had
explained everything. Then he went up t'Telemachus and said in his ear
s'that none could overhear him, "My dear sir, I will now g'back to
the pigs, t'see after your property and my own business. You will look
t'what is going on here, but above all be careful t'keep out of
danger, for there are many wh'bear you ill will. May Jove bring them
t'a bad end before they d'us a mischief."
"Very well," replied Telemachus, "g'home when you have had your
dinner, and in the morning come here with the victims we are to
sacrifice for the day. Leave the rest t'heaven and me."
On this Eumaeus took his seat again, and when he had finished his
dinner he left the courts and the cloister with the men at table, and
went back t'his pigs. As for the suitors, they presently began to
amuse themselves with singing and dancing, for it was now getting on
towards evening.

scenes.title: The Fight with Irus
scenes.summary: Ulysses confronts Irus in the doorway.
scenes.text:
Now there came a certain common tramp wh'used t'g'begging all over
the city of Ithaca, and was notorious as an incorrigible glutton and
drunkard. This man had n'strength nor stay in him, but he was a great
hulking fellow t'look at; his real name, the one his mother gave him,
was Arnaeus, but the young men of the place called him Irus,148 because
he used t'run errands for any one wh'would send him. As soon as he
came he began t'insult Ulysses, and t'try and drive him out of his
own house.
"Be off, old man," he cried, "from the doorway, or you shall be dragged
out neck and heels. D'you not see that they are all giving me the
wink, and wanting me t'turn you out by force, only I d'not like t'do
so? Get up then, and g'of yourself, or we shall come t'blows."
Ulysses frowned on him and said, "My friend, I d'you n'manner of
harm; people give you a great deal, but I am not jealous. There is room
enough in this doorway for the pair of us, and you need not grudge me
things that are not yours t'give. You seem t'be just such another
tramp as myself, but perhaps the gods will give us better luck by and
by. D'not, however, talk to'much about fighting or you will incense
me, and old though I am, I shall cover your mouth and chest with blood.
I shall have more peace tomorrow if I do, for you will not come t'the
house of Ulysses any more."
Irus was very angry and answered, "You filthy glutton, you run on
trippingly like an old fish-fag. I have a good mind t'lay both hands
about you, and knock your teeth out of your head like s'many boar's
tusks. Get ready, therefore, and let these people here stand by and
look on. You will never be able t'fight one wh'is s'much younger
than yourself."
Thus roundly did they rate one another on the smooth pavement in front
of the doorway,149 and when Antinous saw what was going on he laughed
heartily and said t'the others, "This is the finest sport that you
ever saw; heaven never yet sent anything like it int'this house. The
stranger and Irus have quarreled and are going t'fight, let us set
them on t'd's'at once."
The suitors all came up laughing, and gathered round the tw'ragged
tramps. "Listen t'me," said Antinous, "there are some goats' paunches
down at the fire, which we have filled with blood and fat, and set
aside for supper; he wh'is victorious and proves himself t'be the
better man shall have his pick of the lot; he shall be free of our
table and we will not allow any other beggar about the house at all."
The others all agreed, but Ulysses, t'throw them off the scent, said,
"Sirs, an old man like myself, worn out with suffering, cannot hold his
own against a young one; but my irrepressible belly urges me on, though
I know it can only end in my getting a drubbing. You must swear,
however that none of you will give me a foul blow t'favour Irus and
secure him the victory."
They swore as he told them, and when they had completed their oath
Telemachus put in a word and said, "Stranger, if you have a mind to
settle with this fellow, you need not be afraid of any one here.
Whoever strikes you will have t'fight more than one. I am host, and
the other chiefs, Antinous and Eurymachus, both of them men of
understanding, are of the same mind as I am."
Every one assented, and Ulysses girded his old rags about his loins,
thus baring his stalwart thighs, his broad chest and shoulders, and his
mighty arms; but Minerva came up t'him and made his limbs even
stronger still. The suitors were beyond measure astonished, and one
would turn towards his neighbour saying, "The stranger has brought such
a thigh out of his old rags that there will soon be nothing left of
Irus."
Irus began t'be very uneasy as he heard them, but the servants girded
him by force, and brought him [int'the open part of the court] in such
a fright that his limbs were all of a tremble. Antinous scolded him and
said, "You swaggering bully, you ought never t'have been born at all
if you are afraid of such an old broken down creature as this tramp is.
I say, therefore—and it shall surely be—if he beats you and proves
himself the better man, I shall pack you off on board ship t'the
mainland and send you t'king Echetus, wh'kills every one that comes
near him. He will cut off your nose and ears, and draw out your
entrails for the dogs t'eat."
This frightened Irus still more, but they brought him int'the middle
of the court, and the tw'men raised their hands t'fight. Then Ulysses
considered whether he should let drive s'hard at him as t'make an end
of him then and there, or whether he should give him a lighter blow
that should only knock him down; in the end he deemed it best t'give
the lighter blow for fear the Achaeans should begin t'suspect wh'he
was. Then they began t'fight, and Irus hit Ulysses on the right
shoulder; but Ulysses gave Irus a blow on the neck under the ear that
broke in the bones of his skull, and the blood came gushing out of his
mouth; he fell groaning in the dust, gnashing his teeth and kicking on
the ground, but the suitors threw up their hands and nearly died of
laughter, as Ulysses caught hold of him by the foot and dragged him
int'the outer court as far as the gate-house. There he propped him up
against the wall and put his staff in his hands. "Sit here," said he,
"and keep the dogs and pigs off; you are a pitiful creature, and if you
try t'make yourself king of the beggars any more you shall fare still
worse."
Then he threw his dirty old wallet, all tattered and torn over his
shoulder with the cord by which it hung, and went back t'sit down upon
the threshold; but the suitors went within the cloisters, laughing and

scenes.title: Penelope's Decision
scenes.summary: Penelope decides to show herself to the suitors.
scenes.text:
Then Minerva put it int'the mind of Penelope t'show herself t'the
suitors, that she might make them still more enamoured of her, and win
still further honour from her son and husband. S'she feigned a mocking
laugh and said, "Eurynome, I have changed my mind, and have a fancy to
show myself t'the suitors although I detest them. I should like also
t'give my son a hint that he had better not have anything more t'do
with them. They speak fairly enough but they mean mischief."
"My dear child," answered Eurynome, "all that you have said is true, go
and tell your son about it, but first wash yourself and anoint your
face. D'not g'about with your cheeks all covered with tears; it is
not right that you should grieve s'incessantly; for Telemachus, whom
you always prayed that you might live t'see with a beard, is already
grown up."
"I know, Eurynome," replied Penelope, "that you mean well, but d'not
try and persuade me t'wash and t'anoint myself, for heaven robbed me
of all my beauty on the day my husband sailed; nevertheless, tell
Autonoe and Hippodamia that I want them. They must be with me when I am
in the cloister; I am not going among the men alone; it would not be
proper for me t'd'so."
On this the old woman150 went out of the room t'bid the maids g'to

scenes.title: Penelope's Appearance
scenes.summary: Penelope appears before the suitors, captivating them.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the suitors' area.
scenes.text:
"What an exquisitely delicious sleep I have been having," said she, as
she passed her hands over her face, "in spite of all my misery. I wish
Diana would let me die s'sweetly now at this very moment, that I might
n'longer waste in despair for the loss of my dear husband, who
possessed every kind of good quality and was the most distinguished man
among the Achaeans."
With these words she came down from her upper room, not alone but
attended by tw'of her maidens, and when she reached the suitors she
stood by one of the bearing-posts supporting the roof of the cloister,
holding a veil before her face, and with a staid maid servant on either
side of her. As they beheld her the suitors were s'overpowered and
became s'desperately enamoured of her, that each one prayed he might
win her for his own bed fellow.
"Telemachus," said she, addressing her son, "I fear you are n'longer

scenes.title: Telemachus Addresses the Suitors
scenes.summary: Telemachus reprimands the suitors for their behavior.
scenes.text:
"I am not surprised, my dear mother, at your displeasure," replied
Telemachus, "I understand all about it and know when things are not as
they should be, which I could not d'when I was younger; I cannot,
however, behave with perfect propriety at all times. First one and then
another of these wicked people here keeps driving me out of my mind,
and I have n'one t'stand by me. After all, however, this fight
between Irus and the stranger did not turn out as the suitors meant it
t'do, for the stranger got the best of it. I wish Father Jove,
Minerva, and Apoll'would break the neck of every one of these wooers
of yours, some inside the house and some out; and I wish they might all
be as limp as Irus is over yonder in the gate of the outer court. See
how he nods his head like a drunken man; he has had such a thrashing
that he cannot stand on his feet nor get back t'his home, wherever
that may be, for he has n'strength left in him."
Thus did they converse. Eurymachus then came up and said, "Queen
Penelope, daughter of Icarius, if all the Achaeans in Iasian Argos
could see you at this moment, you would have still more suitors in your
house by tomorrow morning, for you are the most admirable woman in the
whole world both as regards personal beauty and strength of
understanding."
T'this Penelope replied, "Eurymachus, heaven robbed me of all my
beauty whether of face or figure when the Argives set sail for Troy and
my dear husband with them. If he were t'return and look after my
affairs, I should both be more respected and show a better presence to
the world. As it is, I am oppressed with care, and with the afflictions
which heaven has seen fit t'heap upon me. My husband foresaw it all,
and when he was leaving home he took my right wrist in his hand—'Wife,'
he said, 'we shall not all of us come safe home from Troy, for the
Trojans fight well both with bow and spear. They are excellent als'at
fighting from chariots, and nothing decides the issue of a fight sooner
than this. I know not, therefore, whether heaven will send me back to
you, or whether I may not fall over there at Troy. In the meantime do
you look after things here. Take care of my father and mother as at
present, and even more s'during my absence, but when you see our son
growing a beard, then marry whom you will, and leave this your present
home.' This is what he said and now it is all coming true. A night will
come when I shall have t'yield myself t'a marriage which I detest,
for Jove has taken from me all hope of happiness. This further grief,
moreover, cuts me t'the very heart. You suitors are not wooing me
after the custom of my country. When men are courting a woman wh'they
think will be a good wife t'them and wh'is of noble birth, and when
they are each trying t'win her for himself, they usually bring oxen
and sheep t'feast the friends of the lady, and they make her
magnificent presents, instead of eating up other people's property
without paying for it."
This was what she said, and Ulysses was glad when he heard her trying
t'get presents out of the suitors, and flattering them with fair words
which he knew she did not mean.
Then Antinous said, "Queen Penelope, daughter of Icarius, take as many
presents as you please from any one wh'will give them t'you; it is
not well t'refuse a present; but we will not g'about our business nor
stir from where we are, till you have married the best man among us
whoever he may be."
The others applauded what Antinous had said, and each one sent his
servant t'bring his present. Antinous's man returned with a large and
lovely dress most exquisitely embroidered. It had twelve beautifully
made brooch pins of pure gold with which t'fasten it. Eurymachus
immediately brought her a magnificent chain of gold and amber beads
that gleamed like sunlight. Eurydamas's tw'men returned with some
earrings fashioned int'three brilliant pendants which glistened most
beautifully; while king Pisander son of Polyctor gave her a necklace of
the rarest workmanship, and every one else brought her a beautiful
present of some kind.
Then the queen went back t'her room upstairs, and her maids brought
the presents after her. Meanwhile the suitors took t'singing and
dancing, and stayed till evening came. They danced and sang till it
grew dark; they then brought in three braziers151 t'give light, and
piled them up with chopped firewood very old and dry, and they lit
torches from them, which the maids held up turn and turn about. Then
Ulysses said:
"Maids, servants of Ulysses wh'has s'long been absent, g't'the
queen inside the house; sit with her and amuse her, or spin, and pick
wool. I will hold the light for all these people. They may stay till
morning, but shall not beat me, for I can stand a great deal."
The maids looked at one another and laughed, while pretty Melantho
began t'gibe at him contemptuously. She was daughter t'Dolius, but
had been brought up by Penelope, wh'used t'give her toys t'play
with, and looked after her when she was a child; but in spite of all
this she showed n'consideration for the sorrows of her mistress, and
used t'misconduct herself with Eurymachus, with whom she was in love.
"Poor wretch," said she, "are you gone clean out of your mind? G'and
sleep in some smithy, or place of public gossips, instead of chattering
here. Are you not ashamed of opening your mouth before your betters—so
many of them too? Has the wine been getting int'your head, or d'you
always babble in this way? You seem t'have lost your wits because you
beat the tramp Irus; take care that a better man than he does not come
and cudgel you about the head till he pack you bleeding out of the
house."
"Vixen," replied Ulysses, scowling at her, "I will g'and tell
Telemachus what you have been saying, and he will have you torn limb
from limb."
With these words he scared the women, and they went off int'the body
of the house. They trembled all over, for they thought he would d'as
he said. But Ulysses took his stand near the burning braziers, holding
up torches and looking at the people—brooding the while on things that
should surely come t'pass.
But Minerva would not let the suitors for one moment cease their
insolence, for she wanted Ulysses t'become even more bitter against
them; she therefore set Eurymachus son of Polybus on t'gibe at him,
which made the others laugh. "Listen t'me," said he, "you suitors of
Queen Penelope, that I may speak even as I am minded. It is not for
nothing that this man has come t'the house of Ulysses; I believe the
light has not been coming from the torches, but from his own head—for
his hair is all gone, every bit of it."
Then turning t'Ulysses he said, "Stranger, will you work as a servant,
if I send you t'the wolds and see that you are well paid? Can you
build a stone fence, or plant trees? I will have you fed all the year
round, and will find you in shoes and clothing. Will you go, then? Not
you; for you have got int'bad ways, and d'not want t'work; you had
rather fill your belly by going round the country begging."
"Eurymachus," answered Ulysses, "if you and I were t'work one against
the other in early summer when the days are at their longest—give me a
good scythe, and take another yourself, and let us see which will last
the longer or mow the stronger, from dawn till dark when the mowing
grass is about. Or if you will plough against me, let us each take a
yoke of tawny oxen, well-mated and of great strength and endurance:
turn me int'a four acre field, and see whether you or I can drive the
straighter furrow. If, again, war were t'break out this day, give me a
shield, a couple of spears and a helmet fitting well upon my
temples—you would find me foremost in the fray, and would cease your
gibes about my belly. You are insolent and cruel, and think yourself a
great man because you live in a little world, and that a bad one. If
Ulysses comes t'his own again, the doors of his house are wide, but
you will find them narrow when you try t'fly through them."
Eurymachus was furious at all this. He scowled at him and cried, "You
wretch, I will soon pay you out for daring t'say such things t'me,
and in public too. Has the wine been getting int'your head or d'you
always babble in this way? You seem t'have lost your wits because you
beat the tramp Irus." With this he caught hold of a footstool, but
Ulysses sought protection at the knees of Amphinomus of Dulichium, for
he was afraid. The stool hit the cupbearer on his right hand and
knocked him down: the man fell with a cry flat on his back, and his
wine-jug fell ringing t'the ground. The suitors in the covered
cloister were now in an uproar, and one would turn towards his
neighbour, saying, "I wish the stranger had gone somewhere else, bad
luck t'him, for all the trouble he gives us. We cannot permit such
disturbance about a beggar; if such ill counsels are t'prevail we
shall have n'more pleasure at our banquet."
On this Telemachus came forward and said, "Sirs, are you mad? Can you
not carry your meat and your liquor decently? Some evil spirit has
possessed you. I d'not wish t'drive any of you away, but you have had
your suppers, and the sooner you all g'home t'bed the better."
The suitors bit their lips and marvelled at the boldness of his speech;
but Amphinomus the son of Nisus, wh'was son t'Aretias, said, "D'not
let us take offence; it is reasonable, s'let us make n'answer.
Neither let us d'violence t'the stranger nor t'any of Ulysses'
servants. Let the cupbearer g'round with the drink-offerings, that we
may make them and g'home t'our rest. As for the stranger, let us
leave Telemachus t'deal with him, for it is t'his house that he has
come."
Thus did he speak, and his saying pleased them well, s'Mulius of
Dulichium, servant t'Amphinomus, mixed them a bowl of wine and water
and handed it round t'each of them man by man, whereon they made their

scenes.title: Ulysses and Telemachus Plan
scenes.summary: Ulysses instructs Telemachus to remove the armor.
scenes.text:
TELEMACHUS AND ULYSSES REMOVE THE ARMOUR—ULYSSES INTERVIEWS
PENELOPE—EURYCLEA WASHES HIS FEET AND RECOGNISES THE SCAR ON HIS
LEG—PENELOPE TELLS HER DREAM T'ULYSSES.
Ulysses was left in the cloister, pondering on the means whereby with
Minerva's help he might be able t'kill the suitors. Presently he said
t'Telemachus, "Telemachus, we must get the armour together and take it
down inside. Make some excuse when the suitors ask you why you have
removed it. Say that you have taken it t'be out of the way of the
smoke, inasmuch as it is n'longer what it was when Ulysses went away,
but has become soiled and begrimed with soot. Add t'this more
particularly that you are afraid Jove may set them on t'quarrel over
their wine, and that they may d'each other some harm which may
disgrace both banquet and wooing, for the sight of arms sometimes
tempts people t'use them."
Telemachus approved of what his father had said, s'he called nurse
Euryclea and said, "Nurse, shut the women up in their room, while I
take the armour that my father left behind him down int'the store
room. N'one looks after it now my father is gone, and it has got all
smirched with soot during my own boyhood. I want t'take it down where
the smoke cannot reach it."
"I wish, child," answered Euryclea, "that you would take the management
of the house int'your own hands altogether, and look after all the
property yourself. But wh'is t'g'with you and light you t'the
store-room? The maids would have done so, but you would not let them."
"The stranger," said Telemachus, "shall show me a light; when people
eat my bread they must earn it, n'matter where they come from."
Euryclea did as she was told, and bolted the women inside their room.
Then Ulysses and his son made all haste t'take the helmets, shields,
and spears inside; and Minerva went before them with a gold lamp in her
hand that shed a soft and brilliant radiance, whereon Telemachus said,
"Father, my eyes behold a great marvel: the walls, with the rafters,
crossbeams, and the supports on which they rest are all aglow as with a
flaming fire. Surely there is some god here wh'has come down from
heaven."
"Hush," answered Ulysses, "hold your peace and ask n'questions, for
this is the manner of the gods. Get you t'your bed, and leave me here
t'talk with your mother and the maids. Your mother in her grief will
ask me all sorts of questions."
On this Telemachus went by torch-light t'the other side of the inner
court, t'the room in which he always slept. There he lay in his bed

scenes.title: Penelope's Arrival
scenes.summary: Penelope comes down to join Ulysses and the maids.
scenes.text:
till morning, while Ulysses was left in the cloister pondering on the
means whereby with Minerva's help he might be able t'kill the suitors.
Then Penelope came down from her room looking like Venus or Diana, and
they set her a seat inlaid with scrolls of silver and ivory near the
fire in her accustomed place. It had been made by Icmalius and had a
footstool all in one piece with the seat itself; and it was covered
with a thick fleece: on this she now sat, and the maids came from the
women's room t'join her. They set about removing the tables at which
the wicked suitors had been dining, and took away the bread that was
left, with the cups from which they had drunk. They emptied the embers
out of the braziers, and heaped much wood upon them t'give both light
and heat; but Melanth'began t'rail at Ulysses a second time and said,
"Stranger, d'you mean t'plague us by hanging about the house all
night and spying upon the women? Be off, you wretch, outside, and eat
your supper there, or you shall be driven out with a firebrand."
Ulysses scowled at her and answered, "My good woman, why should you be
s'angry with me? Is it because I am not clean, and my clothes are all
in rags, and because I am obliged t'g'begging about after the manner
of tramps and beggars generally? I to'was a rich man once, and had a
fine house of my own; in those days I gave t'many a tramp such as I
now am, n'matter wh'he might be nor what he wanted. I had any number
of servants, and all the other things which people have wh'live well
and are accounted wealthy, but it pleased Jove t'take all away from
me; therefore, woman, beware lest you to'come t'lose that pride and
place in which you now wanton above your fellows; have a care lest you
get out of favour with your mistress, and lest Ulysses should come
home, for there is still a chance that he may d'so. Moreover, though
he be dead as you think he is, yet by Apollo's will he has left a son
behind him, Telemachus, wh'will note anything done amiss by the maids
in the house, for he is now n'longer in his boyhood."
Penelope heard what he was saying and scolded the maid, "Impudent
baggage," said she, "I see how abominably you are behaving, and you
shall smart for it. You knew perfectly well, for I told you myself,
that I was going t'see the stranger and ask him about my husband, for
whose sake I am in such continual sorrow."
Then she said t'her head waiting woman Eurynome, "Bring a seat with a
fleece upon it, for the stranger t'sit upon while he tells his story,
and listens t'what I have t'say. I wish t'ask him some questions."
Eurynome brought the seat at once and set a fleece upon it, and as soon
as Ulysses had sat down Penelope began by saying, "Stranger, I shall
