scenes.title: Ulysses Reveals His Identity
scenes.summary: Ulysses speaks to Penelope about his past and their shared history.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Ulysses recounting his story.
scenes.text:
first ask you wh'and whence are you? Tell me of your town and
parents."
"Madam," answered Ulysses, "wh'on the face of the whole earth can dare
t'chide with you? Your fame reaches the firmament of heaven itself;
you are like some blameless king, wh'upholds righteousness, as the
monarch over a great and valiant nation: the earth yields its wheat and
barley, the trees are loaded with fruit, the ewes bring forth lambs,
and the sea abounds with fish by reason of his virtues, and his people
d'good deeds under him. Nevertheless, as I sit here in your house, ask
me some other question and d'not seek t'know my race and family, or
you will recall memories that will yet more increase my sorrow. I am
full of heaviness, but I ought not t'sit weeping and wailing in
another person's house, nor is it well t'be thus grieving continually.
I shall have one of the servants or even yourself complaining of me,
and saying that my eyes swim with tears because I am heavy with wine."
Then Penelope answered, "Stranger, heaven robbed me of all beauty,
whether of face or figure, when the Argives set sail for Troy and my
dear husband with them. If he were t'return and look after my affairs
I should be both more respected and should show a better presence to
the world. As it is, I am oppressed with care, and with the afflictions
which heaven has seen fit t'heap upon me. The chiefs from all our
islands—Dulichium, Same, and Zacynthus, as als'from Ithaca itself, are
wooing me against my will and are wasting my estate. I can therefore
show n'attention t'strangers, nor suppliants, nor t'people wh'say
that they are skilled artisans, but am all the time broken-hearted
about Ulysses. They want me t'marry again at once, and I have to
invent stratagems in order t'deceive them. In the first place heaven
put it in my mind t'set up a great tambour-frame in my room, and to
begin working upon an enormous piece of fine needlework. Then I said to
them, 'Sweethearts, Ulysses is indeed dead, still, d'not press me to
marry again immediately; wait—for I would not have my skill in
needlework perish unrecorded—till I have finished making a pall for the
her'Laertes, t'be ready against the time when death shall take him.
He is very rich, and the women of the place will talk if he is laid out
without a pall.' This was what I said, and they assented; whereon I
used t'keep working at my great web all day long, but at night I would
unpick the stitches again by torch light. I fooled them in this way for
three years without their finding it out, but as time wore on and I was
now in my fourth year, in the waning of moons, and many days had been
accomplished, those good for nothing hussies my maids betrayed me to
the suitors, wh'broke in upon me and caught me; they were very angry
with me, s'I was forced t'finish my work whether I would or no. And
now I d'not see how I can find any further shift for getting out of
this marriage. My parents are putting great pressure upon me, and my
son chafes at the ravages the suitors are making upon his estate, for
he is now old enough t'understand all about it and is perfectly able
t'look after his own affairs, for heaven has blessed him with an
excellent disposition. Still, notwithstanding all this, tell me wh'you
are and where you come from—for you must have had father and mother of
some sort; you cannot be the son of an oak or of a rock."

characters.quote: I fooled them in this way for three years without their finding it out, but as time wore on and I was now in my fourth year...

scenes.title: Penelope's Dream
scenes.summary: Penelope shares her dream with Ulysses and seeks interpretation.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Penelope's dream discussion.
scenes.text:
Then Ulysses answered, "Madam, wife of Ulysses, since you persist in
asking me about my family, I will answer, n'matter what it costs me:
people must expect t'be pained when they have been exiles as long as I
have, and suffered as much among as many peoples. Nevertheless, as
regards your question I will tell you all you ask. There is a fair and
fruitful island in mid-ocean called Crete; it is thickly peopled and
there are ninety cities in it: the people speak many different
languages which overlap one another, for there are Achaeans, brave
Eteocretans, Dorians of three-fold race, and noble Pelasgi. There is a
great town there, Cnossus, where Minos reigned wh'every nine years had
a conference with Jove himself.152 Minos was father t'Deucalion, whose
son I am, for Deucalion had tw'sons Idomeneus and myself. Idomeneus
sailed for Troy, and I, wh'am the younger, am called Aethon; my
brother, however, was at once the older and the more valiant of the
two; hence it was in Crete that I saw Ulysses and showed him
hospitality, for the winds took him there as he was on his way t'Troy,
carrying him out of his course from cape Malea and leaving him in
Amnisus off the cave of Ilithuia, where the harbours are difficult to
enter and he could hardly find shelter from the winds that were then
raging. As soon as he got there he went int'the town and asked for
Idomeneus, claiming t'be his old and valued friend, but Idomeneus had
already set sail for Troy some ten or twelve days earlier, s'I took
him t'my own house and showed him every kind of hospitality, for I had
abundance of everything. Moreover, I fed the men wh'were with him with
barley meal from the public store, and got subscriptions of wine and
oxen for them t'sacrifice t'their heart's content. They stayed with
me twelve days, for there was a gale blowing from the North s'strong
that one could hardly keep one's feet on land. I suppose some
unfriendly god had raised it for them, but on the thirteenth day the
wind dropped, and they got away."
Many a plausible tale did Ulysses further tell her, and Penelope wept
as she listened, for her heart was melted. As the snow wastes upon the
mountain tops when the winds from South East and West have breathed
upon it and thawed it till the rivers run bank full with water, even so
did her cheeks overflow with tears for the husband wh'was all the time
sitting by her side. Ulysses felt for her and was sorry for her, but he
kept his eyes as hard as horn or iron without letting them s'much as
quiver, s'cunningly did he restrain his tears. Then, when she had
relieved herself by weeping, she turned t'him again and said: "Now,
stranger, I shall put you t'the test and see whether or n'you really
did entertain my husband and his men, as you say you did. Tell me,
then, how he was dressed, what kind of a man he was t'look at, and so
als'with his companions."
"Madam," answered Ulysses, "it is such a long time ag'that I can
hardly say. Twenty years are come and gone since he left my home, and
went elsewhither; but I will tell you as well as I can recollect.
Ulysses wore a mantle of purple wool, double lined, and it was fastened
by a gold brooch with tw'catches for the pin. On the face of this
there was a device that shewed a dog holding a spotted fawn between his
fore paws, and watching it as it lay panting upon the ground. Every one

characters.name: Storytelling And Memory
characters.importance_exp: The passage of time and its effects on memory are crucial to the characters' interactions.
characters.quote: Twenty years are come and gone since he left my home, and went elsewhither; but I will tell you as well as I can recollect.

scenes.title: Euryclea Recognizes Ulysses
scenes.summary: Euryclea washes Ulysses' feet and recognizes him by his scar.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the washing scene.
scenes.text:
marvelled at the way in which these things had been done in gold, the
dog looking at the fawn, and strangling it, while the fawn was
struggling convulsively t'escape.153 As for the shirt that he wore
next his skin, it was s'soft that it fitted him like the skin of an
onion, and glistened in the sunlight t'the admiration of all the women
wh'beheld it. Furthermore I say, and lay my saying t'your heart, that
I d'not know whether Ulysses wore these clothes when he left home, or
whether one of his companions had given them t'him while he was on his
voyage; or possibly some one at whose house he was staying made him a
present of them, for he was a man of many friends and had few equals
among the Achaeans. I myself gave him a sword of bronze and a beautiful
purple mantle, double lined, with a shirt that went down t'his feet,
and I sent him on board his ship with every mark of honour. He had a
servant with him, a little older than himself, and I can tell you what
he was like; his shoulders were hunched,154 he was dark, and he had
thick curly hair. His name was Eurybates, and Ulysses treated him with
greater familiarity than he did any of the others, as being the most
like-minded with himself."
Penelope was moved still more deeply as she heard the indisputable
proofs that Ulysses laid before her; and when she had again found
relief in tears she said t'him, "Stranger, I was already disposed to
pity you, but henceforth you shall be honoured and made welcome in my
house. It was I wh'gave Ulysses the clothes you speak of. I took them
out of the store room and folded them up myself, and I gave him also
the gold brooch t'wear as an ornament. Alas! I shall never welcome him
home again. It was by an ill fate that he ever set out for that
detested city whose very name I cannot bring myself even t'mention."
Then Ulysses answered, "Madam, wife of Ulysses, d'not disfigure
yourself further by grieving thus bitterly for your loss, though I can
hardly blame you for doing so. A woman wh'has loved her husband and
borne him children, would naturally be grieved at losing him, even
though he were a worse man than Ulysses, wh'they say was like a god.
Still, cease your tears and listen t'what I can tell you. I will hide
nothing from you, and can say with perfect truth that I have lately
heard of Ulysses as being alive and on his way home; he is among the
Thesprotians, and is bringing back much valuable treasure that he has
begged from one and another of them; but his ship and all his crew were
lost as they were leaving the Thrinacian island, for Jove and the
sun-god were angry with him because his men had slaughtered the
sun-god's cattle, and they were all drowned t'a man. But Ulysses stuck
t'the keel of the ship and was drifted on t'the land of the
Phaeacians, wh'are near of kin t'the immortals, and wh'treated him
as though he had been a god, giving him many presents, and wishing to
escort him home safe and sound. In fact Ulysses would have been here
long ago, had he not thought better t'g'from land t'land gathering
wealth; for there is n'man living wh'is s'wily as he is; there is no
one can compare with him. Pheidon king of the Thesprotians told me all
this, and he swore t'me—making drink-offerings in his house as he did
so—that the ship was by the water side and the crew found wh'would
take Ulysses t'his own country. He sent me off first, for there
happened t'be a Thesprotian ship sailing for the wheat-growing island
of Dulichium, but he showed me all the treasure Ulysses had got
together, and he had enough lying in the house of king Pheidon t'keep
his family for ten generations; but the king said Ulysses had gone to
Dodona that he might learn Jove's mind from the high oak tree, and know
whether after s'long an absence he should return t'Ithaca openly or
in secret. S'you may know he is safe and will be here shortly; he is
close at hand and cannot remain away from home much longer;
nevertheless I will confirm my words with an oath, and call Jove wh'is
the first and mightiest of all gods t'witness, as als'that hearth of
Ulysses t'which I have now come, that all I have spoken shall surely
come t'pass. Ulysses will return in this self same year; with the end
of this moon and the beginning of the next he will be here."
"May it be even so," answered Penelope; "if your words come true you
shall have such gifts and such good will from me that all wh'see you
shall congratulate you; but I know very well how it will be. Ulysses
will not return, neither will you get your escort hence, for s'surely
as that Ulysses ever was, there are now n'longer any such masters in
the house as he was, t'receive honourable strangers or t'further them
on their way home. And now, you maids, wash his feet for him, and make
him a bed on a couch with rugs and blankets, that he may be warm and
quiet till morning. Then, at day break wash him and anoint him again,
that he may sit in the cloister and take his meals with Telemachus. It
shall be the worse for any one of these hateful people wh'is uncivil
t'him; like it or not, he shall have n'more t'd'in this house. For
how, sir, shall you be able t'learn whether or n'I am superior to
others of my sex both in goodness of heart and understanding, if I let
you dine in my cloisters squalid and ill clad? Men live but for a
little season; if they are hard, and deal hardly, people wish them ill
s'long as they are alive, and speak contemptuously of them when they
are dead, but he that is righteous and deals righteously, the people
tell of his praise among all lands, and many shall call him blessed."
Ulysses answered, "Madam, I have foresworn rugs and blankets from the
day that I left the snowy ranges of Crete t'g'on shipboard. I will
lie as I have lain on many a sleepless night hitherto. Night after
night have I passed in any rough sleeping place, and waited for
morning. Nor, again, d'I like having my feet washed; I shall not let
any of the young hussies about your house touch my feet; but, if you
have any old and respectable woman wh'has gone through as much trouble
as I have, I will allow her t'wash them."
T'this Penelope said, "My dear sir, of all the guests wh'ever yet
came t'my house there never was one wh'spoke in all things with such
admirable propriety as you do. There happens t'be in the house a most
respectable old woman—the same wh'received my poor dear husband in her
arms the night he was born, and nursed him in infancy. She is very
feeble now, but she shall wash your feet." "Come here," said she,
"Euryclea, and wash your master's age-mate; I suppose Ulysses' hands
and feet are very much the same now as his are, for trouble ages all of
us dreadfully fast."
On these words the old woman covered her face with her hands; she began
t'weep and made lamentation saying, "My dear child, I cannot think
whatever I am t'd'with you. I am certain n'one was ever more
god-fearing than yourself, and yet Jove hates you. N'one in the whole
world ever burned him more thigh bones, nor gave him finer hecatombs
when you prayed you might come t'a green old age yourself and see your
son grow up t'take after you: yet see how he has prevented you alone
from ever getting back t'your own home. I have n'doubt the women in
some foreign palace which Ulysses has got t'are gibing at him as all
these sluts here have been gibing at you. I d'not wonder at your not
choosing t'let them wash you after the manner in which they have
insulted you; I will wash your feet myself gladly enough, as Penelope
has said that I am t'd'so; I will wash them both for Penelope's sake
and for your own, for you have raised the most lively feelings of
compassion in my mind; and let me say this moreover, which pray attend
to; we have had all kinds of strangers in distress come here before
now, but I make bold t'say that n'one ever yet came wh'was s'like
Ulysses in figure, voice, and feet as you are."
"Those wh'have seen us both," answered Ulysses, "have always said we
were wonderfully like each other, and now you have noticed it too."
Then the old woman took the cauldron in which she was going t'wash his

scenes.title: Penelope's Doubts
scenes.summary: Penelope expresses her doubts about Ulysses' return and her situation.
scenes.text:
feet, and poured plenty of cold water int'it, adding hot till the bath
was warm enough. Ulysses sat by the fire, but ere long he turned away
from the light, for it occurred t'him that when the old woman had hold
of his leg she would recognise a certain scar which it bore, whereon
the whole truth would come out. And indeed as soon as she began washing
her master, she at once knew the scar as one that had been given him by
a wild boar when he was hunting on Mt. Parnassus with his excellent
grandfather Autolycus—wh'was the most accomplished thief and perjurer
in the whole world—and with the sons of Autolycus. Mercury himself had
endowed him with this gift, for he used t'burn the thigh bones of
goats and kids t'him, s'he took pleasure in his companionship. It
happened once that Autolycus had gone t'Ithaca and had found the child
of his daughter just born. As soon as he had done supper Euryclea set
the infant upon his knees and said, "Autolycus, you must find a name
for your grandson; you greatly wished that you might have one."
"Son-in-law and daughter," replied Autolycus, "call the child thus: I
am highly displeased with a large number of people in one place and
another, both men and women; s'name the child 'Ulysses,' or the child
of anger. When he grows up and comes t'visit his mother's family on
Mt. Parnassus, where my possessions lie, I will make him a present and
will send him on his way rejoicing."
Ulysses, therefore, went t'Parnassus t'get the presents from
Autolycus, wh'with his sons shook hands with him and gave him welcome.
His grandmother Amphithea threw her arms about him, and kissed his
head, and both his beautiful eyes, while Autolycus desired his sons to
get dinner ready, and they did as he told them. They brought in a five
year old bull, flayed it, made it ready and divided it int'joints;
these they then cut carefully up int'smaller pieces and spitted them;
they roasted them sufficiently and served the portions round. Thus
through the livelong day t'the going down of the sun they feasted, and
every man had his full share s'that all were satisfied; but when the
sun set and it came on dark, they went t'bed and enjoyed the boon of
sleep.
When the child of morning, rosy-fingered Dawn, appeared, the sons of
Autolycus went out with their hounds hunting, and Ulysses went too.
They climbed the wooded slopes of Parnassus and soon reached its breezy
upland valleys; but as the sun was beginning t'beat upon the fields,
fresh-risen from the slow still currents of Oceanus, they came t'a
mountain dell. The dogs were in front searching for the tracks of the
beast they were chasing, and after them came the sons of Autolycus,
among whom was Ulysses, close behind the dogs, and he had a long spear
in his hand. Here was the lair of a huge boar among some thick
brushwood, s'dense that the wind and rain could not get through it,
nor could the sun's rays pierce it, and the ground underneath lay thick
with fallen leaves. The boar heard the noise of the men's feet, and the
hounds baying on every side as the huntsmen came up t'him, s'he
rushed from his lair, raised the bristles on his neck, and stood at bay
with fire flashing from his eyes. Ulysses was the first t'raise his
spear and try t'drive it int'the brute, but the boar was to'quick
for him, and charged him sideways, ripping him above the knee with a
gash that tore deep though it did not reach the bone. As for the boar,
Ulysses hit him on the right shoulder, and the point of the spear went
right through him, s'that he fell groaning in the dust until the life
went out of him. The sons of Autolycus busied themselves with the
carcass of the boar, and bound Ulysses' wound; then, after saying a
spell t'stop the bleeding, they went home as fast as they could. But
when Autolycus and his sons had thoroughly healed Ulysses, they made
him some splendid presents, and sent him back t'Ithaca with much
mutual good will. When he got back, his father and mother were rejoiced
t'see him, and asked him all about it, and how he had hurt himself to
get the scar; s'he told them how the boar had ripped him when he was
out hunting with Autolycus and his sons on Mt. Parnassus.
As soon as Euryclea had got the scarred limb in her hands and had well
hold of it, she recognised it and dropped the foot at once. The leg
fell int'the bath, which rang out and was overturned, s'that all the
water was spilt on the ground; Euryclea's eyes between her joy and her
grief filled with tears, and she could not speak, but she caught
Ulysses by the beard and said, "My dear child, I am sure you must be
Ulysses himself, only I did not know you till I had actually touched
and handled you."
As she spoke she looked towards Penelope, as though wanting t'tell her
that her dear husband was in the house, but Penelope was unable t'look
in that direction and observe what was going on, for Minerva had
diverted her attention; s'Ulysses caught Euryclea by the throat with
his right hand and with his left drew her close t'him, and said,
"Nurse, d'you wish t'be the ruin of me, you wh'nursed me at your own
breast, now that after twenty years of wandering I am at last come to
my own home again? Since it has been borne in upon you by heaven to
recognise me, hold your tongue, and d'not say a word about it t'any
one else in the house, for if you d'I tell you—and it shall surely
be—that if heaven grants me t'take the lives of these suitors, I will
not spare you, though you are my own nurse, when I am killing the other
women."
"My child," answered Euryclea, "what are you talking about? You know
very well that nothing can either bend or break me. I will hold my
tongue like a stone or a piece of iron; furthermore let me say, and lay
my saying t'your heart, when heaven has delivered the suitors into
your hand, I will give you a list of the women in the house wh'have
been ill-behaved, and of those wh'are guiltless."
And Ulysses answered, "Nurse, you ought not t'speak in that way; I am
well able t'form my own opinion about one and all of them; hold your
tongue and leave everything t'heaven."
As he said this Euryclea left the cloister t'fetch some more water,
for the first had been all spilt; and when she had washed him and
anointed him with oil, Ulysses drew his seat nearer t'the fire t'warm
himself, and hid the scar under his rags. Then Penelope began talking
t'him and said:
"Stranger, I should like t'speak with you briefly about another
matter. It is indeed nearly bed time—for those, at least, wh'can sleep
in spite of sorrow. As for myself, heaven has given me a life of such
unmeasurable woe, that even by day when I am attending t'my duties and
looking after the servants, I am still weeping and lamenting during the
whole time; then, when night comes, and we all of us g't'bed, I lie
awake thinking, and my heart becomes a prey t'the most incessant and
cruel tortures. As the dun nightingale, daughter of Pandareus, sings in
the early spring from her seat in shadiest covert hid, and with many a
plaintive trill pours out the tale how by mishap she killed her own
child Itylus, son of king Zethus, even s'does my mind toss and turn in
its uncertainty whether I ought t'stay with my son here, and safeguard
my substance, my bondsmen, and the greatness of my house, out of regard
t'public opinion and the memory of my late husband, or whether it is
not now time for me t'g'with the best of these suitors wh'are wooing
me and making me such magnificent presents. As long as my son was still
young, and unable t'understand, he would not hear of my leaving my
husband's house, but now that he is full grown he begs and prays me to
d'so, being incensed at the way in which the suitors are eating up his
property. Listen, then, t'a dream that I have had and interpret it for
me if you can. I have twenty geese about the house that eat mash out of
a trough,155 and of which I am exceedingly fond. I dreamed that a great
eagle came swooping down from a mountain, and dug his curved beak into
the neck of each of them till he had killed them all. Presently he
soared off int'the sky, and left them lying dead about the yard;
whereon I wept in my dream till all my maids gathered round me, so
piteously was I grieving because the eagle had killed my geese. Then he
came back again, and perching on a projecting rafter spoke t'me with
human voice, and told me t'leave off crying. 'Be of good courage,' he
said, 'daughter of Icarius; this is n'dream, but a vision of good omen
that shall surely come t'pass. The geese are the suitors, and I am no
longer an eagle, but your own husband, wh'am come back t'you, and who
will bring these suitors t'a disgraceful end.' On this I woke, and
when I looked out I saw my geese at the trough eating their mash as
usual."
"This dream, Madam," replied Ulysses, "can admit but of one
interpretation, for had not Ulysses himself told you how it shall be
fulfilled? The death of the suitors is portended, and not one single
one of them will escape."
And Penelope answered, "Stranger, dreams are very curious and
unaccountable things, and they d'not by any means invariably come
true. There are tw'gates through which these unsubstantial fancies
proceed; the one is of horn, and the other ivory. Those that come

scenes.title: Ulysses' Assurance
scenes.summary: Ulysses reassures Penelope about his imminent return.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to Ulysses' final words.
scenes.text:
through the gate of ivory are fatuous, but those from the gate of horn
mean something t'those that see them. I d'not think, however, that my
own dream came through the gate of horn, though I and my son should be
most thankful if it proves t'have done so. Furthermore I say—and lay
my saying t'your heart—the coming dawn will usher in the ill-omened
day that is t'sever me from the house of Ulysses, for I am about to
hold a tournament of axes. My husband used t'set up twelve axes in the
court, one in front of the other, like the stays upon which a ship is
built; he would then g'back from them and shoot an arrow through the
whole twelve. I shall make the suitors try t'd'the same thing, and
whichever of them can string the bow most easily, and send his arrow
through all the twelve axes, him will I follow, and quit this house of
my lawful husband, s'goodly and s'abounding in wealth. But even so, I
doubt not that I shall remember it in my dreams."
Then Ulysses answered, "Madam, wife of Ulysses, you need not defer your
tournament, for Ulysses will return ere ever they can string the bow,
handle it how they will, and send their arrows through the iron."
T'this Penelope said, "As long, sir, as you will sit here and talk to
me, I can have n'desire t'g't'bed. Still, people cannot do
permanently without sleep, and heaven has appointed us dwellers on
earth a time for all things. I will therefore g'upstairs and recline
upon that couch which I have never ceased t'flood with my tears from
the day Ulysses set out for the city with a hateful name."
She then went upstairs t'her own room, not alone, but attended by her
maidens, and when there, she lamented her dear husband till Minerva
shed sweet sleep over her eyelids.

scenes.title: Ulysses Cannot Sleep
scenes.summary: Ulysses struggles with his thoughts about the suitors.
scenes.text:
ULYSSES CANNOT SLEEP—PENELOPE'S PRAYER T'DIANA—THE TW'SIGNS FROM
HEAVEN—EUMAEUS AND PHILOETIUS ARRIVE—THE SUITORS DINE—CTESIPPUS THROWS
AN OX'S FOOT AT ULYSSES—THEOCLYMENUS FORETELLS DISASTER AND LEAVES THE
HOUSE.
Ulysses slept in the cloister upon an undressed bullock's hide, on the
top of which he threw several skins of the sheep the suitors had eaten,
and Eurynome156 threw a cloak over him after he had laid himself down.
There, then, Ulysses lay wakefully brooding upon the way in which he
should kill the suitors; and by and by, the women wh'had been in the
habit of misconducting themselves with them, left the house giggling
and laughing with one another. This made Ulysses very angry, and he
doubted whether t'get up and kill every single one of them then and
there, or t'let them sleep one more and last time with the suitors.
His heart growled within him, and as a bitch with puppies growls and
shows her teeth when she sees a stranger, s'did his heart growl with
anger at the evil deeds that were being done: but he beat his breast
and said, "Heart, be still, you had worse than this t'bear on the day
when the terrible Cyclops ate your brave companions; yet you bore it in
silence till your cunning got you safe out of the cave, though you made
sure of being killed."
Thus he chided with his heart, and checked it int'endurance, but he
tossed about as one wh'turns a paunch full of blood and fat in front
of a hot fire, doing it first on one side and then on the other, that
he may get it cooked as soon as possible, even s'did he turn himself
about from side t'side, thinking all the time how, single handed as he
was, he should contrive t'kill s'large a body of men as the wicked
suitors. But by and by Minerva came down from heaven in the likeness of
a woman, and hovered over his head saying, "My poor unhappy man, why do
you lie awake in this way? This is your house: your wife is safe inside
it, and s'is your son wh'is just such a young man as any father may
be proud of."
"Goddess," answered Ulysses, "all that you have said is true, but I am
in some doubt as t'how I shall be able t'kill these wicked suitors
single handed, seeing what a number of them there always are. And there
is this further difficulty, which is still more considerable. Supposing
that with Jove's and your assistance I succeed in killing them, I must
ask you t'consider where I am t'escape t'from their avengers when it
is all over."
"For shame," replied Minerva, "why, any one else would trust a worse
ally than myself, even though that ally were only a mortal and less
wise than I am. Am I not a goddess, and have I not protected you
throughout in all your troubles? I tell you plainly that even though
there were fifty bands of men surrounding us and eager t'kill us, you
should take all their sheep and cattle, and drive them away with you.
But g't'sleep; it is a very bad thing t'lie awake all night, and you
shall be out of your troubles before long."
As she spoke she shed sleep over his eyes, and then went back to
Olympus.

scenes.title: Penelope's Prayer
scenes.summary: Penelope prays to Diana for relief from her sorrow.
scenes.text:
While Ulysses was thus yielding himself t'a very deep slumber that
eased the burden of his sorrows, his admirable wife awoke, and sitting
up in her bed began t'cry. When she had relieved herself by weeping
she prayed t'Diana saying, "Great Goddess Diana, daughter of Jove,
drive an arrow int'my heart and slay me; or let some whirlwind snatch
me up and bear me through paths of darkness till it drop me int'the
mouths of over-flowing Oceanus, as it did the daughters of Pandareus.
The daughters of Pandareus lost their father and mother, for the gods
killed them, s'they were left orphans. But Venus took care of them,
and fed them on cheese, honey, and sweet wine. Jun'taught them to
excel all women in beauty of form and understanding; Diana gave them an
imposing presence, and Minerva endowed them with every kind of
accomplishment; but one day when Venus had gone up t'Olympus t'see
Jove about getting them married (for well does he know both what shall
happen and what not happen t'every one) the storm winds came and
spirited them away t'become handmaids t'the dread Erinyes. Even s'I
wish that the gods wh'live in heaven would hide me from mortal sight,
or that fair Diana might strike me, for I would fain g'even beneath
the sad earth if I might d's'still looking towards Ulysses only, and
without having t'yield myself t'a worse man than he was. Besides, no
matter how much people may grieve by day, they can put up with it so
long as they can sleep at night, for when the eyes are closed in
slumber people forget good and ill alike; whereas my misery haunts me
even in my dreams. This very night methought there was one lying by my
side wh'was like Ulysses as he was when he went away with his host,
and I rejoiced, for I believed that it was n'dream, but the very truth
itself."

characters.name: Hope And Despair
characters.importance_exp: This theme is central to the wife's emotional state in the scene.
characters.quote: Great Goddess Diana, daughter of Jove, drive an arrow int'my heart and slay me; or let some whirlwind snatch me up and bear me through paths of darkness till it drop me int'the mouths of over-flowing Oceanus, as it did the daughters of Pandareus.

characters.name: Storytelling And Memory
characters.importance_exp: The theme reflects the wife's struggle with her memories of Ulysses.
characters.quote: whereas my misery haunts me even in my dreams.

scenes.title: Ulysses' Prayer
scenes.summary: Ulysses prays for a sign from the gods.
scenes.explanation: Location changes back to Ulysses in the cloister.
scenes.text:
On this the day broke, but Ulysses heard the sound of her weeping, and
it puzzled him, for it seemed as though she already knew him and was by
his side. Then he gathered up the cloak and the fleeces on which he had
lain, and set them on a seat in the cloister, but he took the bullock's
hide out int'the open. He lifted up his hands t'heaven, and prayed,
saying "Father Jove, since you have seen fit t'bring me over land and
sea t'my own home after all the afflictions you have laid upon me,
give me a sign out of the mouth of some one or other of those wh'are
now waking within the house, and let me have another sign of some kind
from outside."
Thus did he pray. Jove heard his prayer and forthwith thundered high up
among the clouds from the splendour of Olympus, and Ulysses was glad
when he heard it. At the same time within the house, a miller-woman
from hard by in the mill room lifted up her voice and gave him another
sign. There were twelve miller-women whose business it was t'grind
wheat and barley which are the staff of life. The others had ground
their task and had gone t'take their rest, but this one had not yet
finished, for she was not s'strong as they were, and when she heard
the thunder she stopped grinding and gave the sign t'her master.
"Father Jove," said she, "you, wh'rule over heaven and earth, you have
thundered from a clear sky without s'much as a cloud in it, and this
means something for somebody; grant the prayer, then, of me your poor
servant wh'calls upon you, and let this be the very last day that the
suitors dine in the house of Ulysses. They have worn me out with labour
of grinding meal for them, and I hope they may never have another
dinner anywhere at all."

characters.name: Divine Intervention
characters.importance_exp: The theme is central as it highlights the role of the gods in Ulysses' journey.
characters.quote: Jove heard his prayer and forthwith thundered high up among the clouds from the splendour of Olympus.

characters.name: Struggle Against Adversity
characters.importance_exp: This theme is crucial as it reflects the hardships faced by Ulysses and the miller-woman.
characters.quote: They have worn me out with labour of grinding meal for them, and I hope they may never have another dinner anywhere at all.

scenes.title: Telemachus Prepares
scenes.summary: Telemachus prepares for the day and interacts with Euryclea.
scenes.explanation: Location changes as Telemachus gets ready.
scenes.text:
Ulysses was glad when he heard the omens conveyed t'him by the woman's
speech, and by the thunder, for he knew they meant that he should
avenge himself on the suitors.
Then the other maids in the house rose and lit the fire on the hearth;
Telemachus als'rose and put on his clothes. He girded his sword about
his shoulder, bound his sandals on t'his comely feet, and took a
doughty spear with a point of sharpened bronze; then he went t'the
threshold of the cloister and said t'Euryclea, "Nurse, did you make
the stranger comfortable both as regards bed and board, or did you let
him shift for himself?—for my mother, good woman though she is, has a
way of paying great attention t'second-rate people, and of neglecting
others wh'are in reality much better men."
"D'not find fault child," said Euryclea, "when there is n'one t'find
fault with. The stranger sat and drank his wine as long as he liked:
your mother did ask him if he would take any more bread and he said he
would not. When he wanted t'g't'bed she told the servants t'make
one for him, but he said he was such a wretched outcast that he would
not sleep on a bed and under blankets; he insisted on having an
undressed bullock's hide and some sheepskins put for him in the
cloister and I threw a cloak over him myself."157
Then Telemachus went out of the court t'the place where the Achaeans
were meeting in assembly; he had his spear in his hand, and he was not
alone, for his tw'dogs went with him. But Euryclea called the maids

scenes.title: Ulysses and the Swineherd
scenes.summary: Ulysses converses with Eumaeus about the suitors.
scenes.explanation: Location changes as the swineherd arrives.
scenes.text:
Thus did she speak, and they did even as she had said: twenty of them
went t'the fountain for water, and the others set themselves busily to
work about the house. The men wh'were in attendance on the suitors
als'came up and began chopping firewood. By and by the women returned
from the fountain, and the swineherd came after them with the three
best pigs he could pick out. These he let feed about the premises, and
then he said good-humouredly t'Ulysses, "Stranger, are the suitors
treating you any better now, or are they as insolent as ever?"
"May heaven," answered Ulysses, "requite t'them the wickedness with
which they deal high-handedly in another man's house without any sense
of shame."
Thus did they converse; meanwhile Melanthius the goatherd came up, for
he to'was bringing in his best goats for the suitors' dinner; and he
had tw'shepherds with him. They tied the goats up under the gatehouse,
and then Melanthius began gibing at Ulysses. "Are you still here,
stranger," said he, "t'pester people by begging about the house? Why
can you not g'elsewhere? You and I shall not come t'an understanding
before we have given each other a taste of our fists. You beg without
any sense of decency: are there not feasts elsewhere among the
Achaeans, as well as here?"
Ulysses made n'answer, but bowed his head and brooded. Then a third
man, Philoetius, joined them, wh'was bringing in a barren heifer and
some goats. These were brought over by the boatmen wh'are there to
take people over when any one comes t'them. S'Philoetius made his
heifer and his goats secure under the gatehouse, and then went up to
the swineherd. "Who, Swineherd," said he, "is this stranger that is
lately come here? Is he one of your men? What is his family? Where does
he come from? Poor fellow, he looks as if he had been some great man,
but the gods give sorrow t'whom they will—even t'kings if it so
pleases them."
As he spoke he went up t'Ulysses and saluted him with his right hand;
"Good day t'you, father stranger," said he, "you seem t'be very
poorly off now, but I hope you will have better times by and by. Father
Jove, of all gods you are the most malicious. We are your own children,
yet you show us n'mercy in all our misery and afflictions. A sweat
came over me when I saw this man, and my eyes filled with tears, for he
reminds me of Ulysses, wh'I fear is going about in just such rags as
this man's are, if indeed he is still among the living. If he is
already dead and in the house of Hades, then, alas! for my good master,
wh'made me his stockman when I was quite young among the
Cephallenians, and now his cattle are countless; n'one could have done
better with them than I have, for they have bred like ears of corn;
nevertheless I have t'keep bringing them in for others t'eat, who
take n'heed t'his son though he is in the house, and fear not the
wrath of heaven, but are already eager t'divide Ulysses' property
among them because he has been away s'long. I have often thought—only
it would not be right while his son is living—of going off with the
cattle t'some foreign country; bad as this would be, it is still
harder t'stay here and be ill-treated about other people's herds. My
position is intolerable, and I should long since have run away and put
myself under the protection of some other chief, only that I believe my
poor master will yet return, and send all these suitors flying out of

scenes.title: The Suitors' Plot 2
scenes.summary: The suitors plot against Telemachus but are interrupted.
scenes.explanation: Location changes as the focus shifts to the suitors.
scenes.text:
the house."
"Stockman," answered Ulysses, "you seem t'be a very well-disposed
person, and I can see that you are a man of sense. Therefore I will
tell you, and will confirm my words with an oath. By Jove, the chief of
all gods, and by that hearth of Ulysses t'which I am now come, Ulysses
shall return before you leave this place, and if you are s'minded you
shall see him killing the suitors wh'are now masters here."
"If Jove were t'bring this t'pass," replied the stockman, "you should
see how I would d'my very utmost t'help him."
And in like manner Eumaeus prayed that Ulysses might return home.
Thus did they converse. Meanwhile the suitors were hatching a plot to
murder Telemachus: but a bird flew near them on their left hand—an
eagle with a dove in its talons. On this Amphinomus said, "My friends,
this plot of ours t'murder Telemachus will not succeed; let us g'to
dinner instead."

scenes.title: The Feast Begins
scenes.summary: The suitors begin their feast and insult Ulysses.
scenes.explanation: Location changes to the dining area.
scenes.text:
The others assented, s'they went inside and laid their cloaks on the
benches and seats. They sacrificed the sheep, goats, pigs, and the
heifer, and when the inward meats were cooked they served them round.
They mixed the wine in the mixing-bowls, and the swineherd gave every
man his cup, while Philoetius handed round the bread in the bread
baskets, and Melanthius poured them out their wine. Then they laid
their hands upon the good things that were before them.
Telemachus purposely made Ulysses sit in the part of the cloister that
was paved with stone;158 he gave him a shabby looking seat at a little
table t'himself, and had his portion of the inward meats brought to
him, with his wine in a gold cup. "Sit there," said he, "and drink your
wine among the great people. I will put a stop t'the gibes and blows
of the suitors, for this is n'public house, but belongs t'Ulysses,
and has passed from him t'me. Therefore, suitors, keep your hands and
your tongues t'yourselves, or there will be mischief."
The suitors bit their lips, and marvelled at the boldness of his
speech; then Antinous said, "We d'not like such language but we will
put up with it, for Telemachus is threatening us in good earnest. If
Jove had let us we should have put a stop t'his brave talk ere now."
Thus spoke Antinous, but Telemachus heeded him not. Meanwhile the
heralds were bringing the holy hecatomb through the city, and the
Achaeans gathered under the shady grove of Apollo.
Then they roasted the outer meat, drew it off the spits, gave every man
his portion, and feasted t'their heart's content; those wh'waited at
table gave Ulysses exactly the same portion as the others had, for
Telemachus had told them t'd'so.

characters.name: Courage And Determination
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus stands up to the suitors, showing bravery.
characters.quote: I will put a stop t'the gibes and blows of the suitors, for this is n'public house, but belongs t'Ulysses, and has passed from him t'me.

characters.name: Celebration And Joy
characters.importance_exp: The scene revolves around the act of sharing a meal, a key aspect of hospitality.
characters.quote: Then they roasted the outer meat, drew it off the spits, gave every man his portion, and feasted t'their heart's content;

characters.name: Respect And Honor
characters.importance_exp: Telemachus shows respect for his father by honoring Ulysses' place in the household.
characters.quote: Sit there, said he, and drink your wine among the great people.

scenes.title: Telemachus Stands Up
scenes.summary: Telemachus defends Ulysses against the suitors' insults.
scenes.explanation: Location remains in the dining area as tensions rise.
scenes.text:
But Minerva would not let the suitors for one moment drop their
insolence, for she wanted Ulysses t'become still more bitter against
them. Now there happened t'be among them a ribald fellow, whose name
was Ctesippus, and wh'came from Same. This man, confident in his great
wealth, was paying court t'the wife of Ulysses, and said t'the
suitors, "Hear what I have t'say. The stranger has already had as
large a portion as any one else; this is well, for it is not right nor
reasonable t'ill-treat any guest of Telemachus wh'comes here. I will,
however, make him a present on my own account, that he may have
something t'give t'the bath-woman, or t'some other of Ulysses'
servants."
As he spoke he picked up a heifer's foot from the meat-basket in which
it lay, and threw it at Ulysses, but Ulysses turned his head a little
aside, and avoided it, smiling grimly Sardinian fashion159 as he did
so, and it hit the wall, not him. On this Telemachus spoke fiercely to
Ctesippus, "It is a good thing for you," said he, "that the stranger
turned his head s'that you missed him. If you had hit him I should
have run you through with my spear, and your father would have had to
see about getting you buried rather than married in this house. S'let
me have n'more unseemly behaviour from any of you, for I am grown up
now t'the knowledge of good and evil and understand what is going on,
instead of being the child that I have been heretofore. I have long
seen you killing my sheep and making free with my corn and wine: I have
put up with this, for one man is n'match for many, but d'me no
further violence. Still, if you wish t'kill me, kill me; I would far
rather die than see such disgraceful scenes day after day—guests
insulted, and men dragging the women servants about the house in an
unseemly way."
They all held their peace till at last Agelaus son of Damastor said,
"N'one should take offence at what has just been said, nor gainsay it,
for it is quite reasonable. Leave off, therefore, ill-treating the
stranger, or any one else of the servants wh'are about the house; I
would say, however, a friendly word t'Telemachus and his mother, which
I trust may commend itself t'both. 'As long,' I would say, 'as you had
ground for hoping that Ulysses would one day come home, n'one could
complain of your waiting and suffering160 the suitors t'be in your
house. It would have been better that he should have returned, but it
is now sufficiently clear that he will never d'so; therefore talk all
this quietly over with your mother, and tell her t'marry the best man,
and the one wh'makes her the most advantageous offer. Thus you will
yourself be able t'manage your own inheritance, and t'eat and drink
in peace, while your mother will look after some other man's house, not
yours.'"
T'this Telemachus answered, "By Jove, Agelaus, and by the sorrows of
my unhappy father, wh'has either perished far from Ithaca, or is
wandering in some distant land, I throw n'obstacles in the way of my
mother's marriage; on the contrary I urge her t'choose whomsoever she
will, and I will give her numberless gifts int'the bargain, but I dare
not insist point blank that she shall leave the house against her own
wishes. Heaven forbid that I should d'this."
Minerva now made the suitors fall t'laughing immoderately, and set
their wits wandering; but they were laughing with a forced laughter.
Their meat became smeared with blood; their eyes filled with tears, and

scenes.title: The Prophecy
scenes.summary: Theoclymenus predicts doom for the suitors.
scenes.explanation: Location remains as the suitors react to the prophecy.
scenes.text:
their hearts were heavy with forebodings. Theoclymenus saw this and
said, "Unhappy men, what is it that ails you? There is a shroud of
darkness drawn over you from head t'foot, your cheeks are wet with
tears; the air is alive with wailing voices; the walls and roof-beams
drip blood; the gate of the cloisters and the court beyond them are
full of ghosts trooping down int'the night of hell; the sun is blotted
out of heaven, and a blighting gloom is over all the land."
Thus did he speak, and they all of them laughed heartily. Eurymachus
then said, "This stranger wh'has lately come here has lost his senses.
Servants, turn him out int'the streets, since he finds it s'dark
here."
But Theoclymenus said, "Eurymachus, you need not send any one with me.
I have eyes, ears, and a pair of feet of my own, t'say nothing of an
understanding mind. I will take these out of the house with me, for I
see mischief overhanging you, from which not one of you men wh'are
insulting people and plotting ill deeds in the house of Ulysses will be
able t'escape."
He left the house as he spoke, and went back t'Piraeus wh'gave him
welcome, but the suitors kept looking at one another and provoking
Telemachus by laughing at the strangers. One insolent fellow said to
him, "Telemachus, you are not happy in your guests; first you have this
importunate tramp, wh'comes begging bread and wine and has n'skill
for work or for hard fighting, but is perfectly useless, and now here
is another fellow wh'is setting himself up as a prophet. Let me
persuade you, for it will be much better t'put them on board ship and
send them off t'the Sicels t'sell for what they will bring."
Telemachus gave him n'heed, but sat silently watching his father,
expecting every moment that he would begin his attack upon the suitors.
Meanwhile the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, had had a rich seat
placed for her facing the court and cloisters, s'that she could hear
what every one was saying. The dinner indeed had been prepared amid
much merriment; it had been both good and abundant, for they had
sacrificed many victims; but the supper was yet t'come, and nothing
can be conceived more gruesome than the meal which a goddess and a
brave man were soon t'lay before them—for they had brought their doom

scenes.title: Penelope's Plan
scenes.summary: Penelope decides to challenge the suitors with Ulysses' bow.
scenes.text:
THE TRIAL OF THE AXES, DURING WHICH ULYSSES REVEALS HIMSELF T'EUMAEUS
AND PHILOETIUS
Minerva now put it in Penelope's mind t'make the suitors try their
skill with the bow and with the iron axes, in contest among themselves,
as a means of bringing about their destruction. She went upstairs and
got the store-room key, which was made of bronze and had a handle of
ivory; she then went with her maidens int'the store-room at the end of
the house, where her husband's treasures of gold, bronze, and wrought
iron were kept, and where was als'his bow, and the quiver full of
deadly arrows that had been given him by a friend whom he had met in
Lacedaemon—Iphitus the son of Eurytus. The tw'fell in with one another
in Messene at the house of Ortilochus, where Ulysses was staying in
order t'recover a debt that was owing from the whole people; for the
Messenians had carried off three hundred sheep from Ithaca, and had
sailed away with them and with their shepherds. In quest of these
Ulysses took a long journey while still quite young, for his father and
the other chieftains sent him on a mission t'recover them. Iphitus had
gone there als't'try and get back twelve brood mares that he had
lost, and the mule foals that were running with them. These mares were
the death of him in the end, for when he went t'the house of Jove's
son, mighty Hercules, wh'performed such prodigies of valour, Hercules
t'his shame killed him, though he was his guest, for he feared not
heaven's vengeance, nor yet respected his own table which he had set
before Iphitus, but killed him in spite of everything, and kept the
mares himself. It was when claiming these that Iphitus met Ulysses, and
gave him the bow which mighty Eurytus had been used t'carry, and which
on his death had been left by him t'his son. Ulysses gave him in
return a sword and a spear, and this was the beginning of a fast
friendship, although they never visited at one another's houses, for
Jove's son Hercules killed Iphitus ere they could d'so. This bow,
then, given him by Iphitus, had not been taken with him by Ulysses when
he sailed for Troy; he had used it s'long as he had been at home, but
had left it behind as having been a keepsake from a valued friend.
Penelope presently reached the oak threshold of the store-room; the
carpenter had planed this duly, and had drawn a line on it s'as t'get
it quite straight; he had then set the door posts int'it and hung the
doors. She loosed the strap from the handle of the door, put in the
key, and drove it straight home t'shoot back the bolts that held the
doors;161 these flew open with a noise like a bull bellowing in a
meadow, and Penelope stepped upon the raised platform, where the chests
stood in which the fair linen and clothes were laid by along with
fragrant herbs: reaching thence, she took down the bow with its bow
case from the peg on which it hung. She sat down with it on her knees,
weeping bitterly as she took the bow out of its case, and when her
tears had relieved her, she went t'the cloister where the suitors
were, carrying the bow and the quiver, with the many deadly arrows that
were inside it. Along with her came her maidens, bearing a chest that
contained much iron and bronze which her husband had won as prizes.
When she reached the suitors, she stood by one of the bearing-posts
supporting the roof of the cloister, holding a veil before her face,
and with a maid on either side of her. Then she said:
"Listen t'me you suitors, wh'persist in abusing the hospitality of
this house because its owner has been long absent, and without other
pretext than that you want t'marry me; this, then, being the prize
that you are contending for, I will bring out the mighty bow of
Ulysses, and whomsoever of you shall string it most easily and send his
arrow through each one of twelve axes, him will I follow and quit this
house of my lawful husband, s'goodly, and s'abounding in wealth. But
even s'I doubt not that I shall remember it in my dreams."
As she spoke, she told Eumaeus t'set the bow and the pieces of iron
before the suitors, and Eumaeus wept as he took them t'd'as she had
